comments.text: Great inspiration and wonderful program! I've been trying to do some of these things but only in a course context...  I love the experiential learning, the multidisciplinarity, and the enthusiasm part... this is where students might learn how to keep (or regain) a prototyping spirit and learn that failing sometimes happen (and is needed) when you innovate. thanks for sharing!

Awesome! A similar initiative was just announced at my university. By taking 2 courses in Digital Specialization, students will have "the opportunity to acquire digital skills and achieve academic credit for pursuit of students entrepreneurial ideas in the areas of business and social innovation." More information can be found here: http://digitalmediazone.ryerson.ca/2012/03/27/ryerson-university-introduces-canada%E2%80%99s-first-digital-specialization-program/

comments.text: Hi Kelsey,Yes, I will 100 times aplaud this , if I can.I trully beleive, then PLAYING is most natural and powerfull way of learing.I will add there may be one theme and this is a "team forming". Start-ups often start with 2-6  peoples and after some time then need to grow quickly to 20 - 60 heads. This is wery wery chalenging.Form leared ship perspective I will add there a Leadership programs Like UK "National Business Awards, Orange Leader of the Year"Here is video with Mike Lynch, CEO, Autonomy.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6xu9-YhfQvUHis style of leadership is wery interesting :-)
Great sideways thinking, Kelsey  and congrats for being our 100th inspiration on this challenge!

the_start_up_annual.description: A book published once a year, focused on sharing new start up's and stories
the_start_up_annual.creator: 6967cabefd763ac1a1a88e11159957db

comments.text: Would love to see a Feltron Annual Report http://feltron.com/ visual data analysis mixed with stories and experiences of startups.Great idea! It would be interesting to see who you could partner with to get the idea out whether it be media, government or VC's that might fund/sponsor the project too. Could there be a local report for every city that you provide a platform to make it really easy for each city to make their own in a common branding and analysis, a little like TEDx independently organised, this would be independently organised annual report.
Canny builds, James!

Oh, Feltron-like reports are a lovely idea, James! How might we make it something people treasure and re-read, not just read and toss? TBH I think there is value in either path.... whatever gets people buzzing!

Great suggestion JamesI think partnering with schools and colleges can also be a cool way to start, I say this because colleges like NYU Poly hosts incubators for many array of companies and individuals.

There was a like-minded book i read this year that had a similar premise.  It broke some of the coolest current startups by industry and told their stories including strengths and challenges. http://www.amazon.com/The-Coolest-Startups-America-Volume/dp/0615576451/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1336774248&sr=8-1Additionally, there is this book that tells the startup stories behind some of the most recognizable companies of today.http://www.amazon.com/Founders-Work-Stories-Startups-Problem-Solution/dp/1430210788/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1336774464&sr=1-1

Great idea. We suggest you take a look at Start-up Digest and see whether you could work with them.Swing by our Web Start-up Challenge Refinement Phase Announcement: http://bit.ly/startup-shortlist + the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine for more tips!

Here's the link to start-up digest. Would be great to reach out to them and see whether you could do anything complementary... http://startupdigest.com/london/Also, it could be fun to work with Louise's "failure" series... and produce books related to that!
Big fan of my startupdigest emails....

Great idea! Another option to finding a publishing company is to print on-demand so you print once you receive an order or work with online printers such as blurb.com. This will save time and upfront costs associated with printing. Look forward to seeing the concept developing further!

Failures are many times better lessons that successes.  It would be interesting to pair this idea with other ideas, such as accelerators or co-work spaces, to study the progress of start-ups year-after-year.  Where do people get stuck?  What was the key turning point for each company?  Where do you get your advisers or board members?  What do yo know now, that you wish you knew then?   What gets measured gets managed.  Measure the progress of start-ups and share them with others.  If the 366 inspirations are any indication of the expanding field of web entrepreneurship, tracking new start-ups and pulling data out of them in aggregate could be very useful to those who come next.
I'd happily have this concept as the handout/manual for my TED+ concept... ;-)

Great concept, Jeremy. Love the builds Denny. I see two needs here: 1. celebrating start-ups - even just for starting-up, never mind if they succeed or fail2. helping start-ups learn from others' experiencesDoes it need one book or two?

Could be interesting to have 2 Amy: One for celebrating little known start-ups and the second maybe could be a 'lessons learned' supplement.. this idea reminds me of The Black List (http://blcklst.com/about/) which is an annual list of Hollywood's most liked unproduced screenplays. What is cool about this list is that if your movie gets placed on it, a lot of the films will actually then get made!

One if the things I like about this is that it would allow us to observe the changes over time of the kind of start-ups which would feature. I'm sure we'd get a few laughs a decade down the line  like if you think back to when some folks thought CD-Roms were going to take over :^) But also to track changes to social drivers, challenges and motivators, etc.

Love this idea about observing start-up trends and being a method of data collection! This also reminds me of IDEO's Tom Hulme's thought about the importance of creating new methods of data collection: http://vimeo.com/39718552

So, it will specifically appeal to other start ups or people who are interested in starting something of there own and are looking for advice? Because i am thinking that if you are trying to put your idea out there (like I'am) you have research other start-ups.

the_hero_s_journey_a_communication_devic.description: The Hero’s Journey is perhaps the most universally understood structure in the world. It communicates widely understood values, beliefs or situations that are understand regardless of race, religion or gender.
the_hero_s_journey_a_communication_devic.creator: e9677e8a046f24c99e8adefb1d34aaf5

comments.text: Love the parallels of the mythological heros journey and business startups/innovation! You would enjoy the words and videos here: http://herosjourneyentrepreneurship.org:The same classical values guiding the rising artistic renaissance will protect the artists intellectual property. The immortal ideals which guide the story of blockbuster books and movies such as The Matrix, Lord of the Rings, Braveheart, The Chronicles of Narnia, and Star Wars, are the very same ideals underlying the United States Constitution. These classic idealswhich pervade Homer, Plato, Shakespeare, and the Bibleare the source of both epic story and property rights, of law and business, of academia and civilization.Enjoy! :)
Doh. I meant to put this in the analogy category

No worries  I think most folks will appreciate the fab analogy you're making here regardless. And we're loving that you've been talking to folks about this challenge to gain insights so quick off the mark!

the_hero_s_journey_a_communication_devic.title: The Hero's Journey - A communication device whose connective tissue can successfully cross cultures

x_media_lab_the_lab.description: "X Media Lab is the best seminar/conference I ever have visit. Ten session with ultra-high level professionals gave us an opportunity to develop and sharpen our concept to clarity. We have now got our seed funding for our new web start-up." Mathias G
x_media_lab_the_lab.creator: ade79a66f1a754879925ad66d9cc748a

comments.text: Hi Mathias, great inspiration and wonderful initiative. From the video, it seems that it provides networking, informal interactions, knowledge sharing and storytelling and access to expert and mentoring. What really made the experience worth to you?Congrats on the seed funding!

Hi Anne-Laure,Thank you! It's so nice to get financial support in the right moment. Yes you are right XML provides these kind of opportunities - like many other settings.  There are lots of talk in the filed of entrepreneurship - consultants, expert with almost no experience and officials.  what was special with XML was that the mentors had ultra high experience of start ups and had two days for us and 14 other start up teams. Mentors including people owning companies they have founded now worth billions, business angels and world class creatives. Almost all regions, at least in Sweden, have the ambition to become "the world leading xxx" but the support they give in terms of knowledges people, networks ... are rarely aligned with these ambitions. That's the reason of why I am so impressed by XML. And - XML was really helpful. So my advice for EU - if you want start ups to become "best of the world" you have to offer at least matching support.

x_media_lab_the_lab.title: X Media Lab - The Lab

insights_from_a_social_entrepreneur.description: Today, I met Veronika Scott, a Detroit-based entrepreneur who has created a sustainable business that employs the homeless, gives them employment, make them independent. So naturally, I pulled out the Interview kit. Here are the answers and insights.
insights_from_a_social_entrepreneur.creator: 2e5ede96fea1eab1cdff8a2e3bad4fee

comments.text: Awesome interview!  What struck me was Veronica's insight into breaking into a new "culture".  Veronica says "they didn't trust volunteers, they didn't trust me."  It was hard for her to garner support from this group of women.  The irony was that she wasn't asking them for money or protection, she was offering them work.  Her life would have been made much easier had there been a connected individual inside the group who could convey Veronica's message . . . (think ahead to the concepting stage already hahaha)
Great story! Awesome to hear firsthand from someone who had an idea and making it come to life as well as challenges.
She was very inspiring, she also gave a lot of insights of how important it is to always remember the limitations of your employees as well as your end-users.

And talk about things coming full circle: Veronika is actually a resident sharing the Ponyride space in Detroit http://ponyride.org/ that we highlighted during our Vibrant Cities Challenge! Learn more here http://bit.ly/GTEBMh
I know, she was talking about Steel Case and how wonderful the whole experience of working with them was.
Way to go, Ashwin! Would be great if you could provide a link to the Interview Kit on your post to inspire others to use it.

Thanks Ashwin for sharing this great story. The motivation and passion of Veronika Scott is impressive and inspiring. From her interview, I got this sense of passion and belief in the idea, an idea that in some ways goes beyond her, the people - those who make things happen and those who could make things happen. How can we make sure that people with these ideas do like Veronika and make things happen? Sharing these stories is a first step: http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/learning-from-those-who-ve-been-there-before/http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/passion-meets-momentum-talkshttp://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/ted-talks-create-a-resource-of-information

comments.text: Awesome, Haiyan! I think we have a lot of similar thoughts on how innovators could benefit from a network of passionate, talented contributors. Imagine if all of the energy spent on Facebook was directed towards a purpose!The challenge I think we both face is how to get people interested in joining the network before it is well-connected. Once it's established, the benefits are very clear. Do you have any ideas for how to attract people in the beginning? One strategy we are focusing on is attracting idea people first. Because they will be excited about their idea, they will share it with their network, and we can grow organically in that way.

Hi Dan, thanks for your comment!You bring up a really good point in terms of how a platform such as this could 'go viral'. I think one strategy could be to motivate people to recommend and suggest projects to their friends.Perhaps if someone sees a project on the platform they can suggest that to a friend they think would be relevant. They could then earn 'matchmaker' points as a result.

Interesting comments - Judging by other responses OpenIDEO is already a healthy growing community to achieve this for some concepts not yet in the commercial space.I am endeavouring to determine if any of the visitors I have attracted to my site prototyping a few of the non-winning concepts from the Social Impact challenge have actually migrated to OpenIDEO too.
I'm in!

This sounds like a great idea, I like that people can help each other for free. How could already existing businesses benefit from this community? How can potential volunteers hear about this idea?  Hayley and Brittany. Wells College.
Great Resource! Sign me up! The Founder's Dictionary is need of some seriously talented coders! Love it!

I love the idea of being able to simply cheer people on! Having, if only virtual support is still invaluable to make you feel that you are working on something worthwhile. It's a important area that I haven't seen touched on much - supporting others to keep going! I'm in!

Brillant, I had the chance to participate at some activities where developers/ designer came together to help an organisation. It was quite impressive what the team managed to do in a very short amoun of time. Building such platform to help frame the project is good.
Hi Paul, great to see you on OpenIDEO and congrats on +U!I would love to do this sort of developer/designer hack event online.. taking place across many days and weeks.

Love the idea of an online hack event to get this up and running. Would be super great to see it get going during the challenge! I can see this being really useful for those who have start-up ideas but don't know where to begin. Though they bring together people who haven't met before to work together, the advantage hack-a-thons have is physicality - it is easier to work with new people in person. How might this site help get beyond that barrier to help people form virtual teams? Maybe there is a physical element from time to time as well?

hackathons_and_user_groups.description: Developers like to get together over weekends to build new products from scratch. These are called 'hackathons'. By embedding them in local surroundings and getting support from local governments, they will be easier to exist and grow.
hackathons_and_user_groups.creator: b607db01b11ee558fda6f0291ca60d2e

comments.text: Who can shed light on what the EU institutions can do to give credibility to (add weight to) the idea of organizing these events in public buildings?Who can plug us into local community (town/city) governments?

Netherlands has a national association of mayors. They participate sometimes in projects to benchmark feasibility of a project/service. But do we need top down only?I sure think we should first/also just get from let's say 10 EU places, 10 people which know 10 great public places. Why? It is easier for me to talk to a mayor/politician/public building manager with the story : You want to be the FIRST public building in this hackathon places challenge?" We connect your building with 9 other in Europe! (In other words; you miss the boat if you don't host our hackathon programme)What do you think?

Love the idea of tempting locations to be the first movers, Paul! Pjv, it sounds like you've already thought of who could be the first mover in Belgium. I'd encourage you to reach out to the manager of the Genk library or someone in local office and pitch your idea. If you don't have contacts there try reaching out cold and pointing them to this site and to Android Dev camp event. It sounds like you have great experience running hack-a-thons so it would be great to see you help Genk take up the challenge! In terms of sponsorship, what are creative ways to keep the costs down? Could the community chip in with a pot-luck lunch? Or could a salad or bottle of soda be the cost of entry? Alternatively, maybe a local business would sponsor drinks if one of the hack teams made an app for his restaurant?

Great idea Piv! For the food, I like the idea of the potluck. I remember going to art and technology in NY and everyone has to bring either food or drinks. I like also the first mover approach. It might be also Piv that you could understand what the director of Gent's library would be interested in. Maybe hackathons are not about literature, but I have the feeling that many libraries are more than about books and literature these days. Or maybe you could try to organize your event in parallel with a read-a-thon organized with the library and the local public schools.

Hi again, you might want to check this inspiration about the Moscow library http://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/inspiration/library-for-youth/ They have developed interesting facilities and programs tailored to the youth and beyond offering only access to books. You could also check what the Oslo library is doing: http://www.livework.co.uk/our-work/the-deichman-library

I could maybe plug you into my local authority here in Camden, London. Picking up on your issue about credibility - weirdly I don't think our endorsement necessarily lends credibility, but what can do is spread the word through a range of networks that aren't necessarily available to most people (local magazines, schools, council tax notices!). Also we tend to have a lot of physical space as well that we can tap into.I think the key to engaging with organisations like mine is aligning closely with the challenges we are facing on a local level. Get hold of strategic plans and pitch to us that for a small investment of local government time you can tap into a wealth of talent and ideas within our resident population. Happy to explore.

Hi, thanks all for your comments. I *am* reading them, and underwater I'm trying to also gauge some reactions from locals and my network. I expect some kind of materialization before November 2012, but I still can use help with the motivations for the public sector to chip in. The more official the better!It makes sense contacting me on Google+ profile: http://gplus.to/pjv.@Alexander: when you say "our endorsement" you mean ...? I'm still figuring out the roles on this platform.

1. One minute video. Motivating public sector:Most museums and libraries in EU are struggling with getting and keeping young people in. Any 1 minute video helping to solve this with at the experiment phase only HR involvement from them should be enough to get some going. 2. Two steps finance. Long term policy challenge : Museums and libraries are costly culture, but gov. are not going to close them down.  If the concept gives a generation X-Y-AO meaning/value to 'culture' and making people to come more. They can fit it in their next year budget planning. The first year (for 2013) would be like 3-5k, a worthy investment into hope. IF succesfull activities take place in 2013, policy makers can start reserving more from 2014 budgets.

@pjv: I guess when I say endorsement, what I am referring to is that when something has a government brand (local or national), it tends to mean a lot to people who have direct contact (usually contracts) with government but very little to the majority of people. Let's take Paul van Zoggel's post about costly library/museum services that to be honest are caught between having an important role to play but also feeling a little archaic. There is a big difference in perception between a hackathon on behalf of a local authority trying to make savings, and a hackathon where the local authority is an important but equal collaborator in tackling tough subjects and fostering insight and innovation. So what's the sell? Perhaps the opportunity to create safe, independent spaces where individuals and institutions can collaborate on equal terms to get at those ideas and resources that often feel locked away from public sector institutions.That feels a little muddled - sorry. Will have a think and try and explain my thinking better.
Interesting musings to provoke thinking around the central proposition, Alexander. Clarity around stakeholder roles and motivations will indeed be significant to effectively pitch an idea like this.

You guys have a great idea. It would be awesome if you guys had an effective way for advertising the hackathon. Also, making this a competetion might give people more incentive to participate.-Wells College
Luke Thomas, Ashlyn Loomis, Matt Condy, Matt Duffy, Diana Soler

Great idea. Our suggestion is to focus this outside of big cities in order to encourage Hackathons in more communities.Swing by our Web Start-up Challenge Refinement Phase Announcement: http://bit.ly/startup-shortlist + the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine for more tips!

Thanks. There is a lot of "hinterland" in Europe that often amounts to as much creativity as the cities. In some countries the wealth ratios city-country are even reversed, where people aspire to go live outside the big cities for success.

Exactly the right mindset I read here. Plenty of places, and weekends are great timeslots. I think if a government would have a 500-2000 euro voucher to cover basic costs to have everything 'sustainable' from food to drinks, it could spread. EC could be helping out with doing 50% matchmaking, to ensure local hackathons have an Open EU/world followup to scale/test results.

Thanks Paul, you've just very well summarized the concept and made it specific. Additionally, even if the EU would only have a public supportive program and a contact person, I could use this as a reference when talking with local governments and functionaries.

Really good idea. In some respects Hack-a-thons are the modern equivalent of the 18th Century coffee shop where people from different backgrounds would come together and debate various issues.I think ideation sessions / hack-a-thon events work best when you have a range of different professions at the core. Creative ideas are likely to be more fruitful when you have different perspectives overlapping with one another.

Tom, the coffee shop / teahouse is a big 'loss', and I hope they come 24/7 connected back. I spend a lot of time in bars/restaurants, and there has to be a way to sustainably involve existing places to meetup first online and then sometimes, like first sunday of the month to have a hackathon.@PJV; you have any more plans with this concept?

So my plans are mostly bottom-up, grassroots. As you've probably read, I organize more of these hackathons as a volunteer. We know that this generates some amount of good ideas, and that - indeed - with complimentary teams we can fine-tune or even market them. We do, and see what happens. There's a high amount of action in this concept, and a lot less thinking-talking-supporting.

hackathons_and_user_groups.title: Hackathons and user groups

comments.text: Hey guys, it is also worth looking at The Apprentice (UK version here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Apprentice_(UK_TV_series)) as an interesting model. Maybe a mix between that and what happens at an incubator or hackathon?
thats a great idea Amy, thanks.
Might be some learnings from Dragons Den for this:http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dragons'_Den

Thanks Meena for the wikipedia link. It is interesting to see that so many countries are already making a reality show on this concept. We believe involving the celebrities like in "Dancing with the stars" will make it more fun process as well as promote the idea more. Do you have any thoughts on that?
I personally think that involving stars too much kind of undermines the entrepreneurial theme. Seems like it might be better to use well known people from the business arena? eg Richard Branson.
Yeah, or he could be one of the judges!
Aside from providing an entertaining experience and start up money for entrepreneurs, this program could inspire young people to start their own businesses. A great concept to build on!
Thanks Logan , let us know if you have any suggestions to refine it further.

It's worth taking a look at this joint UK-Sri-Lankan production:http://ideators2012.com/I think anything that inspires young people to consider starting their own businesses and helps equip them with the skills they need is a good idea. What is needed is not to sell a dream but to show people it can be done and what practical steps they need to take.

Thanks for the link Tim. Ideator seems to be very interesting reality show for student entrepreneurs. You are right , such programs also have potential to inspire people to take risks who would otherwise be afraid of failures.
how would it be broadcast to the people it needs to reach
E.J. , Broadcasting the show on popular TV channel in EU would be a great way to reach  mass audience.

I really like the idea of the reality TV show. It brings publicity to the business. It also provides an entrepreneur a chance to learn through judges, as well as their own experiences, how to make their businesses more successful. Making this a competition will motivate the entrepreneurs to really sell their businesses and make people aware and awarding the winner with money will really help boost their business and make things happen faster.
Thanks Diana!

People always need money to start and connections is a great way do that. Yet Isn't becoming a Web Entrepreneur competitive as it is. By forming a T.V. Show it will only create more competition which is good but not always needed. Still Great Idea if it were to be similar to current show Shark Tank. Could see this having success!
Thanks Cody!

business_model_canvas.description: The Business Model Canvas, developed by Alexander Osterwalder, is a framework that helps you to nail down what your idea / startup is about, and maps the ecosystem necessary for your startup to thrive.
business_model_canvas.creator: 43f0831e4b1ed97eda323432ab1df335

comments.text: Glad you mentioned this. I have the book, too! And it's been more than helpful in my line of work. Sometimes, the big vision must be seen before drilling down into the fine details. You can definitely see the benfeits of the canvas especially in groups since it brings everyone's perspectives together within a simple common framework. What's funny is that over time I had to slightly modify this for nonprofits. The left hand side of the canvas was still relevant. But when you flow further to the right into value proposition and revenue streams and such, the issue of "non-financial" outcomes come to play. For example,  an organization still needs memberships or volunteers.

I'm loving the concept of approaching a start-up as a work of art!  There are patterns and repetitions, continuity and contrast.  For a successful entrepreneur, the business will work as a whole as well as in parts (think of a microsite presence for an iPod app, a Tumblr to support a new online boutique, etc.) Instead of viewers, the entrepreneurs are faced with scrutinizing customers.  Any disparity in their "artwork" would become readily apparent after a little investigation.  Could we create a platform that would allow entrepreneurs to gather the different facets of their business in one place, step back, and view the whole with a critical distance?
Wow! that's great inspiration. I can see relation between customer segmens, value proposition, chanels, etc. Thanks.
This should be taught in the first few weeks of university business courses. I'm also a big fan of http://www.amazon.co.uk/The-New-Business-Road-Test/dp/0273663569

Often, when being in the very early phases of your start-up, is is very time consuming to write a full business plan, and also sometimes not even possible to write a business plan in a realistic way, since you;re still tweaking your product or idea. Then you could start with the business model canvas, and later on get back to work on a business plan.
Owesome. Are these too the building block of a business plan? what is the difference?

Hi Sidi,To my understanding this is an organic approach to the key deliverable of a business. It cannot be a business plan because the planning part is actually missing (e.g. business environment analysis, industry background, competitor analysis, marketing plan, etc.). Instead it focuses on the key aspects of your business which need a strategy and clearly defined objectives.Best regardsManu

Indeed; you could use it as a brainstorming tool to come up with different business models, or use it to get a clear insight in your current model.Later on you could one of those business models as a starting point to write a full business plan.
Great Break down, excellent video, open source approach. The creators need a standing ovation.
I agree. I actually bought their book about this canvas. I look at it every now and then to reflect on my work.

This is a wonderful video!There's also an alternative business model canvas by OpenIDEO's own Tom Hulme, which includes things like growth strategy, and competitive strategy:http://hackfwd.com/documents/Business%20Model%20Framework.pdf
You can also play around with that business model here: http://www.phase2generator.com/ Just be sure not to hit submit unless you want to sign up for HackFwd
Great inspiration. Having these tools available is wonderfully helpful for startups.
I agree, I love this tool Bram!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

This is a great tool, Bram. In fact we've even seen it crop up a few times on OpenIDEO. Here was the first instance: http://www.openideo.com/open/how-might-we-improve-health-care-through-social-business-in-low-income-communities/concepting/food-subscription-food-insurance/ on a concept that went on to be a winner on our Social Business Challenge.

Also the intersection of ideas from Osterwalder's "Business Model Generation" including, but not solely, the canvas with the ideas of Steve Blank's "Customer Development", Eric Ries's "Lean Startup" and others have been interesting to watch and see evolve.See Alex Osterwalder's original blog post on this [http://goo.gl/kqoCp] and Steve Blank's post about his latest book [http://goo.gl/EcEuW] describing the canvas as the "scorecard" for customer discovery.

business_model_canvas.title: Business Model Canvas

helping_build_killer_teams_design_london.description: Design London brought together designers, business people, and technologists to build killer teams with a much greater chance of success.
helping_build_killer_teams_design_london.creator: 6c0385b2c8468220d8772642a066e692

comments.text: Nice one, Daniel. Perhaps, it might help others engage with this topic if you add a few links to your post? To activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link Looking forwrad to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO.

Hi Daniel, I spent a year as a visiting researcher at Design London and I agree it's a very interesting experience. Per Meena's suggestion, I would add: http://www.designlondon.net/I also thought that the STIR public lectures were great opportunities for ideas sharing: http://www.designlondon.net/stir-lectures/Yet, what I think you have in mind is the incubator which hosted the folding plug: http://www.designlondon.net/incubator/The objectives of the incubator are interesting:1. To provide tailored teaching and training to a new community of design entrepreneurs which empowers them to act as change agents in industry2. To pioneer new models for interdisciplinary incubation of design-led ventures and3. To demonstrate the value of this approach through a flow of commercially successful projectsto note is the focus on design and teaching but also the focus on interdisciplinary projects and on the experimental nature of the incubator and its approach.

Hi Anne-Laure,There was certainly a lot which came out of Design London.The big thing which struck me was how design was such an integral part of all the startups involved, and was promoted through the teaching.But also the focus on getting business people, designers, and technologists to speak some sort of common language and work together.I think a lot of the designers and technologists involved had never even met an MBA before, never mind worked with one! So breaking down those walls between disciplines was quite groundbreaking.Dan

HI Dan, I completely agree on the central role of design, which reminds me Louise's inspiration http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/have-a-designer-as-a-founder/as well as the importance of creating a shared language and creating conversations and collaborations. I remember attending sessions from the IED program http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/entrepreneurship/services/ied-projects where MBAs, engineers and designers from the RCA working in teams to develop an idea proposed by one of the members.I completely agree that going being a silos view of disciplines is key.

Design London was a proponent of getting a designer on the founding team of startups, which ties in with this other inspiration:http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/have-a-designer-as-a-founder/

helping_build_killer_teams_design_london.title: Helping build killer teams - Design London

comments.text: Here there is another example. http://www.teenbiz.org.uk/#Although there is not much information on the website it would be interesting to know more about it. In terms of funding I was thinking that it would be interesting for the teenagers to submit their projects to crowfunding pages, as part of the learning process (learning how to present and summarize the project). Apparently a group of teenagers have just created a crowfunding/consultancy websitehttp://www.prweb.com/releases/2012/4/prweb9436403.htmhttp://pentaplate.co/Of course, this idea should be evaluated and implemented in coherence with the goals and policies of the project.
Exciting updates, Heidi! I'm especially digging the mentoring aspect and celebrating of implementation.

The idea of tapping the minds of 15-19 year olds makes a lot of sense. Nice idea. The experience will also help young adults better understand themselves, jump start their thoughts about what they might want to do in the future, and build their confidence in making decisions. As far as the process these kids would go through to develop their pitch it may be helpful to give them a basic framework for pitching their ideas. Surely they could deviate from it, but it may help them determine if their idea is an opportunity and if it addresses a problem, need or desire. When I went back to school to get a masters in HCI I took an elective class called technology entrepreneurship. The final team project included coming up with a viable idea for a start up. We wrote an executive summary and then created and presented the pitch. Our professor suggested we reference some materials from the Garage Technology Ventures website. On their website you can find two pdfs: "Writing a Compelling Executive Summary" (http://www.garage.com/resources/writingexecsum.shtml) and "Perfecting Your Pitch" (http://www.garage.com/resources/perfectingpitch.shtml). Both were helpful. Creating a short two-page executive summary first was invaluable for developing the pitch. The pitch pdf guides you through building a presentation with all the necessary information (from your executive summary) to get your idea across in only 10 slides. Putting a cap on slide length or pitch time may be something to consider down the line for the pitch review process. Also, if everyone uses a similar format it may help with pitch evaluation. I am sure there are other resources like this out there or custom materials could be developed just for your website idea.
Dear Vanessa,you are absolutely right. I also think that a standardized pitching process would help a lot, both the youngsters als well as people evaluating. Thanks a lot also for the links Heidi
Glad the links are helpful. I hope your idea makes it to the final phase!

This idea reminds me of this non-profit (http://www.build.org/).  Build works with high school students to develop their own businesses.  They present at a forum, and if they win, they get their start-ups funded.  I think this idea is great since a video submission would reach a much broader audience.

A very successful EU-awarded experience in Spain is that one of Valnaln Educa, that has even gone lower in the education system, to primary education... http://www.valnalon.com/en/valnalon_educa/ Of course, this is an initiative which doesn't end up with real start ups to set up, but it's been very successful when engaging educational establishments and local context (parents, community) in the educational process regarding entrepreneurship of their children.
Dear Tracy,thanks a lot for the helpful link.Heidi
Dear Irene,its a really interesting link regarding education and goes along with an idea that I think I will bring up. Thanks a lot.Heidi

The backbone of this idea, I think, it's the scope of its audince: veeeery young entrepreneurs (15-19 years). I see the point of encouraging the "entrepreneurship culture"; however, if you think of the projects coming out of this, ready to be considered for investment... Which profile of investors do you see interested in engaging? Would they engage as sponsor of a social initiative or as actual, very business-oriented, investors? Which specific support will need this very young people, still finding their path, on the top of what an older entrepreneur (dunno, 25-35 years, or even older) would need?

Dear Irene,Just think about young US web entrepreneurs...it was often that age they started with their ideas...I believe that a lot of people underestimate the young. There is a lot of potential in the young. In addition they think in a more independent way, what the grown up might sometimes call in a childish way. However, certainly they would need help in breathing life into their projects. When it comes to the kind of projects - I am talking about social initiatives as well as business orientated projects. Tmw I will post my idea on the basis of ideo suggestions to proceed. Hasta luego :)Heidi

We love the idea of involving the 15-19 year old age group. We'd like to see you consider how this could be more educational than about starting companies. Perhaps there could be a theme every year that students have to pitch against, maybe around social good so it doesn't feel commercial. Perhaps it could follow a Eurovision type path and students could pitch across Europe in various contests.Swing by our Web Start-up Challenge Refinement Phase Announcement: http://bit.ly/startup-shortlist + the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine for more tips!

Love how this is evolving. I'm wondering what themes we could start with? Maybe something around ideas that help mitigate youth unemployment or something around making it easier to be good to the environment?

Hey there Heidi! Congrats on being shortlisted for our Refinement phase of the Web Start-up Challenge. Only one week left to evolve your concept. We hope you'll be chiming in and updating this exciting idea.
Hello, I am back  Thanks a lot, I really appreciate your remarks. Will post more tmw. :)Heidi
Heidi, there are a bunch of smart teenagers on Quora!:http://www.quora.com/Alex-Greene/Teen-Startups
Hi Avi,thanks a lot - very interesting link :)Heidi

Great idea! We always hear about young entrepreneurs, but instead of just expecting the next Mark Zuckerberg to come from nowhere, let's create an environment where we cultivate the next big CEO in schools. Instead of focusing education on "teaching to tests" we could focus on teaching for creative thinking and risk-taking. Perhaps educational standards reform is the place to start with this idea? Or creating a network for student clubs?

So a change in educational standards might be a consequence....  however, in addition it will definitely be a good network between people who are motivated to realize their ideas... thats a wounderful thing I think because this system would have something systemic - its about helping each other... I also thing it would be good to have investors (who often started successful start ups in the past to give online video talks/discussions with the young (there are lots of things that can be included in the final concept)...

Interesting Heidi. This morning I read about an 18 year old start-up guy from the US on FastCompany which I thought others might find inspiring in relation to your concept: http://www.fastcompany.com/1835159/gumroad-pinterest-sahil-lavingia
Thanks Meena for the link sharing...very interesting article...people when they are very young really have this beautiful independent thinking...out of the box...

If the former, will carrying through with the ideas be inside or outside of schoolwork?

comments.text: Very nice Sina! It seems to be a mix of an incubator and a business plan / entrepreneur competition (which has the educational component that you don't have in an incubator.http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/the-varick-street-incubator/another related inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/campus-london/From the video, I gathered a few elements:co-location and informal interactions (and the related idea sharing)networkmentoring and learningmore than the seed money...
Yah exactly. The balance of those elements really lend itself to a successful model of sustainability as well as providing an engine for growth.
I would add one more point. Mobility is a must for the majority of entrepreneurs.

Love it, Sina. I was going to post inspiration based on my experience of starting a web business through the Design Council challenges. An incubator with strict deadlines and an advisory board to provide help is essential. I've found the business mentoring and having people to generally sound ideas off is essential. You learn so much from talking to other people...creating the right environment is a must for a successful web start up.
Totally agree.

pressing_on_and_stepping_back.description: I am currently launching my own venture and I find that every day requires two seemingly opposite strategies: forcing myself to move forward and create my own next steps and forcing myself to take a step back and reconnect with myself and the world.
pressing_on_and_stepping_back.creator: ab0d5caf1dfd099bbe4505be22d5dc2f

comments.text: Meghan, you are not alone in this.  I went through the same process (and I am still going through it now) of feeling like you are driving really fast and going absolutely no where at all.  You are online finding things and making connections and contacts and as you said, when you step back you realized that the only communication you have had over the past few days has been in your head.

Thanks for sharing this story Meghan and some of the tips for how you address some of the challenges. It would also be great to hear from others about the techniques they use for support on the non-techie side of the equation. Shana, what techniques did you use?

Amy, it depends on how deep it has gotten.  Sometimes, I will not turn on the computer for a few hours (I have gone 24 hours with no computer usage before) or watching shows like Bloomberg or BBC to see what changes are going on and how it relates to what I am doing.  I will also just make a phone call to speak with someone versus sending an email or chatting when I have an issue.

I think this is an insightful look at a concern that extends well beyond entrepreneurship. While technology has effectively shrunk the world and given everyone access to so many more resources and people, it has also made it far easier to remain disconnected from all those people. As efficient and convenient as electronic connections may be, we all still need some real human interaction.

Thanks for the comments, Joshua. You are spot on in terms of what I was trying to get at.  I was excited to see that the local IDEO chapters was one of the winning entries for the competition on sustaining and growing OpenIDEO's impact.  We are so focused on technology that we often forget about the technology of the human mind itself and just how powerful it is to connect in reality, rather than virtual reality.

steve_jobs_and_the_rules_of_success.description: For entrepreneurs, Jobs' major legacy is several principles that drove his successful results. Here we tried to group the best of them. To help the future and present entrepreneurs.
steve_jobs_and_the_rules_of_success.creator: 97fa522f342b5fface534b5c73e1a544

comments.text: Thanks Team S.O.Y for this summary of Steve Jobs' main insights on entrepreneurship.I'm wondering how can we go from his story to others' stories; how or what can we generalize from this specific individual story? By that I mean, how can we get these lessons to be learnt and enacted by young entrepreneurs? Just thinking aloud, one could imagine:-having his story shared as well as others e.g. see inspirations about websites with stories of entrepreneurs- allowing educational systems to be more multidisciplinary to provide people with knowledge to make connection- teach students how to say "no"... not an easy thing to do, but nothing is impossible.etc. Regarding your point that entrepreneurs never fail, I am not sure I agree. I see your point: entrepreneurs will end up realizing their dream if they really believe in it. However, this implies often failing along the way and knowing how to fail, to be able to recover. In fact, Jobs has not always been successful. I believe he had a feeling of failure when he had to leave Apple (which was not doing great from a business standpoint at that time) in 1985. Yet, he was able to keep going, to found NeXt and eventually come back to Apple. Yet, I think knowing how to fail and to recover is key and Jobs showed he was able to do it, probably because of many of the points you mentioned in your post.thanks.al

hi, I think what we meant by "Entrepreneurs never fail" is that they fail but are never failures. In their heart defeat is never an option and Steve embodied that thought yes he did fail but but he thought of him self a failure .

Nice one guys. So it's going to be interesting as we enter the Concepting phase to think about ho we can devise fresh yet practical ideas which support these principles to help start-ups launch and grow. We're looking forward to what you come up with!
great post!

another_interview_from_a_web_entrepreneu.description: Filip Mlekicki from Chromosense LLc, BRooklyn talks about his journey from an idea to starting a company.
another_interview_from_a_web_entrepreneu.creator: 2e5ede96fea1eab1cdff8a2e3bad4fee

comments.text: It is interesting to know the interviewee said that "mentors and incubators helped, they only seemed to limit my ambition". It reminded me a YouTube clip about John Mayer telling his Berklee fellows how to study music: to combine "information" and "inspiration". Oftentimes, I try hard to understand the meaning of education. What I've got so far is: we should distinguish "knowledge" and "my knowledge" (what I have learnt combined with my inspiration)For those who interested in the clip, here it is;) http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c1i2vuN2dzU
Thanks for this interview. :D

Thanks Ashwin for posting. Nice to see the interview kit "in use" again. The insights I'm getting out of Filip's experience are:- the role of inspiration (which others have called internal motivation, drive, passion or big idea).- people and in particular personal network - mentors and incubators did not really help: this reminds us to keep in mind the difference between the theory and the practice. Not that all mentors and incubators don't work. We had great stories of success in this inspiration phase, but they don't always work. This reminds us that it is not enough to set up an incubator, you need to do it "right"- "reality check" and the importance to set up expectations and be ready for changes. Having a prototyping mindset might help?- importance of 'peers' - 'people who share the same passion as you': that reminds me a lot of the co-sharing spaces inspiration- it's not only about an individual: it's about a right team.- multiple roles / hats for an entrepreneur: be flexible...

Great stuff A-L. Ashwin  would be great if you could mention the Interview Kit and link to it on your post so folks can connect the dots of goodness ;^) Plus adding some key takeaways is a great way to promote further discussion we find.

coffee_shop_open_evenings.description: Starting up is hard. no money. no time. no resources. Just collaboration and networking. coffee shops that close in the evening open their doors and host start up evenings. The one time those with a full time job have time to meet and work.
coffee_shop_open_evenings.creator: 75d21c55c8921be6d28c6945e2479cbc

comments.text: Hello I'm a student at Wells College. For my innovations class my group and I decided to prototype your idea and perform a short skit illustrating the concept of the cafe evening hours. Here are some changes we made to the foundation of your idea: Instead of incorporating spaces from chains like starbucks, dunkin' donuts, or Tim Horton's, we propose that we invite local businesses to open up there space in the evening. This is keeping with the idea that we want to promote young businesses. Thus, in opening a space for aspiring web entrepreneurs to collaborate and make connections, we give patronage to local "underdog" businesses as well. Furthermore, we want to invite guest speakers who can interact with the evening cafe users and give them advice and support. For example, business owners who share stories of success and failure. Perhaps, local lawyers who can provide some basic advice on navigating through the legal boundaries of starting an online business. We intend for these speakers to give their advice and offer their knowledge for free. By providing these services, these speakers spread knowledge of their own business and have the opportunity to administer business cards in the cafe. We do not want to simply limit this opportunity to local coffee shops. Any small/local business in the participating area can apply for the program and become a part of this self sustaining system of web entrepreneur networking and collaboration. We preformed our skit in class and it was very well received. Viewers liked the idea of using local businesses and the minimal costs of the idea.

Great builds Logan! Love the idea of promoting local businesses instead of chains - very fitting. The speakers and services are also very much in need. I'd say to start with on this concept, keep it really simple - promote connections first. Then add on as appropriate. Maybe the question to ask is what is the most basic event that will get start-ups flocking to the cafes? Then once we have the crowds we can go from there!
Nice work Logan, the spaces could suit different startup business types as well

Another venue to consider is ING DIRECT (ING) cafe. ING has challenged the notion of banking, and thinks that learning about finance should be as easy as having a coffee with friends. I live in Toronto, Canada, and the space has been a great way for loyal ING clients (like myself) to withdraw cash,  check-out local events and meet some amazing people. The physical  layout makes the space inviting, and more importantly open to collaboration and discussion. ING is committed to investing in local communities and this could easily be a win-win for all interested partners. They have a few products re: renting space and are reasonable. Check out:  www.ingdirect.ca/en/networkorange/

We like the idea of using existing infrastructure for meetings  and think there's a lot of potential in government buildings. What about using libraries or other spaces that close in the evening for events? Swing by our Web Start-up Challenge Refinement Phase Announcement: http://bit.ly/startup-shortlist + the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine for more tips!
Not just government buildings, if local companies are willing open meeting rooms or work spaces that are not being utilized at night.

Love the concept of using coffee shops' evening hours for work and networking space. So much creativity is fueled by caffeine, after all! As additional incentive, both for independents who could use the extra business and the large chains who may not need it as much, local councils could give a discount on business rates for participating companies. Similar incentives could be provided in the form of better insurance rates or rent subsidies, to offset potential insurance increases and additional staff time.I like the idea of leveraging underutilised space in general. Similar kinds of incentives could be offered to local businesses or government buildings like libraries.

Another thought: in the same way a bar or club might agree to hold a private event at a reduced rate as long as there's a minimum spend at the bar, there could be a minimum spend agreed on for these startup events, so businesses would be assured of at least covering their staffing and other costs.

Some great comments and suggestions hereTo pull together and expand few points:Love opening it up to other people with under utilised infrastructure, that suits those timings of after work and weekend hours, such as quiet nights for clubs or late night openings for libraries - The company would need to have support staff there to monitor proceedings this could be covered by:Coffee shops and bars - spend at the tillGovernment/local authorities - government initiatives Private individuals - covered by minimal per head charge  - or act as advertising , buy supporting startups with matched space, if it becomes successful it could be a relationship that develops (e.g space gets rented on a regular basis  What is key is having the ability to match up local startups and their needs with local businesses and their under-utilised infrastructureAn online/mobile service that matches startup needs with spaces and businesses  in your local area.  Each could list their requirements and conditions, speed dating for startups and willing businessesFor example,- A business with five meeting rooms and 24/7 security would open up the rooms on a weekend end if it could ensure security and and a small cover change per head to subsidise 24/7 security they may have in place anyway. 5  teams that need to meet and collaborate could sign up for the space- A bar would open during the day  if a minimum drinks tab of $XXX was set up in the evening. a group of startups needing private space to do a bit of network would be great- A library would do special late nights if staff costs where covered by bookings. people needing quiet space to focus could attend when numbers reached acceptable levels2 key elements required for this:1.Promoting to business about the benefits, ( additional revenue, foster relationships that may turn long term)promoting to startup s and would be startups that there are business out there willing to help themPerhaps a small sign up fee for the service  could help promote  it,  along with collaboration, barter and contra deals between startups and businesses to get them going

Great discussion, guys! Dan  be sure to incorporate any feedback & new thoughts that you're keen on into your actual concept post to acknowledge your idea is evolving through these collaborative conversations. This will be important for when folks come to evaluation your idea in the next phase. This will be important for when folks come to evaluate your idea in the next phase of the challenge.

Hi all,Thanks for putting this idea forward!I've tweeted all the coffee shops in the visual to get them involved, please retweet my tweets and hopefully they will jump in.  on twitter i'm @danthemanmoran , alternatively tweet them direct @starbucks @costacoffee @Pret_uk @Caffenerolets make some noise and see what happens!
Fab idea.  Everyone's a winner with this idea!

In general I like the idea. In Berlin and London are many start-up get together in coffee shops and restaurants. Usually the scene already has its hip and cool places. chains like starbucks or costa are surely not between them!.The thing is, the scene chooses the place, not the place the scene!

I definitely see startups and creative companies using cafes in Londons for meetings. Some, like The Book Club in Shoreditch, are open until late but then it's about drinks, not working. Some independents with whom it might be interesting to follow up: Prufrock on Leather Lane (currently only open late for private events, Caravan on Exmouth Market (closed Sunday evenings), Ozone Coffee on Leonard Street by City Road, J&A Cafe off Clerkenwell Road (esp the upstairs, closed evenings and Sundays).

Great ideas - Dan, it might be fun to pop into one of those recommendations from Charlene, or local coffee shops near you, and just ask them what it would take for them to be up for something like this... would be great to hear their take on it.

Just sent out a tweet - will be interesting to see if we hear anything (Independent coffee shops... what do you make of this idea? bit.ly/K0nTh1 #oi_startup @PrufrockCoffee @DeptOfCoffee @caravanexmouth)
Here's the response from one of our local faves: Department of Coffee  @amy_bonsall It's about size of groups. Turning over a shop for 40 people is tricky during trading & expensive after hours.

motivate_yourself.creator: b6722f08b0e5a47af06afc92ad2e0bcf

comments.text: Your absolutely right, it takes a great deal of perseverance and motivation comes from the passion you have in the idea. You need tools to get from point A to Point Z.   Each step has the potential to be very intense.However, we may have some tools to allow the journey to include better visibility

motivate_yourself.title: Motivate yourself

bringing_start_ups_together_helping_them.description: General Assembly is a New York based start-up campus, combining meeting and work places for start-ups with inspirational and practical advice in seminars and events.
bringing_start_ups_together_helping_them.creator: 7771fbb20af6ef10827c593daa3aff7b

comments.text: I think the space issue is especially interesting. Many start-ups feel isolated and shared space certainly helps connect folks to also share challenges, skills, expertise, expenses, networks, suppliers, etc.

Agree, Meena. It's too easy to sit at home in front of a computer and work 24/7 to get a company off the ground but it's very isolating. People need to be encouraged to work in creative, innovative environements. The Hub Westminster in London http://hubwestminster.net/ is a great example of this.
I haven't been to their new London GA, but I think they have started there Monday Burger Night.
http://galondon.com/
THE NYC GA has a great atmosphere and location and the combination of workspaces with seminars is simply brilliant!

I believe that they are working on an online classroom environment, as well, which would be great for people like myself who follow what they do, but geographically cannot make it to one of their courses.

Glad to hear this one resonates. Great point Duncan about making it virtual so that many others can join in. What do you think are the key things one needs in a virtual element? So much of what I get from working with others is the easy banter across the table and the chats by the coffee machine. Anyone seen great sites that enable that kind of connection?
Avi, curious how you got involved in GA NY? Can anyone join in? What do you guys think needs to be different about such a set-up in Europe, if anything?

Amy, I attended one of the GA NYC Demo events (anyone can come by registering via eventbrite) and took a day-long course on Game Design. IMHO nothing needs to be that different for an European operation but locating such a set-up near a major transport and cultural hub is critical. For example, one of my considerations in signing up for the GA course was that I could walk over to the Strand bookstore near Union square afterwards:)
Thanks Avi. Great point - location is everything!
I think the 'flipped classroom' comes back to this, where learning is done online, and meeting up in person becomes collaborative and deeper, personalised learning and sharing.

Meetup I go in Dublin. Archie Talks, I was interviewed and mentioned  similar thing at the end when asked, what do you like most about coming to these events. http://youtu.be/mRccVNkAz7MLast night even, a friend who is very close to launching a social commerce fashion site was telling me about UK tax exemptions for Angel Investors, hardly general knowledge. He also gave advice to find angel investors who know one's field over VC firms who ask for lots of your time to bring them up to speed with a much lower rate of investing than angels in the field. Meetups are great!

144 inspirations... I am 'shocked' how many initiatives there are already everywhere. More is always welcome! The question in my mind reading the comments. 144 inspirations thusfar; most have a similar formula; young passionate people with fresh ideas are helped forward to go global. physical mashed with digital. great.What other 'type of webentrepeneur incubators do we need'?Are there types? types of needed web startups on Europa?Or is just because we can technically enough for now?

Great provocation, Paul. There's something in James' comment about things that aren't general knowledge that makes me wonder what is the next step up from desk sharing and informal meetups. I think it is a lot harder in Europe to find info / the right connections / funding than it is in places like SV. And yet I think the fact that we don't have a well-oiled machine like SV offers interesting advantages - we can build up an ecosystem that works well for all parties - from new entrepreneurs and investors to seasoned ones. Wondering what other industries we could learn from that started out very grass-roots and got more structured?

Next step up after arousal and sharing... 7 habits of covey probably works. (before the business canvas post-its)I totally agree on the good off not having a well oiled machine. Also because we shouldn't have that analogy! We need organic ecosystem analogy, not a factory line in our head, the EC tried that enough in FP5-6-7 There also I get the feeling there are no other 'industries' to be inspired from. I think we are really at the moment Paul Hawken said some time ago; "This generation get's to completely redesign the world... "Now where to start redesigning the Europa continent with webentrepreneuring in mind? Where is the general knowledge for that?
"Common knowledge is not so common." Voltaire.

this is a great conversation. I'd like to follow up on Louise's point on how working in a start up or small business can be a very lonely experience. It reminded me a case study I read a few days ago on DOT (organized by the design council) on the future of work: http://www.designcouncil.org.uk/our-work/challenges/Communities/Dott-07/Dott-07-case-studies/New-Work/They did a project with designers and 6 entrepreneurs in the North East of the UK.  Some common themes emerged which resonate with some I read in this thread and in other inspirations:- Working from home might not involve lengthy or costly travel to an office every day but people can feel isolated working alone- The potential to share skills and expertise with colleagues is limited when you work in a very small group- Offices are too small to hold meetings, and cafs or restaurants are often too noisy to hold serious business meetings.

Interesting to note also is that they now have a free online course with tips how to develop your brand, your team, etc. It is really well developed, check it out: http://generalassemb.ly/start/fundamentals-of-entrepreneurship.So the idea of a free online course given by reputable people might also be an inspiration.
The GA online course is awesome - it also includes a module on how to apply Design Thinking:https://generalassemb.ly/start/fundamentals-of-entrepreneurship/turning-user-insight-into-product
Meena, your comment made me think: how about a global couchsurfing network for startup founders:)

Avi, I can imagine a network of garages, changed to Hubs, for travelling social (ad)venturers to crash in. The owner could set a theme or challenge people can work on, in return he cooks a warm meal. local garagebands principle going global.
Great thoughts, guys. Remember these for when we get to concepting phase!
Also worth adding the idea that Y-combinator companies and presumably other incubator/accelerator companies behave like larger companies as associations of small companies.

bringing_start_ups_together_helping_them.title: Bringing start-ups together / helping them learn

The heavy weights should play the role of the Godfather and can help startups by forming joint venture with them and investing capital on interest. A joint venture augments a company's profile and it can meet bigger qualifying criteria after that. The fact is that the Behymoths invest in other portfolios and actually try their best to keep the entry-barrier high to make things more difficult for smaller enterprises?

comments.text: Nice idea! Perhaps to help cover the cost of running the website you could broadcast webinars through it? It would be a good excuse to connect with the experts to deliver the webinars and depending on the topic could be worth paying to access for the entrepreneurs. The webinars would facilitate Q&A so listeners would be able to get specific questions answered. Experts benefit from the exposure to a new group of potential clients. Over time you would collect a library of these videos and could release the old ones for free.

very inspiring concept! especially the screening. how to control and balance the expectations from the star-ups is also a critical thing. maybe a seminar or workshop providing with an overall image can help. give people brief ideas about what can be done or not~

interesting idea. Do you think it would work to have these seminar ideas included in the site. It would be simpler if everything was on one platform as it includes people from all countries instead of making them travel. I'd prefer to have everything in one place which I can access at any time of day/night but maybe others would prefer physical interaction.

Very nice Louise! I like the fact that you also thought of how to do a pilot. It could also provide access to legal help for start ups that want to expand to different countries. You could also imagine that start up founders which have used the services could pay back by mentoring new start ups.
Fab ideas! Thanks A-L
Fab stuff Louise. Would be great for folks to discuss here how large companies, lawyers, VCs & angel investors would be motivated/incentivised to be part of this.

Good point - to start it off there is simply the fact that there will be people out there who want to do 'good', people who want to do something outside of their day jobs and then  companies who allowe employees time within their working day to help.A lawyer friend of mine said her company pride themselves in their pro-bono offering  apparently laywers in the company fight for the work to do in their own time because it gives the company a great profile and helps them stand out against their competition!
I love the logo on this.

connect_the_right_people.creator: 99d4e9d49b2faba34b1257e95d0ad115

comments.text: I can see some sort of automation. Where people could enter what they want to find, and what they offer. Then be linked up immediately to complimentary networks within the network. And be notified about incoming opportunities. e.g. I have neither an idea for a start up or money to invest but I can offer the writing and presenting skills to generate interest or do pre-sales of a concept. I prefer to work with start-ups because that's where the fun is at. I am also particularly interested in Agriculture, Bio-tech, Nano-manufacturing and human augmentation. I put all that into the system and it connects me with people who have startup ideas in these areas and investors with interests in these areas. Whammo! Instant team....maybe.

I agree that the system should immediately match up interests and offers. I doubt that potential users would take the time and seek through hundreds of entrepreneurs or offers in order to find the right fit. The easier to use the higher the success or match rate.

Skill Share sounds like a great option for Entrepreneurs to really get their idea out there and have potential interests from investors.  I agree with Meena, I am looking foreword to seeing this idea in the concepting phase!

Intriguing thoughts, Melanie. We're looking forward to hearing more on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on OpenIDEO.

comments.text: What a greta inspiration Juan! I'm just curious: what happens when these businesses are started? who takes over? I'm wondering how they are turned into sustainable businesses in the mid-term?

They make sure they select teams of truly committed and passionate people, it is not easy to get selected. This is definitively the main way to assure sustainability. Other liabilities may work too but they wont result on the same quality of output.(There is not equity exchange, so you dont risk your business joining.)
It would be great to take their model and leverage it out, adjust to different environments - a truly great initiative that should be getting more international media coverage!
Great to see you back, Juan!
Hi Meena, I love this topic! :) Btw, changed jobs..., I moved to Commercial Innovation for Ericsson :)
What a great program! I wish there was more governments seeing the opportunity and real leverage for the growth of their economy.
You know, every time I read their news I get overexcited. Timing is important...

campaign_for_startups.creator: 97fa522f342b5fface534b5c73e1a544

comments.text: Hey guys, when reading this concept I was struck by the comments under "what type of resources will you need" and the discussion below. It brought to mind a curated art exhibition. What if this was created in that form, with the curators choosing the "artists" (start-ups) to exhibit, filming them, and putting together a narrative around the stories they're telling? Maybe documentary filmmaking students would be interested in it as a project, and one could be filmed for a variety of different European cities. Start-ups would have been selected because they tell an interesting piece of an overall story - and the exhibition can travel across Europe, maybe showing at the various film festivals throughout the summer. Just food for thought and a slight twist to consider!

Exciting thoughts, Team S.O.Y. Would be great for you & others to think about how entrepreneurs might be incentivsed to take part  given many of them are very busy and have to prioritise their time. Looking forward to seeing collaborative conversations here!

Good point Meena. If the campaign (as I understand) is about sharing stories about web entrepreneurs who might not be famous, but still successful to encourage people to even start considering being an entrepreneur, we could maybe have a small team who would be in charge of recording these stories. I thought of the Storytelling America: http://www.storytellingamerica.com/I saw one of their stories in an exhibition and it has been mentioned in other challenges as well. Maybe this is a campaign that could be sponsored by the EU or one of their agencies. It could be driven by some multi-media schools or university programs in various European countries (so it will also get students exposed to these stories).It should not take more than 5 minutes for the people to tell their stories. You could even imagine a storytellingEurope that will get jumpstarted with this project. A second entrepreneurial spin up could be to develop the platform (the components are all somewhat available I believe) that would facilitate this story telling project.just a few thoughts inspired by your questions Meena! :-)

Another round of thoughts more specifically related to your question Meena on motivating people to participate:I think the main motivation should be the possibility to have one's story shared on a public platform. You could imagine that some of the best stories could be showcast on some of the EU websites (related to creating businesses).
great points, we will update
Way to go on the iterative goodness!

agreed! Nice to see the update. I'm still unsure about the relationship to the campaign, the website and the contest. Is the website a support to the campaign, or are you seeing as a long-term project and the campaign would be more of a quick-off? In that case, the contest is "the campaign"?As for the contest, I'm wondering if your aim is to raise awareness and creating a sense of possibility, if you should not focus the stories on the experience and the motivations rather than then product or service as you seem to do now. Just a thought... I still feel that this concept could be 2 concepts... both interesting...
good idea. how is it responsive to grass root organizations that have limited connectivity and content generation/management that look into citizens business values and concerns.

Interesting idea. While you seem to highlight the mentoring potential through the networking and the sharing of stories (and probably best practices and tips), I think such a website could also inspire people that don't necessarily see themselves as entrepreneurs (by providing stories of various types of entrepreneurs).Could you clarify how you are envisioning the contest - its structure, audience and (potential) impact? thanks

magic_markets.creator: 95cd9b6a07cc5d5429d9aa9e28142a0a

comments.text: Interesting idea. I'm imagining an investment wiki that maps out an entire industry. I think this is also known as a VC's brain - they tend to understand their industries really well, with good insight into where the holes/opportunities are in the market.

Thanks Reba! Yeah I am hoping that more people can get insight into these topics & that it will result in better (but also profitable) technology that we can all enjoy. Honestly, this industry is so dynamic and new - I think there are very few people, even VCs, that have a complete grasp on it. That is why so many of them have lost money & don't want to invest in these types of ventures....Just goes back to the principle, that finding a market is more important than finding funding....

Some of the greatest ideas come from the humblest of backgrounds.  Keeping things user friendly is always a plus.  I love all of the websites you have mad readily available.  The gathering of minds and resources is beautiful.  Keep up the good work!
Thanks so much Nova. I spend a lot of my free time searching the web for resources for Entrepreneurs. I am pretty passionate about it.
Great Idea. I once had planned to look for a student working on this subject for his PhD, but it never happened. So I am interested to see how it will proceed.

Mmm, thanks Christian. Funny, I have actually considered getting a PhD in this area some day. This has been my side project for the course of my MBA (which I just finished last week.) I did a lot of related projects over the last year to supplement my research. Now all I need to do (now that I have time!) is finish learning the technical skills needed to implement this....
I love this idea!
Awe, thanks Natalia - I am working on Version 1.0 right now. Hopefully I will be able to get something up & running by the summer. :-)
Great idea Aimee will hope to see the fruits of your efforts in the next few months.Good luck!
Good luck! Aimee. I'd love to learn more about it when yo get it ready.
this looks good
Thanks Vikas. :-)
This is a great idea.  All the links make this much easier to follow and understand.  I definitely think there is promise with this concept!
Awe, thanks Ann - I have been trying to put together a page with links for awhile. I'll post it on my profile once I'm done....
Yay for the amazing and oh so brilliant Aimee! Did my applaud go through?
Thanks for the Applause Brandi. BTW - Hubspot might some day be a good platform for you. And, of course, you know how I feel about the Right Brain Business Plan.
Oh my first three mind maps - with the white backgrounds above. Very important and useful too. I will send you bigger copies.
This seems like a really good idea. Your graphics help me understand the start-up process. Great submission! Very creative!

Thanks Lindsey - there are a lot of moving pieces when it comes to internet start-ups - so I have been creating illustrations - over the last year of so - to try to better organize and communicate what is happening. Glad they gave you some insight. I have a lot of them and have been culling through my hard drive and uploading them as I find ones relevant to this challenge. :-)

Hi Aimee, great work. I like the back ground info with all the links. You are idea is definitely worth pursuing. For Step 1 and 2 (How we could get started?), I had  developed something similar called the trendpool gathering all the information across different industries. But, it was a closed platform, with access only for fortune 500 companies. I just imagine how powerful an open platform could be to support your idea.
Trendpool sounds super interesting. What kind of research did it have?
Yeah - great links thanks Aimee! All the crowd sourcing links are really great. Always wondered about that....

Thanks Melanie. I didn't discover crowd sourcing until this year and I ended up doing a huge project on it for my Commercialization Analytics class. It is a really interesting business model. Also, crowd funding is a pretty amazing way to fund a new venture. Plus, there is going to be legislation in the US, within the year, that allows this type of platform to raise small amounts of equity investment from many people across the nation. Obviously this model will be difficult to administer at first, but over time - this could completely change the way companies are funded!
