you_have_5_minutes_to_find_the_perfect_t.creator: 8e84dcee4c3a16638492d06cd11ca88f

comments.text: great point Louise... it seems to always (very often) ends up to people, interactions and communication! :-)One of my students is doing a business plan competition at NYU and at the beginning of the competition, there is an event where people who have ideas present them and ask for help, trying to form a team... It reminded me of Daniel's inspiration on design london http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/helping-build-killer-teams-design-london/and his point on the importance on offering the opportunity to create multidisciplinary teams.I will argue that even though finding the right skills matter, it is also about "personality fit" and process.

Anne-Laure, yes the right team dynamic is crucial.  I stumbled on an HBR article which examined communication patterns..."It seems almost absurd that how we communicate could be so much more important to success than what we communicate...In fact, weve found patterns of communication to be the most important predictor of a teams success. Not only that, but they are as significant as all the other factorsindividual intelligence, personality, skill, and the substance of discussionscombined."That's right. *Combined*!  Interesting, huh?  Full article can be found here...http://hbr.org/2012/04/the-new-science-of-building-great-teams/ar/1Now we just need a concept that fosters successful communication patterns :)
nice inspiration, people need to find the right team~hope to see the concept soon

It can be a great event for founders to find partners if it's able to address the issue of copycats. Even though competition is healthy for the industry, imagine what rocket-internet.de will be able to do after such a session.

are_europeans_risk_averse.description: On average,  EU citizens are less inclined to become entrepreneurs and more risk averse than their American counterparts- from an excert of teh European Commission on Enterpreneurship. The fear of bankruptcy is a key obstacle to entrepreneurship.
are_europeans_risk_averse.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: I think there's an intrinsic link between risk taking and exploring new territory and that start-ups should be supported in taking these risks (within reason).

Super insightful. I wonder if fear of failure might relate to differences in bankruptcy law between European countries and U.S.??? Or just differences in knowledge of bankruptcy and how it works for corporations vs. individuals?

Krassimira, this is a great point! So much of what fuels entrepreneurship is a culture that's open to the potential for failure. In the Silicon Valley, it's not unusual for a stranger to discuss their recently failed startup the first time you meet. No one looks down on it - in fact, it's a sign of initiative. How can that type of culture be fostered in Europe?

are_europeans_risk_averse.title: Are Europeans risk averse?

Terrific post, Shana! Thank you for sharing your start-up experience. I think our current economic state in the U.S. is creating a surge of young entreprenuers. If we can't find work, we'll make work. It's really a prime opportunity to find a way of doing what you love to do by working for yourself on projects you're passionate about. I'm looking forward to your insightful comments and contributions to this OpenIDEO challenge! All the best!
Thank you Andreanna.  You are welcome and I agree that the economy has contributed to many new entrepreneurs.  OpenIDEO is one of the many markets that are aware of this too.

Great personal insights here, Shana! Regarding Arjan's comment below about varying requirements in Europe  I was shocked when I worked for an advertising firm here in New Zealand that did a lot of wine branding for export, how much the label requirements differed throughout the EU. Great to bring up the challenges around regulations in your inspiration  and to note that you've overcome them!
Thank you very much Meena.  It was a long process and each day is a new learning experience but they are good ones.  Interesting fact about label requirements, one would never think it would matter.

Great personal story, Shana. And a good illustration of the journey of starting up. There are so many things you need to be aware of! In Europe there are different regulations in each country, which seems very much like the situation in the US, even though to us Europeans it looks like a true single market from afar :).Thanks for sharing!
Agree with Arjan, this is a great personal story you shared with us, Shana!

Arjan and Krassimira, thank you very much.  There is so much more behind the scenes tools that are involved in a startup that you don't realize until you begin the process.  As Arjan said, even though I am in US and dealt with their regulations, my story may help those in Europe and elsewhere because there are regulations everywhere.

make_it_work_by_being_basic.creator: 97fa522f342b5fface534b5c73e1a544

comments.text: Team SOY, I like the way you have thought about helping on different levels and about allowing countries exchanges to work. How about thinking of spaces other than dedicated creative spaces (art departments) to get involved? It might be interesting to see what untapped resources could be used - I know in the UK councils are looking at different ways to use public libraries to help keep them open.
Using libraries is very interesting, and cheaper with all the infrastructure placed. I will update. thanks

Great to see the update Team S.O.Y. I agree with Louise that it universities might not be the only place to think of having these spaces, in particular if you think of the stratospheres. You want a public space (such as public libraries or other spaces depending on the countries) where people will feel comfortable entering, and where they will go for other purposes (at least at first). You could also imagine that one way to create traffic to the stratosphere could be through events... I read about a space in NY, The General Assembly. It is an incubator but with different layers of involvements: http://generalassemb.ly/You might want to check this out...

Great input Louise and AL - I know NY Poly and other student chapters are springing up that make the Uni's a natural fit for this but there is an opportunity to combine this concept with the establishment of Local OpenIDEO Chapters ( http://www.openideo.com/open/impact/concepting/local-openideo-chapters/ ) in general.

Great idea Paul. In fact, the founders of the OpenIDEO student chapters are graduating (one in May, the other in December) and we've been discussing on how they could keep being involved... maybe by creating an OpenIDEO local chapter?

I think it can only be a good thing - and worth trying. The realisation of Local Chapters is something open to the community (as compared to some of the other winning concepts from that challenge). Anjelika envisaged the Local Chapters as places to further the OpenIDEO mission - I took that to mean broadly they would become extensions of the OpenIDEO community participating in both OpenIDEO and locally generated challenges. Embracing this concept would give the Local Chapters a link to the broader creative community.This also accords with the sentiments expressed in your OpenBasket concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/impact/concepting/openbasket-what-works-for-us-might-work-for-you/ ) too!
I like that playing with prototypes is part of this plan. The public needs something to latch on to, and everybody loves being on the ground floor or a new app, etc.
very true, thanks

I agree that using part of the space as a way to get quick feedback is an interesting idea. It could also be an opportunity to try out an app or website that worked well in a country and see how it will be perceived in another, and what changes might be needed.
I think this is an interesting concept guys.Where does the intellectual property reside and the merchantable product?
Great questions Paul!

I like the idea of using the space to encourage the idea process and the sharing of ideas I also like that there is a focus to the space in the center and that space is also where one idea is focused upon
and that makes it easier to relocate and move around based on the entrepreneurs needs.

make_it_work_by_being_basic.title: Fostering Innovation Through the Recreation of Workspace

volunteering_for_start_ups_portal.description: Allow people to find one-off or longer term ways to volunteer their skills with start-ups.
volunteering_for_start_ups_portal.creator: 7771fbb20af6ef10827c593daa3aff7b

comments.text: This is a great idea. It would be important to build as much recognition and currency for the volunteers' actions as possible. For example, an app that displays the volunteers' portfolio of successfully completed tasks on Linkedin. Another idea would be to make it compulsory for the start ups to have a section in 'about us' on the start up's website that lists the volunteers, with their Linkedin profiles.It would also help if the volunteers' assistance was broken down into discrete tasks connected to time units: a weekend, one day for a month, an evening a week etc. This would make it more attractive to volunteers maybe? And also show publicly just how much of their precious time they had given up.One last thought- what if you had volunteered for Instagram? Is there any way the terms of accepting volunteers could include some kind of reward or at the very least major recognition in the event of an IPO or trade sale? Tricky one....

Again, awesome concept.   Something like this would find more users than expected.  This Site would offer the ability for professionals transitioning between careers to build their resumes.  You could call it Bridging the Gap or Venture Transitions!One difficulty with ideas like this is how to ensure that the work a startup contracts someone to do is done to a satisfactory level and in a timely manner.  Perhaps there is need for an intermediary that makes sure projects are done correctly.  If a user that agrees to fulfill a job fails, they could have a rating that goes down and likewise a rating that could go up with a job well done.  In this way, individuals who complete projects satisfactorily will stay in the game.
Nice one London OpenSTORMERS! You might also want to join in the conversation here: http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/talent-swap/

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
"The Raspberry Pi is a cheap computer DESIGNED so kids can use to learn programming" !

That's right. It runs Linux, and high level programming languages such as Python, which makes it an ideal platform for learning web development.It's about putting the right tools into the hands of kids - and not just Windows machines running Excel and Word.

Hi Daniel,100% agree with "It's about putting the right tools into the hands of kids"Raspberry Pi is based on work in MIT Media LAB, they demonstrate then, playing is most exective when you can physicaly interact with thinks. Base idea is learning cycles of "Software Programing, Software Testing, Hardware developing and integration, Hardware debugging". In MIT Media LAB they define how such platfom for learing basics Roboticks and Automation must look. LEGO participated in this program and build LEGO stuff like Mindstorms on it and Microsoft makes it's Robotics Studio as follow up of this principles.See links in Technical Kinderganden Inspiration.I hope Raspberry Pi will be in future much chaper community driven alternative (with extension boards) to compercial Robotics and Automations kits enabling kids to learn interdisciplinary basics of SW & HW. Beause just programing can be learend on cheap tablet, phone + lager PC as most of us learned (Do you remeber this nice 8 bit boxes ?).o So you can see Raspberry Pi as more advanced wooden train assembly for older kids. oPS: As for learning kids basics of programing and robotics we develop in CzechoSlovac Republic "Karel the Robot" and it's derivates http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karel_(programming_language)Of course in MIT Media Lab they make something similar Scratch :-)

Hi Daniel, I really like the idea of getting kids to fail earlier and 'learn by doing'.With regards to coding your inspiration reminds me of Codecademy, have you heard of it? http://www.codecademy.com/ Maybe it's a platform that these kids could learn coding through.
Hi Ana. Yes, I really like the look of that site! Really cool.
Ana  hopefully you might add Code Academy as it's own inspiration post?
Hi Meena, yes I could do that! I will do it today when I get the time, thanks :)
Great provocation! If folks want to check out the link, it's http://www.raspberrypi.org/ Daniel  you could add that directly to your post via the Update button.
Great addition to this phase. Teaching the skills at an early stage is important. Coding, but also entrepreneurial skills.

True. And when they learn to hack/play in digital realm, they have the mental skills also to start hacking/playing with real local ecosystem.Aren't entrepreneurial skills seeing potential and digging for opportunities (like in coding)? Analogy mapping...

This book has some nice examples of encouraging entrepreneurship at a young age. The author is a lecturer, and she gives her students $5 and challenges them to make as much money as possible! http://www.amazon.co.uk/What-Wish-Knew-When-Was/dp/0061735191

I like this idea. Thinking back to why I started coding as a kid it had everything to do with access to the raw material to solve problems. That meant computers that didn't do everything for you (mostly because at the time they couldn't) and required some imagine and motivation.
Do you know the arduino project? It is a open hardware part of the make movement. And it was created by Prof Massimo Basso, an European!
The Arduino is really cool. But the Raspberry Pi is British, so even better :)
Great inspiration. It's all about accessibility and like Arjan said, teaching the skills at an early age!

create_panic.description: Use human behavior to make them think they must have your product or service.  People want what they can't have.  Use psychology to gain lift.
create_panic.creator: eb28ee0d97e95dc891db0f4fbe3554e2

comments.text: I kinda like the way you think. even if it is not suitable idea for improve the entepreunship is a really good strategy to sell products.

Interesting Mary. Do you think this tactic would wear a bit thin if too many people were doing it? Given our challenge question focuses on "sustainable businesses" I'm wondering whether this approach could be sustained. Perhaps someone may come up with a build on your idea which draws upon the idea of highlighting limited supply but beyond a marketing tactic?

I think at start up it absolutely can be sustained (as in used again for other businesses), but that business can't continue using it for the long term.  It's more of a kick my business off idea and then move to a sustainable business model.  That is the slow growth I mention which in it's self need much more detail.  Of course if everyone does the same thing it almost never works as it just become a commodity or just plain boring. This model is beyond just creating panic.  It's just one of many behavioral tactics that can be used that uses the human psyche to create a "want" that they believe is a "need".  Thanks for the provoking thought! I love it. :)

start_up_on_google_map_.description: Start-ups usually rent space in larger buildings. This way they are hidden and are not know. Perhaps a Google Map just for Manhattan or San Jose, sponsored by an overarching organization would bring some visibility to these innovative teams.
start_up_on_google_map_.creator: e705c665ad962d5708f0481d62ac7508

comments.text: Thanks for this, Nima. Agree that start-ups are often too hidden. Check out this map of London's Silicon Roundabout for inspiration: http://www.wired.co.uk/magazine/archive/2010/02/start/silicon-roundaboutIt would be great to think about what European cities would benefit from this; for instance Berlin or Paris. Perhaps some community members could chip in with thoughts.
The Bazaar. It is local, it is visible and thus has a voice and respondents within the city space.

This idea is great in that it helps minimize the amount of precious money that start-ups have to devote towards advertising. In highlighting their presence in cities and urban centers where they could normally be overlooked, we increase starting businesses chances of success.

launchland_social_gaming_to_provide_seed.description: Social gaming websites are expected to gross over $6.4 B in revenue by 2014.  What if we could engage social gamers in a virtual world of entrepreneurship and direct the revenue from games to actual entrepreneurs? Enter LaunchLand...
launchland_social_gaming_to_provide_seed.creator: a92cdba051336921a88d2551ca20c9cc

comments.text: This is a great concept. One thing that I would suggest adding is the feature to reiterate your business plan/model as a part of the game as you get feedback from the members of the community. Business ideas change over time (as we know very well here at OpenIDEO) and I think it would be helpful for LaunchLand wannabe entrepreneurs to see the evolution of their business model over time as they receive feedback from other players, investors, and the market.

Great point, Brett!  We want to create many ways in which users can take advantage of feedback and advice from other entrepreneurs to advance in the game and to experience the decision making process of real entrepreneurs.  It would be cool to have a timeline feature that would allows users to look back on the choices they made and how their business model changed.  Thanks!

I'm a little late to this party but feel this idea has the potential to act as a portal for all the finalists ideas as well as help get people into action.  LauchLand will aid those definitely looking to launch their own business but will also allow curious minds to tinker with ideas that if they get traction to actually make the jump into action.  It also offers exisiting firms the opportunity to test new strategies.Sorry for the rant but love the potential if the framework can get sorted.
Awesome updates!!
Also, check out this related concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/virtual-economy-for-vapor-startups/
We took a look at Jyotirmaya's idea and its wonderful. We wanted to add him on - is there a formal way to do this? Thanks for the heads up Amy!
Great updates, guys! You can add Jyotirmaya to your Virtual Team Field.

Thanks to everyone for their support and great ideas over the last few weeks.  We made some changes to incorporate the feedback we received and flushed out the game concept a little more.Please let us know what you think!

A good idea- get it right and it could be huge. I'm not sure to what extent it would promote good business practice in the EU though- you'd need to look at multiple language options.A good starting point might be to look at some of the proprietary business simulations available like http://www.business-smart.com/products/fantasy-ceo/ and approach them with an offer to make it social, mobile and bring it to the Facebook masses.

Nice idea. What interests me here is this addresses at least three of our themes: creative funding, celebrating start-ups, and tapping untapped human potential. It is a lovely way to allow people to engage with the entrepreneurial world in a fun way, which hopefully will turn some would-be entrepreneurs into actual entrepreneurs. And, what a great feeling to see your virtual support turn into real world success.Love Tim's idea of looking at business simulations as inspiration. Maybe talk to business school professors about how this could end up being used in business school classrooms? And secondary school teachers as well. The first order of business is just to make it fun to use, then get to the rest. There is a great article in the current edition of BA's business:life (sadly not online) that talks about how social gaming attracts different types of users, particularly women. Zynga is great at this - for instance Hidden Chronicles' main audience is women aged 35-60. Given this challenge is for the EC, a great question to consider is how social gaming can actually exploit cross-border collaboration. What if it is a way for would-be entrepreneurs to meet and try working together in a safe environment?

Hi, I'd like to follow up on Amy's point regarding a simulation version to be used for teaching. It could be used in business school classrooms but it should be used in other schools as well (engineering, design, etc.). While reading your concept, I immediately thought of a version of this that could be used in a course. I personally use a couple of simulation, but in particular a great simulation on change management which was developed by one of my colleagues at INSEAD. I have been using it for the last few years in management programs but within an engineering school.I could see this game (as it is or an adapted version of it) to be used in class and then debriefed and used as a support to discuss concepts related to entrepreneurship. A great way to support experiential learning. I also remember colleagues in marketing that had a course based on a simulation. Students were in teams and had several rounds to play and they met in between with faculty members for coaching sessions. You could also envision something similar for this game: rather than one session, it could be the basis for a whole course.I'm sure that with the current interest in entrepreneurship, there will be many schools which would be interested in sponsoring the idea.  As regarding the European aspect, it depends on the main aim of the game: if it's to teach specifics about how to start a business, then laws and other regulations matter; but if it's more about developing an understanding of the main mechanisms involved in developing an idea and launching a business, I think the game can be made generic enough that it could work in most countries without modifications.al

Tim - Thanks for the simulation ideas. We reviewed what you, Amy, and Anne-Laure pointed out regarding simulation and did some research in that area.Launch Land 2.0 aims in this direction while still keeping many of the organic elements of the prior version. We really liked the idea, as Anne-Laure added, about Launch Land becoming an educational tool as well as a fun game to play. Hence, our new version is something we think may reveal the hidden entrepreneur of a gamer whose original intention was to just have fun while also providing a realistic framework an existing entrepreneur can learn in. We would love to hear what you gals/guys think about the new 2.0 version!

Nice idea! I love social gaming, and this s gonna be a very attractive platform to get practical experience! So I wanna ask more, what if the real- world market shows very different result, u know things r changing everyday, so how can keep updating and how can we build relationship between the virtual and real world? Thank u!

Very good insight and point Jiangxuan! The software inputs RSS news feeds to stay abreast of market trends/conditions and factors relevant items into the game. Then it is up to the entrepreneurs in the game to incorporate these new issues. What are your thoughts on this solution and are there any other ways you think we can add real world events? Would love to get your feedback!

As an aspiring entrepreneur, I like this idea. Certainly something I would like to use. The value added for me as an entrepreneur is the ability to get community feedback and validation/invalidation on ideas I would like to evaluate. I'm not too clear on who, besides entrepreneurs who want to get funding, this is geared to benefit; the community of users/gamers or who...

Hi Rick. Leveraging off of your input regarding community feedback and validation/invalidation of venture concepts, we refined the concept to award game participants points for engaging potential customers early on in their new venture. In our refined game, entrepreneurs get to experience the real world challenges of launching a new business. Gamers who may not be entrepreneurs but still want to play are welcome as it makes the game more lively and real. The social mobile gaming market is already very large and growing!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thank you :)
There is so much promise here by bridging the virtual and physical and building on some proven game mechanics around sharing and gifting. Get started now, it's a great idea that should be in beta.
Thanks Robert. We have been prototyping a few concepts that blend real and virtual worlds. Thanks!
great idea, this could be built on the ideas of such games made by zynga. the "villes"   This could connect people across the world very easily building more ease between countries.
Yes, connecting people across the globe to work on entrepreneurial endeavors is a top goal for us. We envision tomorrow's start-ups comprised of people all over the world.

Hey nice idea !I also had a similar idea "virtual economy for vapor startups"http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/virtual-economy-for-vapor-startups/And social gaming is an excellent platform.I think you should also think about the potential users as they are going to drive the simulated economy. Now if only the startups and beginners participate in such a social gaming, it won't give an actual simulation of economic movements. It will be great if the synthetic economy would not only engage and expose them to market condition,  but also help them with predictive simulation and help them in making informed decision.
Would love to collaborate.
We reviewed your ""virtual economy for vapor startups" and its pretty cool! We welcome your collaboration. Is there a way to formally add you on?
This is a brilliant idea -- sending my props
Thanks Burak!
Like your idea! :)
Thanks Ari. We have refined it since so we hope you like the 2.0 version!

I love the idea of turning a social happening into something for social good. Why stop people from enjoying social gaming when it can be it to good use. Have you spoken to anyone who is currently into social gaming to see what they'd think of this idea?  Would be interesting to hear their point of view!
Welcome Cornell Hacksters!Might be some learnings from the Urgent Evoke team for starters?http://blog.urgentevoke.net/2010/07/26/what-went-right-what-went-wrong-lessons-from-season-1-evoke1/
Wow, great article!  Thank you!

Thanks Louise. We have been speaking with a lot of gamers and they find the game interesting. We are hoping non-gamer entrepreneurs will find it interesting as well since they can gain simulated real world experience by playing!
Hi Meena. We checked out the Urgent Evoke concept as recommended and it is pretty cool. Thanks!
What time and time zone does refinement officially end?

The best way to calculate when the phases switch (as we're all on different time zones ;^) is by the Realisation phase counter at the top of the left column or the Evaluation phase counter at the top of the page. You can actually keep updating your concept after the phases switch  but then you run the risk of some people evaluating your post before you've added your finishing touches.

Thanks Louise. We have been speaking with a lot of gamers and they find the game interesting. We are hoping non-gamer entrepreneurs will find it interesting as well since they can gain simulated real world experience by playing!
The technology/design is easy, plenty of people/companies who can deliver. Do you have already a game mechanic smarter than farmville meets foursquare?
We are still looking at what talent we might have here at Cornell, but would welcome any suggestions/referrals.  Thanks!
has true potential to be realized....use the existing structures of social gaming am insert some social aspects...bravo
thanks for your support!

We love the simulation part of this but the advisory panel cautioned against making it an environment where companies are actually launched. Consider pivoting it to be about simulation for educational purposes, and we think it has a lot of potential.Swing by our Web Start-up Challenge Refinement Phase Announcement: http://bit.ly/startup-shortlist + the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine for more tips!

I like the idea!I had a comment below about the educational simulation aspect and this inspired me to develop a concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/definitely-a-virtual-incubatorYou might find some useful ideas or references in our concept.

Hey there Cornell Hacksters! Congrats on being shortlisted for our Refinement phase of the Web Start-up Challenge. Only 6 days left to evolve your concept. We hope you'll be chiming in and updating this exciting idea.
We are meeting up again and looking forward to refining this idea!  Thanks for your support!

Looking forward to seeing the updates guys. Thanks for putting time into iterating it! As you get together, think about how you can make it into something more like a simulation that doesn't rely on people inputting real start-up ideas into it. It will be an awesome educational tool in that regard and will simplify the concept. Also, you might consider charging a fee for using it in classrooms on a per head basis and not have it provide funding to entrepreneurs - that's a big challenge in and of itself.

This game has real potential. How do you address the problem of making sure you're supporting real and morally excellent entrepreneurs? I would love to team up on this concept to help fully fill the obvious gaps that you pointed out. My approach is very people oriented. We remove all negatives through sociological assimilation.
Thanks Ari!  We belive it's a promising concept!!
Oops...I meant 'believe.'  Sorry for the spelling error!

comments.text: Great highlight of IndieGoGo's global relevance. Tip: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link
LOL, really. Did I just do that? And did you just explain to me how this works. Hahaha. I've been away too long. Sorry.

Hey Arjan, this is a great idea. I will help with your project...saw the tweet last night! This is what friends are and this is so great you can share with this community your experience first hand!:-)
Haha, thanks, Krassimira. Yes, it's through my Book Dream project that I've found out about IndieGoGo and that as a non-US resident I could not use Kickstarter. All help is welcomed warmly :).

Oh, and indeed. It's also a great way of getting the experience of how crowd funding works. Sometimes we might think that by sending out one tweet and putting it on Facebook once, we have spammed our friends enough. But funny that you mention seeing the tweet last night. I've been tweeting and facebooking and pinning etcetera about it every day for the last almost 2 weeks. Goes to show, that you have to really put effort in such a campaign, because not everything gets noticed by everybody.

The lovely thing about crowdsourcing is it makes funding become accessible to everyone. The thought of looking for funding can be very daunting and probably makes lots of people feel put off starting up.

comments.text: Hi Jennifer, great you've joined this wonderful platform. ANd thanks for sharing your inspiration. Have you seen these two (one by me, one by Ozlem Aslan):http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/crowdfunding-kickstarter.com/andhttp://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/international-crowdfunding-with-indiegogo/It's always good to see an idea pop up several times in the inspiration phase. That emphasizes the value of it, I tend to think. Did you know that you can link inspirations together? It would be good if you do that, so that it's easy to see the connection. Here's a how-to instruction from the user forums: https://openideo.zendesk.com/entries/507304-connecting-inspirations-and-concepts-to-each-otherOh, and links do not work in the summary section of an inspiration or concept. You can put links in the description section. Here's an instruction how to do that: http://bit.ly/oi_link

Hi Arjan! No I didn't see those, I must have missed it, there are quite the number of inspirations to browse through. Thanks for the heads up. Should I take it down? I'm not sure of their policy on this.But thanks for sharing and all the useful links. It's my first time so all your help is greatly appreciated!

Nono, don't take it down. WIth large numbers of inspirations, this is bound to happen. It's more a case of 'great minds think alike' :).But... it would be great if you can connect them to your inspiration. In that way, it's more visible that this crowd funding is a good part of the inspiration and can be important.On top of that, it will give you extra DQ points :).

Here's a quick tip: we're starting to see a couple of related inspirations around crowdfunding and you might want to connect them to your post using the Build Upon feature. This helps us all join the dots between related posts and will show up on your Collaboration Map for this post. Plus, as Arjan mentioned, you'll get more DQ points!. Hit the Update button on the right of your post, then scroll down to Build Upon. Search terms like 'crowdfunding and crowd funding' and drag anything relevant over to your Build Upon field. Keep up the great work!

startup_labs_2013_22_days_5_teams_and_50.description: Coming from Startup Weekend, Startup Labs is a 3 week program providing seed capital, mentorship, and technical support to validate your startup.
startup_labs_2013_22_days_5_teams_and_50.creator: 6e75a6fc07caaa04191c4cbe89e9433c

comments.text: This is great. Especially their focus on up and coming international markets. And I guess 8% equity is not bad, if more connections to VC's and network rolls out of this. Great post!

Thank you for the comment Nima! Startup Labs' focus on emerging markets is definitely one of its features. Its a really new program and I hope in the future we will hear more stories of Startup Labs utilizing its global network to accelerate local startups.

It's been interesting to note the number of inspiration posts which include some kind of time-constraint as a form of motivation. We're interested to see how this notion might manifest itself in fresh and bold thinking in our upcoming Conceptting phase  starting this week!

Very interesting indeed Meena. Time constraint or the power of the deadline? It will also be interesting to see what comes out of these events: how many people follow up on the ideas and move to realization? It might be important to have a process there too. It reminds me of one of Louise's inspirations on how to create spaces where people can take their start-ups to be nurtured: http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/get-help-with-your-own-project-instead-of-giving-it-to-someone-else./Maybe there is also a need to think in terms of process or phases...

I'd say that time constraint and the power of a deadline go hand in hand (just like resource constraint & power of hunger might)  and indeed, we're excited about the processes which might arise from these inspirations.

It's great to see these discussions. I would say that time constraint/the power of deadline is essential to both entrepreneurs and investors. Time constraints not only motivate entrepreneurs, but also help them decide a cut off point. Investors also wish to see certain progress in limited time period; this helps them determine whether or not the startup is worth investing, and also helps them examine the entrepreneur's ability to cope with stress.

comments.text: I really like the idea of big companies supporting start-ups and I wonder how the reverse can also come into play: how can big companies learn to act like more start ups? Some big companies have a lot to learn about being nimble, fast-moving and innovative -- the forte of many start-ups. How could the EC create/facilitate a mutual relationship between the two where big companies support start-ups and start-ups in exchange show them the ropes on putting these skills into practice?

Like any endeavor in: innovation, urban development, entrepreneurship...the Vision and Means to steer the objective - it is a good start...work in progress...INCs and startups are driven for profit. the dilemma is over value and productivity that sets a culture within
this is by far my favorite, since a culture of innovation is encouraged within the Corporation hierarchies. What a great challenge to set a trend reversely.

Any platform or tool that help corporations to engage better with small, innovative, business, are very well appreciated by the corporations themselves. However, the "openness" of the process is always tricky for them, most of them have dificulties in being open, and make their requirements and ideas for development. They are afraid of showing their weaknessess or too much of their development plans. Thus, I think that the grat challenge of your concept is to keep open, but in a way that makes corporations at ease.

Very good point, Irene. What engaged the advisory committee on this one was the following: How do we help companies open up their resources to start-ups in a helpful way? So, not only do they need to be comfortable with openness, they need to have a real understanding of what start-ups need (e.g., space, access to supply chain partners, etc) and what they don't need (e.g., strategic consulting when they're all hands on deck trying to get a beta product ready). As inspiration, Startup America (http://www.s.co/) seems to be doing a nice job of this. Maybe we could start a dialogue here: what are the things that start-ups really want from big companies? Startup America's framework of four stages is a nice place to begin (http://www.s.co/resources). What do companies need in the "idea," "startup," "rampup," and "speedup" stages?

Good point, the strategic consulting issue... Most companies base their incubation support in "coaching" schemes that, you're right, might be useful at some stage of evolution, but not always, and it's not the primary concern... They grab a techie and try to create a MBA techie... In companies with 2-3... 5? people (that is, with very few possibilities to divide roles)OK, so... What do companies need in the "idea," "startup," "rampup," and "speedup" stages? A quick guess: IDEA: please help me prototype, get someone to believe in me and be my first client, that firts cliente I need to get the second... STARTUP: show me to the world (partners, investors, potential clients). RAMPUP: I don't want to die of success, I wanna grow smoothly and tranform my way of doing (maybe at this stage they do need that couching and strategic consulting...). SPEEDUP: what do you want to do with me? Invest? Buy my concept an integrate it within the company? Let me follow my own path. Let's decide, let's (win-win) negotiate.Just brainstorming... Anyway, I think there's issues that are constant; I mean, companies always will value that corporations provide business leads and access to supply chain. It's just that the way that should be done varies a lot from one stage to another...

Irene, agree, In our experience in developing i4exchange.com platform, large companies have actually been quite closed to letting outsiders attempt to solve their problems or provide innovative input. Most of the initiatives we have seen are thinly veiled marketing pitches for the large company.  Also they fear dealing with independents that have a distorted view of the value of unproven ideas and concepts they submit. We are attempting to create a level playing field that protects the larger firms privacy needs while providing adequate compensation for the contributed IP.

Thanks both. Irene, I like your set of needs at different stages. I'd also add: IDEA: help me find people who can help me get it off the ground (e.g., developers, biz brains, UX experts, etc)STARTUP: help me get more funding / additional team members to helpRAMPUP: this is actually a huge need after companies get Kickstarter funding - being able to deliver on what they promised and not getting in too deep (particularly if kickstarter has been way more successful than expected). SPEEDUP: help expanding to new geographies

We find this intriguing  and would love to see how it could be flipped on its head a bit to encourage companies to support start-ups, ala Start-up America. What would a successful version of Start-up America look like in Europe? Swing by our Web Start-up Challenge Refinement Phase Announcement: http://bit.ly/startup-shortlist + the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine for more tips!

comments.text: interesting to see that they decided to pivot, develop and relaunch.  I bet that is a common story for most start ups if they are honest....
I think so too, But most see it as failure and won't admit it.

Thanks Ohood for this interview. Apart from funding, I noted two interesting points:the importance of the existing network and relationships in the field (which provides an understanding of the need and support) and the prototyping approach (" Lots of free capacity to allow us to develop and test without capital expense" + the decision to evolved and redesign the interface.Thanks!alPS: you might want to link it to the interview guide inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/the-interview-kit-learning-from-entrepreneurs/. It'll be nice to see how many interviews were generated using the interview guide :-)On prototyping, see my inspirations:http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/amazon.com-a-story-of-prototyping/http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/prototyping-a-shorthand-of-entrepreneurship/

Great stuff Ohood. Might also be handy for you to explain that you used the Interview Kit plus provide a link, here on your post so that others are encouraged to use it too. You can update your post by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right.

comments.text: Hi Nadine!  I'm working on a similar concept for the educational challenge (crazy and awesome that we both came up with similar ideas... there's something to this).  Any ideas on how we could combine your thoughts on this concept toward educating young people?  http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/sim-startup/

Great idea! I had a similar wish that Monopoly or Tiny Tower have a start-up version...

This is really cool! Sim City was one of the coolest games to play back in the old days. This could be marketed to schools everywhere. Children could come up with ideas and then build them through different steps. Talk about critical thinking being implemented at a young age! GREAT, GREAT IDEA!

comments.text: Do I have to post again in the concepting phase to be considered for applause and short listing? Or would the "this inspiration" be enough?

You would have to post as a concept to be considered for our Refinement shortlist, Sidi. You might also like to check out concepts like http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/virtual-economy-for-vapor-startups/http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/launchland-social-gaming-to-provide-seed-funding-and-engage-entrepreneurs/ to join in conversations and think about your point of difference.

His father was illiterate yet he taught him a secret that made him many many millions. 1. Work for your self 2. Invest 50% of what you make. 3. Persist. This man now owns more than 1000 rental properties and he pays Canadian universities to teach his approach.  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oxenZXPfN68
Everything about about this market trading game is realistic, up until transferring money to your bank account. http://www.wallstreetsurvivor.com/
Hi Sidi, I like this idea a lot. One platform I could think of for inspiration is Second Life, where there is substantial interaction and virtual economic activity as well!
Hi bassem .. Have not played SL as of yet .. Curios to see how  realistic are business plans in second life, if any and wether or not  we can plugin real market live data in the game?

I enjoy the farmville analogy. The first screen of the game would already help me a lot; to see what potentially can grow into something beautiful. Later indeed to speed up the process by having some 'angels' flying in with money or 'moles' popping up to keep you sharp/focussed. Hope you will pursue a cool concept.
Great approach I thing ...

Hi Sidi,The idea sounds good. Since farmville has more than 80 million users managing virtual farm, harvesting trees and bushes, or raising livestock, it would be much better to create a game that encourages entrepreneurship, and motivate people to create startups.

Hi Sidi, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. toolbelt_everything_you_need_always_at_h.description: ToolBelt is an application that helps keep everything you need easily available in ONE place. The foundation for building something great starts with an idea and the right tools to make it happen.
toolbelt_everything_you_need_always_at_h.creator: 529fb7905ba543afd5128954781758fd

comments.text: Great idea Andreanna!How do you see the range of tools growing - through designer choice, user choice or collective accumulation?To avoid clutter would you see a system of user preferences from the tools on offer?

Thanks, Paul! Great question. I think you're as every bit the designer of this app as I am. How would you prefer the range of tools to grow? I'm partial to the user maintaing control, but a "suggested-tools" notification or pop-up could be fun. :) Can you expand on your last question?

Hi Andreanna Just to explain my thinking a bit - the list you madeAboutBrandingBudget       etc.I saw as categories of tools that might fit with Ashley's Founders Roadmap and Louise's Project Angel while the tools themselves (that is the links to them) would form the content of the categories as you have demonstrated.Am I right in thinking that the Toolbelt comes with a set of categories to suit the average user or follow the roadmap but the content is empty until chosen by the user, based on the tools they have access to.or would there be an ever growing master list?As to my last previous question i guess I was thinking that if users have several tools in each category they might have an order of preference for using them. For example I have a Facebook account but because I am uncomfortable with the use of my information I rarely use it.

Yes, I think there will be a default set of tools that are necessary for building a business and maintaining strong relationships. The user can go beyond the default tools and add on other useful tools that aid in their particular needs. Maybe there could even be a way to see ToolBelts that belong to our friends and collaborators, and then share tools with one another, similar to how we would work together and learn from each other in our tangible off-line world. (The plus side being that we don't actually risk loosing our tools when sharing them. lol!)I'd like to see an aspect of mentorship be incorporated, perhaps via chat and/or roadmap comparison, etc. I could see this as an data-comparison chart via friends/success-models/etc.I think Facebook and social media are very powerful tools for business right now. If your "Social Media" tool on ToolBelt is not synced with an active account, then it doesn't have any priority. If someone has multiple social media accounts that they are actively using, then all the accounts would be accessible through the ToolBelt "Social Media" tool. It's like having access to everything you need in one place WITH the flexibility to scale and adapt as needed.It's quite literally like having a construction tool belt, or gathering ingredients before preparing a dish in the kitchen...as designers and entrepreneurs, we need a place to grasp and organize all the facets of building a business that we juggle with every day, because the tools are broad and diverse and we need a way to reign 'em in to handle things efficiently and effectively. :)

Thanks for the further explanation Andreanna I'm getting a better picture of your thinking. I just wish I had the skills to start prototyping these and the related concepts because, as with some of the concepts in the Social Impact challenge I think they are worth developing regardless of this challenge outcome.

Beautiful renderings and presentation here! If I may play devil's advocate a moment, however... how do you envision the Tool Belt helping a user utilize apps more efficiently than the hardware's existing operating system? For example, tablets and phones running Android or Apple platforms allow me to organize my favorite apps on multiple desktops quite effectively already, so in what ways does the Tool Belt go beyond what's out there to give the user easier access to their necessities? That said, I think this is an excellent idea with a lot of potential - especially on the social/collaborative side (if an entrepreneur is working with a small team, for example).

Thanks, Mike!I don't know that the ToolBelt goes beyond what's out there, but rather I think it distills and simplifies what is out there to give the user easier access to their necessities in a fun, scalable and organized way.If you have any ideas about ways to take it "beyond what's out there" I'd love to hear them; this is as much your design as it is mine. It's nice to have this collaborative space online to brainstorm. :)All the best!
This looks like a great idea for consolidating all of the programs that a growing business would need to use.
Thank you, Logan, that is what I had hoped this concept would convey. Thanks for commenting.Take care.

Hi Andreanna, I had a question about implementing this idea; how would you make this toolbelt legally and financially feasible to bundle all of these apps into a package? ie. microsoft excel is expensive on its own would the cost of this app cover the full cost of this program?

Hi Tyler,I envision the ToolBelt application accessing the independant apps and software, not necessarily bundling them into the app. Just like a real tool belt provides easy access to tangible construction tools, this app with provide "all-in-one-place" access to infinite tools: software programs, apps, chat streams, media, files, etc. You'll be able to sync software and mark/label files to be stored/accessible via ToolBelt. The hope is improve on organization, accessibility, consolidation and integration of the various tools we use in building and promoting our business. Hope that clarifies this idea. Any refinements, suggestions, critiques are welcome. Thanks for commenting. Best!

Hi Adreanna, I like the idea of the single platform where tools can be found and added. The visualizations are very nice too. I have  a clarification question: are you envisioning a standard tool belt (that could for example follow the founder's roadmap and could also be set up based on the European country the start up is based in) and then each entrepreneur can customize it, by adding other tools along the way? thanks!
sorry forgot to add the link to the founder roadmap concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/the-founder-s-roadmap/

Thank you for your comment, Anne-Laure. I hope this answers your question:I envision ToolBelt open-ended and scalable to meet new needs/opportunities as they arise. In short, yes, I think if you envision a need for it to follow the founder's roadmap there will be a tool on the belt that is capable of doing that. If you would like content/qualities to be geared toward European business standards, then yes, I envision ToolBelt having either a tool or initial set-up options that are capable of meeting that need.Thank you for contributing! Your ideas, Anne-Laure, enrich the concept! All the best!
Thanks Adreanna for the clarification. I like the idea of flexibility and customizability to the needs with the possibility of having standard settings to start.
Andreanna, you must have been reading my mind.  The thought of having all your social media and the tools you need to keep them going in one place is PRICELESS!!
Thanks, Shana! Please feel free to expand on tools/functions you would like to see on ToolBelt. :)

You're welcome.  So far from the images, I can't think of anything that needs to be added.  Just being able click on the media you want to update is the best.  Would it be possible to allow users to create new apps/icons right from the screen they are on (similar to adding a page to Homescreen on iPhone/iPad)?
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thanks for featuring it! :)

I love the idea, the expandability, and how it provides any level of user a familiar way to interact with their "Business World"Skype has recently opened up an API and a lot of other services will too, so focusing on the platform makes a lot of sense. This also allows you to share information amongst the community with high degrees of relevance.
Thanks, om design. Your post is a terrific contribution!
Great job Andreanna!  Wonderfully made :)
Thank you, Daniella!
Lovely concept. How about adding Founders Dictionary to your tool belt? http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/founders-dictionary/
Thank you, Louise. I think adding the Founders Dictionary as a tool is a terrific idea!

Nice one, Adreanna  and nice work on the visualisations! Glad to see you've considered topics like tax advice. Given it's an app, I assumer they would be some way for folks to load what country they're from to bring up relevant details around topics like this. Looking forward to onwards discussion and builds here!

Thank you, Meena. Great point about country status. I'd like to see State status as well, with online filing and deadline reminders for State and Federal form applications that are relevant for the type of business: Corporation, LLC, 501(c)3, etc.
Nice build.

comments.text: Great! Time constraints certainly seem to motivate creativity  as we're seeing on posts like this too: http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/startupbus-a-roadtrip-with-a-difference-/

Really great! Time constraints are essential for a creative workshop output. In a short time the brains are forced to spin around producing ideas. If the outcome is a working prototype that visualizes the functions, it is a huge benefit for all further steps.So maybe there is a need of innovation and prototyping workshops where designers and developers meet startup teams.Web startups should be enabled to quickly generate protoypes. This is much more effective than long theoretic explainations.

enterpreneur_loan.description: entrepreneur-loans is the idea of re-appropriating the existing student loan infrastructure for start-ups - to make it easier for them to get to capital especially in the tough beginning years.
enterpreneur_loan.creator: 116fee19f83200c3abeba614c26191e9

comments.text: Hi Stefan, Way to go evolving this concept and posting it to our Youth Employability challenge!http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/diy-entrepreneur-loans-for-young-people/
Congratulations on sharing a winning concept! The EC loved the thought of providing alternative means of bootstrapping young companies.

Once again congratulations Stefan - you have a very insightful mind for transitional ideas. Will be very interested to see what develops from this and the other winning concepts despite my being physically remote from the centre of action. Look forward to your thoughts on the next few challenges too.

We like the idea of encouraging entrepreneurship as a valid means of education, but we would like to hear ideas on how to minimise debt. Perhaps you can only take out this loan if you don't have a student loan already? We'd also like to hear about how entrepreneurs who try this versus university can be supported if their start-up fails. Perhaps people who have started companies through this loan can receive credits at university, to encourage them to continue their education once the start-up has run its course.Swing by our Web Start-up Challenge Refinement Phase Announcement: http://bit.ly/startup-shortlist + the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine for more tips!

Obviously no loan is risk free for the lender. Student loans here in Australia are government sponsored and tied to future income levels (from any source) and provided in stages dependent on progress.I imagine similar 'conditions' could be established for entrepreneur loans (at least for loans partially or wholly originating in government).Here the recovery starts at a particular income level and is facilitated through the income tax system. Perhaps a tax-linked guarantee system as part of any public/private partnership for making loans would be worth considering.As for Uni credits - this would be a great idea for 'liberal arts' type degrees (I wish Australia had such an undergraduate system at least I would have a degree by now instead of 3 partially completed ones).

Good point, Paul. It would be nice to minimise risk on both sides. We don't want to help people to a point where they're buried in debt! Perhaps the loans are graduated and start pretty small then can be added to (as long as we could find a way not to make getting updates cumbersome)? Or, perhaps applicants are given their loan partially in cash and partially in "needed services" (legal advice, etc). Other ideas?

I love the uni-credit idea! Potentially it could be linked to part-time studies. I believe the universities and its other students would also benefit from having more people with hands on experience to contribute in their programs.

Hey there Stefan! Congrats on being shortlisted for our Refinement phase of the Web Start-up Challenge. Only one week left to evolve your concept. We hope you'll be chiming in and updating this exciting idea.

I like your concept a lot: it's simple and clear. I think it can be very successful in those countries where student loans are widespread, as in UK (not so much in Spain, for example, and other EU countries where there's not such an habit). I was thinking that, if you get a student loan, when you finish your studies I suppose you rush to get a job to return the loan... If you were considering setting up your own business, I suppose you just leave that on hold... And sometimes the opportunity is here & now...

Some good points Irene - and, as usual, another straightforward and very useful concept Stefan.I guess for those countries without student-loan systems (or perhaps even centrally through the EEC) copying and building on existing models would provide a starting-point.

@balderton Capital's twitter says "We nurture innovative, world-leading companies. We invest for the long haul - never 'quick flips' - and we look for entrepreneurs with a similar perspective," whereas others funding sources seem interested in the quick flip and exit strategy as soon as possible.Depending on the source of funding and intention behind that funding, it can have an enormous impact on decisions made by a startup.  I wonder how this loan would motivate entrepreneurs and which direction....

I really like this concept a lot, Stefan. My husband is starting a business and access to funding is the #1 issue he's facing. A small business loan isn't quite right for him - but something like this, that has the purpose of helping him get on his feet while also incentivizing his growth, would be really helpful. I'll be eager to see this one get built out a bit more over the Concepting phase.

Nice thought. A loan payback system can be designed which will take into all new asset purchases or hiring into consideration. Instead of loan repayment , banks could also derive paybacks form public offering the new enterprise will make.
This concept has been in place in France for many years for every kind of businness. See http://www.france-initiative.fr/ For innovative project, the loan can be up to 80 000 euros in our place.
I like the french system, has there been any studies on its success?

Follow the link http://www.france-initiative.fr/index.php/france_initiative/presse_documentation/communiques_de_presse/en_2011_pres_de_16_000_entreprises_et_plus_de_35_000_emplois_crees_ou_maintenus you will find figures for 2011: 16 000 business created, 1,1 Bn of loan (including bank loans associated to the loan to the entrepreneur)

When I had a student loan (quite a while back!) in New Zealand  the mechanism for baseline repayments was via an additional tax percentage devised for loan holders (ie. you only had to start repaying the loan once you were earning) A potential build so that startups didn't have to meet repayments until they were deriving a profit?

Great thought, Meena. It would have to be structured carefully so as not to disincentivize profit. Maybe loan repayment comes from revenue, not profit. Love the idea of finding creative ways to help web start-ups get access to funds. I wonder about other creative ways to encourage the right behaviour with web start-ups - e.g., instead of incentives coming by hiring more (not necessarily to the benefit of the start-up at that time), could incentives come for reaching certain milestones - for instance beta release? Stefan, who do you and Bryan envision funding this? Banks or the EC or private investors or even individuals (ala www.zopa.com)? Different parties would have different motivations, which could change the structure of the loan.

Amy u have a very great point. Wow I didn't know of Zopa! that's a great concept! I built on your comment - what do you think about a public private partnership? it all seems allot more bureaucratic than zopa however.

I like the idea of providing confidence to private investors, but I wonder if public money is the signal that will work in this case. What about alternatives such as knowing that prominent angel investors have invested, or knowing the team has worked on start-ups in the past? Here's another bit of inspiration: www.seedrs.com

Making this like student loans, you could go farther and make entrepreneurial loans to students.  Some cash to push a class project that little bit further and start marketing it.  This could alleviate some of Tim's comments below in that you could require a professor or department sign on as a mentor to say there really is a project.And if students were getting their company in gear as they graduate maybe they could start paying off both loans sooner. :)

Hey Stefan , Just an off hand thought.A lot of students aspire to have their own startup when they graduate. But they already have their student loans to payback. Sometimes its quite a big sum which holds them back from trying out exactly.We can have a loan service which gives students extra payback time if they want to have their own startup.

Great idea, however, the success rates of most businesses are so low that producing a specific Entrepreneur-Loan is highly unlikely because most banks would rule out the concept.Team Purple Cobra's-Wells College

A good point Tyler, although drop out / exam failure/ post graduate unemployment rates are also very high and this doesn't put off banks from issuing student loans. I suspect Stefan's idea is for the loans to be underwritten by government, just as I believe is the case with student loans.Meena's idea below makes sense- no repayment until the business reaches a certain freshold of profitability.I think the idea is a sound one although I would hate it to turn out like the schemes tried in the 80s in the UK. These paid the equivalent of unemployment benefit to 'entrepreneurs' who set up all kinds of bogus businesses.I think Stefan's idea is to be far more ambitious and rigorous than this. What worries me are the costs of due diligence and auditing. The interest rate linked to employment levels is an especially excellent idea.

This is a very interesting idea. However, I pose one potential conflict. My class at Wells College interviewed an Italian web entrepreneur and we learned how difficult it is to obtain federal loans for a start-up business in Italy. Throughout Europe, banks are very reluctant to give out money to new businesses due to a lack of trust. Furthermore there is a general fear of failing in the business world so people are less willing to take risks. How can we break through these social barriers to gain European investors trust in its entrepreneurs? We need to find our way to apply the courageous business risk taking practices to the European market and eliminate the fear of failing.

I really like this idea because it lowers the initial risk of failure, makes it more likely that a business will succeed, and lessen the personal risk of failure by giving the entrepreneur a chance to recover and try again making failure not a final state.

enterpreneur_loan.title: Entrepreneur-Loan

the_interview_kit_my_interview_with_ashw.description: Hello everyone my name is Alan Hyman and I have had my own business for over ten years helping startups by being a startup. I was interviewed by Ashwin Gopi.  His link on OpenIDEO is here: http://www.openideo.com/profiles/500520676/
the_interview_kit_my_interview_with_ashw.creator: bc5055a5f26b2fb7705a1b38c317ab06

comments.text: Great posting, Alan! Hope you didn't mind me grilling you. I especially like the part where you talk about feeling low. It's hard to sometimes be the CEO and Errand boy of your own company. Wouldn't it be awesome if there was a network of Entrepreneurs who could barter services? Do I smell a concept?
Loving the "Balancing smarts vs integrity and persistence vs Intellect" equation.
I second that! "Balancing smarts vs integrity and persistence vs Intellect" Nicely said.

Thanks Alan for sharing your experience. Back to your 3 wishes, did you have any of these? It might be interesting if you could also share your insights on your experience of helping start-ups? what do you think are their main challenges? What seem to be the key to successful ventures? Technology? people? network? policies? thanks!

Alan  it would be really helpful for you to set up a fresh profile under your own name. It's likely a bit confusing for folks to see an individual posting on a group profile. comments.text: I am new to the site and have been reading a lot of other peoples' submissions and two happened to cross paths in my brain.  The previous challenge "How might we restore vibrancy in cities and regions facing economic decline?" mentions pock marks of empty blighted space in Detroit.  I am sure that there are similar parts of Europe that have struggled.  Maybe you could create little entrepreneur villages like Christiania (in Denmark) but without all the drugs and bikes.  Some of my most intense productive periods have been when I had a few entrepreneurs crashing with me at my apartment and we worked in close quarters for a week, how much could you accomplish if you all lived in a little community?  You could provide communal meals inexpensively, maybe take 2% of simple equity for companies born in these immersion incubators?
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
AWESOMEEverybody please help make this idea better!

What a fantastic idea, Erik! I love your observation/insight that entrepreneurs often lack focused time - I completely agree! I often say I need a week away from all the distractions around me to catch up 'on life' and read the books I need to read. Being in a different, inspiring environment can really make you focus and achieve that needs doing in the time you have.It also reminds me of the temporary hotel room that is on the London South Bank at the moment http://www.living-architecture.co.uk/the-houses/aroomforlondon/overview/ - a bit random but you can pay to have the room for a night but there are also some incubation type initiatives using it as 'office space'. The cities may not need to find hostels as such but any kind of space that can be turned into a working area. The cooler the better for attracting creative talent ;-)

Love this idea, Erik. Great that it solves basic needs of entrepreneurs. I wonder if we could also combine it with all the empty high street (main street) stores and team up with banks that have closed branches to provide shared workspace near the hostel. Could be an interesting way to engage the start-ups with their communities.

Loving the cross cultivation here, Erik! And programs like the Acumen Fellowships http://www.acumenfund.org/fellows/global-fellows-program/the-fellowship-year.html + IDEO.org Fellows https://www.ideo.org/fellows might hold some further inspiration for what you're proposing.
Nice!

Great idea on EU level. It reminds me also of Garret Lisi's dream http://garrettlisi.com/sh.html (BTW I heard they make progress). EU invested heavily in tourism, each country/city with 100k+ people has an overload of pensions/hostels/hotels at the moment. What about having a seat for each EU country and the hostels have to come with an offer for a collaboration contract of 3 years? If they have a good kitchen, soft beds and fast internet and a great view... What else do we need?
A three year commitment makes sense. I would expect there to be a ton of learning in the first year.

comments.text: Nice attempt to think of the educational aspect of supporting entrepreneurship in Europe. It'll be great to know more about the "TBD"...  I love the video as it provides a good sense of the journey and the different stages. Maybe you could highlight more the different elements you have in mind:- providing experiential learning coaching and mentoring- - creating a network of students, alumni, and professionals (across Europe)You might want to look at the Erasmus program in Europe and see how you could "build upon" it.

oops sorry I did something wrong... let me just go back to my listing of the various elements I could see playing out in your concepts:- providing experiential learning through:1. coaching and mentoring2. a play field where students can experience with new ventures which might end up to be successful- developing multi-disciplinary teams (and the skills need to work in this context)- creating a network of students, alumni, and professionals (across Europe)these points might be part of your answer on how your concept helps support web entrepreneurship.for Erasmus: http://ec.europa.eu/education/lifelong-learning-programme/doc80_en.htm

You might also explore this inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/european-entrepreneurship-awards-/and see how you could build up on it and integrate existing components in your concept. That might make it easier to implement...

pop_up_store_tour_of_europe_by_small_bus.description: A consortium of small European businesses will travel to the hometowns of each of the business owners for a month-long pop-up store experience, where they will publicize their brand, promote online purchasing, and learn about local consumer trends.
pop_up_store_tour_of_europe_by_small_bus.creator: 42776da8182583447fd49a7e426b9bd1

comments.text: I love this idea!  It brings the product to the people and it also targets web illiteracy.  This is a modern day version of a door-todoor sale man.In addition to visiting the hometowns of the business owners, wouldnt it be possible to stop in other location s as well?  This would increase the number potential new customers, similar to how a touring rock band makes many stops in different cities to increase sells of downloads/CDs, merchandise, and potentially gain new fans.   Awesome.

Hi Daniel! Thanks for your comment. It absolutely would be possible for the tour to stop in other locations. The logic behind stopping in hometowns, though, is that the entrepreneur from each town would be able to provide insights on local market trends and demographic preferences to the other business owners, creating a grassroots source for market analysis. It's definitely possible that business owners have insights beyond just their hometown (extending to their region or even country), but it seems like hometown is a good place to start!

Great idea. We are currently working on a close approach. Having a physical store to sell start-up products. We are also considering pop-up store around Europe with the help of our partners in a European Project.
Hi Christian! Thanks for weighing in. How does your concept differ or relate to ours? Do you have any advice or questions for us? Thanks!

Welcome Yale Hacksters! Interesting thoughts. Do you have ideas about how to showcase start-ups who are not dealing in physical inventory? Might there also be innovative ways to promote their offerings?

Hi Meena! Thanks for your thoughts. While this system is clearly most beneficial to those entrepreneurs/ small business owners who have a physical good to sell, I believe that having to opportunity to do an in-person demonstration of one's product can be very useful! Business owners would have the opportunity to answer questions in person, build the trusting relationship that is often lacking from online consumerism, and present a demo with screens showcasing their product. Additionally, these entrepreneurs would benefit from the information on market trends and local demographics that they would gain by exposure to and conversation with local business owners.

I love this idea.  It really shows an understanding of culture and context.  I like how it doesn't call for huge cultural change - shoppers can still view, touch, and try on items.  And the technology that they might not be using is really handled by the vendor.  And yet you are at the same time turning the web illiterate into web shoppers.  Brilliant.

comments.text: Interesting build, Ting-Han! I completely understand the need to find people to test a prototype, especially an independent one. The coaster image idea is really simple and engaging. I wonder if a means of gaining trust in the people testing can be included? Firstly so that your idea can be kept secret if necessary (do people always trust non-disclosure agreements?) and secondly so you know that the person has given genuine, useful feedback?The collaborative consumption model springs to mind - trust between strangers is so important and EBay were one of the first to achieve this with their user rating system. Just some food for thought!

Thanks for the feedback Louise! Instead of finding random people, maybe an online community with registered users will help establish more trust. CouchSurfing's system just came to my mind...see if I could incorporate some ideas into the revised concept!

Louise, inspired by your comments, I posted another concept:http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/1stmovers.com-connecting-trendsetters-with-entrepreneurs/Hope to hear your thoughts on it!

comments.text: Great inspiration and provocative final question, Nima. We hope it's inspires some savvy thinking in our Concepting phase  starting this week!

Hi Nima,I really like the video and that it points out the global potential of the Founder Institute. I also very, very much like the second video--the one on the dynamics of incentives, autonomy, mastery and purpose. I'm getting ready right now to share it in a couple of places but I wonder why this video is there...Rose

I am very glad to hear you liked it. In my opinion, we are all kids and we don't get old, we just age. The reason I put this video was to remind the viewer about the power of engagement and the source of motivation. It's never money on its own. There is usually a game aspect to motivation and for many who want to be influential, they are not fundamentally after money or event status. They have an earning to share and engage. With that said, I think Founder Institute encourages the power sharing in a sport (entrepreneurship) that was for a long time a solo endeavor. Little wordy but I just want to say we all miss pulling on our mom's skirt and excitedly sharing with her what we just learned.

Fab collection but also a very accessible collection! we probably all take it for granted now but DropBox www.dropbox.com/ has allowed file sharing to be so easy. It helps to be mobile when starting up any company.
Louise great, I've use also Box.com , inside teams. :)
I like box.com too, because it does not require any installation and can be accessed with a smartphone
I would add other three (every entrepreneur should use them daily) Google Apps,Facebook PagesAsana

Thanks for all the great comments everyone - am definitely going to play around with some of the suggested tools like Trello and Shipwire that I've not come across before.One other small thought - if you've already come up with a winning name for your startup, it never hurts to do a digital land-grab ASAP.  Register your relevant domain names (there are loads of services to help you do this but I found Gandi.net really good and they live up to their 'no bullsh*t promise) and grab the accounts you think you'll want on Twitter. Even if you just post up a placeholder page or profile, it's great to put a stake in the ground and, to me, it felt my first 'real' investment in my idea.

I think tools are really important.For some reason there are LOTS of different lists, Wikis, Quora posts, slidedecks, websites dedicated to startup tools:Lists - Steve Blank [http://goo.gl/rTKnH], Tom Eisenmann/HBS Startup Tribe [http://goo.gl/vhihk]Wikis - Ian Hogarth/Songkick [http://startuptools.pbworks.com/], Seedcamp [http://biztools.pbworks.com/]Quora posts - One (of many) [http://goo.gl/Sq0nE]Crowdsourced slidedecks - Tom Hulme [http://goo.gl/NDGoS]Infographics - Mashable [http://mashable.com/2011/07/26/startup-tools/], Best Vendor [http://blog.bestvendor.com/2011/07/survey-results-the-startups-toolkit/]

Been using Highrise at Beep and it's been invaluable at tracking conversations. Like anything though you really need to integrate it into your day-to-day workflow for it to really work; use the email dropbox address to bcc conversations so you can track all the interesting conversations you're having and use the tasks to delegate both to yourself and your team.
Anyone have experience in highrise or other small business focused crm software? How does it compare?
Nice ideas. I like tools. You could also add Yammer, sort of an internal facebook meets twitter. Used by huge corporations, but free in a very useable basic version.
We use Do.com (salesforce) and offer you to try on your own start-up Yoomit (www.yoomit.com - we're changing it image ;) helps to manage and organize meetings up to the minute ;)

Be sure as well to checkout fulfilment services like Shipwire.com. Again, we use them at Beep to fulfil our orders and you get global warehousing and shipping for a monthly tiered fee. Also if you need to run support for a product, emails coming in to your inbox isn't going to cut it. Use something like Freshdesk to keep control of support requests and more importantly keep customers happy.
