virtuous_equation.description: Succesfull entrepreneurs choose to adopt an aspiring new one and mentor for 1 year. They groom the aspirant to the early pains of setting up a business, offers  guidance and resources for his new endeavor.
virtuous_equation.creator: 857012841cf2c4a27e35424d8800eb11

comments.text: I think this Idea, could work very well. Do you have ever heard of the modell "business angle". It sounds very similar and have made good experiences in such a way of starting your business.

this kind of relationship is funded through eco^2 in a scalable way... which means mentors could exist at yearly levels, but also seasonal or weekly, or even hourly -- which would be translated as "life coach" perhaps...

Sign me up as well!!I think all we need now is to add a  financer to the equation!During an Entrepreneurship fair in Madrid I got to sit at a conference  given by three venture capital directors and hear what they had to say about funding seed and working with start-ups. They have a very different way of looking at our projects, and I can confirm that from a couple of other experiences/meetings.An experienced entrepreneur is bound to know at least one financer who has trusted them once and made a profit. Can we communicate that it will be in the financers best interest to help this entrepreneur develop another professional? That would really make this effective because by the end of the year the savvy mentee has experience and funding!

How would you attempt to match the mentors with mentees? Would the emphasis be on areas of interest, or different areas of expertise? For example, would you try to match a successful online retailer with someone else who also wants to sell products online, or would you match a mentor who is great with financing with a mentee who has more experience creating websites? I guess what I'm asking is do you want this to be a more reciprocal thing or experienced entrepreneur giving advice to a novice?I really like this idea, though - keep going with it!
I like this one-to-one crowdsource angle. The benefits are multiplied!

I love the idea. The selection process is pretty much built right in.  Entrepreneurs are not wilting flowers, they should be able to agree or disagree with someone about being a "good fit" and working together or not. the mentor and mentee should be able to pick each other.  A webpage with Bios and contact info would be a good way to start.

What a great idea! And sign me up to be the second rookie behind you :) Have you thought about what this matching system would look like/how it might work? How do mentors and aspiring entrepreneurs get matched up? And who might fund this kind of mentoring program?

And I back these questions :) I wonder if incentive could be 'same' as doing a lot of volunteerwork as a student, it improves succesrate when you apply for job when a lot of good will for community is on your Resume. Foursquare.com badges for entrepreneurs? ;)

Terrific idea Paul. I imagine having a black belt system for mentors/mentees. The more people you develop the more you advance and reach a level of "black belt" mentor. More kudos if, for example, you help people from underpriviledged areas or backgrounds...and everybody can see that on your online . Awesome.Thnx for signing up Ashley...we now officially have 2 eager mentees. What about matching us with our mentors through a lottery system, where we have araes of passion (e.g. Community development, media, services, etc.) and we put entreprenuers with  rookies and match them in a monthly draw..imagine the thrill of waiting to find out your match !!Crazy?  What do u think?

Karate belts, right on! Identify some colors/skills on moving to next belt that  you need to support a sustainable business concept, or even find seed money for it. Than you get higher status in higher respected communities. The blackbelts of Europa... BB of Africa... The highest ranges to get in and enjoy lifelong respect.

I had a very similar idea, but this one is much more thought out, great work! :)I'm a student mentor at my university & one thing we really stress is that student mentors/ mentees can have their own relationship; they can meet in person, or just over the web, they can meet once a week or once a semester, etc. Would mentors/ mentees in the Virtuous Equation have to live in the same location, or could they talk over the web? (I just wonder this in regards to the tax breaks - I don't know a lot about economics so please forgive me.) Would they be working in the same physical space, such as the same office?

Thanks for the comment Carly. I was thinking this could be a relationship of an apprentice and a master. like old carpenters used to work with their assistants. under the same roof until the novice is strong enough to setup his own shop and move on. so, a bit of the "analog world" paradigm. tax breaks could be an incentive for existing entrepreneurs to take rookies under their wings and guide them in the early phases, so that all have some kind of a "return"...and tax returns are "digital" :)

Awesome, thanks for your response & the info on tax returns (you learn something new every day!). I like the idea of them working in the same space - it would be the best environment for a new entrepreneur to learn, I think.
Love the moustache. Reminds me of old Buster Keaton movie characters...
Fab visualisation!
thnx Meena...

virtuous_equation.title: Virtuous equation

the_creative_co_op.description: Finding the people with the skills needed to help realise ideas can be extremely difficult, especially when you lack the necessary network of contacts. The Creative Co-Op is an enabler for all, allowing people to source collaborators from their peers
the_creative_co_op.creator: 70d91733bbadc007ffc27e4c384fe37e

comments.text: I like the idea very much - would suggest as you build this out that you incorporate some reference to intellectual property and how to protect it. Perhaps this could initially take the form of a non-disclosure agreement operative until the founder/entrepreneur is "ready" to "go public" - the last thing you want is someone with more money and paid expertise beating you to the finish line.

Good idea Maxi. Some possible inspiration here: http://thecreatorsproject.com/studioIt's not the same as your proposal but it has a really excellent bit of UX design, especially the concept of the Studio, where creators can get together and plan joint projects.

I love the idea, but I could see some problems. One is how are you going to get people with certain skillsets to look on this site? You could end up with more people making a pitch page and not enough skillset people. Another possible problem is the 15 day limit, to me it seems too short a time to find the people you might need to start your business. Especially if there are not a lot of skillset people on the site.

Great idea to tap the enthusiasm of individual entrepreneurs for the benefit of many startup businesses!  It might also be worth thinking about how entrepreneurs could trade services through the Creative Co-Op.  Sometimes it is difficult at an early stage to imagine how offering an equity stake could impact the project later on or take needed revenue away from early cash flow (which could affect how attractive it is for other potential investors once it's built).  If you help create a barter-type system where entrepreneurs are serving each other with specialized skills, it helps them 1) define what they need to complete their business, 2) find the talent to help complete the task, and 3) foster collaboration and awareness among like-minded people.

Interesting stuff, Maxi! A potential build here might be to connect with existing platforms to amplify such an initiative. A bit like Behance did with LinkedIn: http://www.linkedin.com/opensocialInstallation/preview?_applicationId=104096&_ch_panel_id=1

You're right - integrating the service with something like LinkedIn would make it easier to use for everyone, especially applicants. And of course, if it's easier for applicants to represent themselves, its going to be easier for those reviewing applicants. Thanks for the suggestion!

Glad you liked the suggestion, Maxi. If you want you can add any collaborative builds to your concept post as we proceed  by hitting the Update Entry button up there to the right of your post. Looking forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO!

Maybe Airbnb should introduce this feature for entepreneurs to meet other entrepreneurs, or artists to meet other artists, muscians to muscians and so on and so on.......

Avi: Sent message on twitter to Brian Chesky Airbnb co-founder, he gave a good speech at London launch, maybe he'll reply and put something into the community as they are all designers I think... :)I want to do something small and actually realise it as pursuing my startup now which is keeping me plenty busy. A global network of Blackboxes:)

comments.text: Great analogy, Krassimira. It is interesting that a lot of our great sports heroes start putting single-minded devotion behind their sports at a very young age. It doesn't seem to me that's the case with entrepreneurship. The coaching mentality is really interesting in this case - I can't think of a great sport hero who didn't have a full time amazing coach behind him or her. How might we strengthen coaching from a young age for budding web entrepreneurs? What else can we learn from how sports heroes attain success? How might we celebrate our entrepreneurs like we celebrate our sports heroes? (Fascinating that we sometimes disdain the "commercialism/capitalism" of successful entrepreneurs but applaud sports stars who make millions)

I agree with you that coaching is very important. In my view building confidence is essentail as well. Also the encouragement from family and friends-> they are often the first uers/customers of a product/service and they are the first ones to give a yes or no...I might think of a concept for later on around your questions.
Sport; I always love the sisters Williams analogy, they compete against eachother all the time, where it is more important to get better/fitter in mind/body, than to win. Look how far it got them.

beware_of_bad_translation_or_bad_localis.description: A crowd sourcing platform may help web startups to easily find traps in bad translations, or bad brandings for different countries. Also the acceptance of products and services could be tested before going live in other countries.
beware_of_bad_translation_or_bad_localis.creator: 86367ed3fdd9dc98bf2c8dcdaa971703

comments.text: Translation is very important, even in every day language when you are visiting other countries.  Meanings of a word vary from country to country, in one country could be harmless every day speak and offensive in another.

Let's take it a step further - how about a site that is dedicated to open source localization promising web start-ups?  I'm thinking an open source community that is dedicated to translation and usability testing throughout the EU - one of the main stumbling blocks in the EU is that, without internationalization/localization, your market is initially limited to a small subset of the EU that speaks the language in which you initially developed the app/site in, which limits potential growth and critical mass.

right, thats the pointI have been in software development for several years. In one big project we had to think global from the start. The 'normal' way for startups is to quickly get the software/apps/website working for the home market. Localisation at a later point may get really difficult.An open source community for europeanization or better globalization might be a great deal for entrepreneurs.
Great discussion guys. We're looking forward to these ideas being also posted in the upcoming Concepting phase!

Well, this is valid point, but it's very difficult to find good international name.For Example SAP named one of latest products HANA - in Czech its Women name, but it's also mean "stud shame"One Czech company producing precision moving technology parts have name TOS, but in French this mean "trembling"

Yes, there are many examples of such namings.I think, it is not always necessary to find the ONE-fits-all name that works in every country.But it is essential to proof fitting of the name before entering new territories. Sometimes a little ambiguity might be useful.Not very useful are Siemens Sirotec (zero tech) - for automation systems or Nescafe in Portugal sounds like n'es cafe (no coffee).

A thought :Can we design a banking service called Future Loans similar to the concept of Future Stocks.Future Loans will be a service in which Banks provide a future date loan to the startups based on mutual consent. The eligibility for future loans is decided by the social media popularity of the startup and once a threshold popularity target is achived the loans can be actually obtained with sepcial offers.Here social media popularity becomes the marker of economy for the startups. For example : 1. "number of likes" or "number of mentions" become a marker of economy. 2. A threshold target of number of tags/mentions become the eligibilty condition for Future Loans. This will give these startups a lot of visibility as well a hands on expericence of economic condition.Please post you suggestion.
your suggestions *.

comments.text: Hi Brennan, what is the key differentiator of your program against existing MBA programs, and other program, which provide trainings to entrepreneurs?

Gabor, thanks for your comments. This program incorporates an important eBusiness component as well as structured, in depth and extremely valuable real world learning experiences and opportunities. Furthermore, MBA programs are postgraduate programs whereas this program is designed for those who do not already have an undergraduate degree and years of work experience but have the determination to succeed and are passionate.

Really like the idea of creating strong programs and that you would have a required monthly book club - you learn so much from these types of sources! I also have a few thoughts to share with you: 1) In regards to getting started, could this program be integrated into existing entrepreneurship degree programs? 2) What about another requirement for joining the program is that each student (or a group of students) must start a company before they graduate? Allows the students really put theory to practice right when they are in the midsts of it. 3) It would be interesting to have as an added component that during the exchange semester students are partnered with start-ups in the country they are off to and work part-time during the duration of the semester. This, again, would allow students to put theory into practice but at the same time, get exposure to what the start-up environment, difficulties, etc are for companies in a foreign company.
Great builds, Karina! And of course, our focus on Europe means the exchange semester could be quite financially feasible.
Very true! Which is certainly very attractive to all students!

founders_dictionary.description: Founders have many problems, finding press, finding financing, finding a team. One problem non-business trained founders have is understanding the scene, the jargon and the language. For that we have created Founders Dictionary.

comments.text: I really like this idea. Somehow I was envisioning a tool like a visualthesaurus (http://www.visualthesaurus.com/) could also help in order to relate the words.

Two great additions from the last week:1. Add a game: Users test their knowledge improving their entrepreneurial vocabulary and at the end are asked to upload one word on a topic they know. via OpenIDEO's (Cansu and Louise)2. Add experts: add a list of twitter handles, books, article links, videos for words that someone is an expert in. e.g. LeanStarup: See also: eric ries, leanstartup, leanstartupmachine, leancamp, Sal Virani, Rob Fitzpatrick,
Point 2 from Mikko Jarvenpaa

Hi everyone. Thanks for the support and your comments.I'm working on the design and branding of the site and solving the contribution challenge.In which cases would you contribute a word? How can we make the contribution process easier?

I don't know if it's about making contributing easier so much as making sure that the contributed definitions are correct. Having a team of editors/moderators to oversee contributed definitions (like moderators on Wikipedia) would be ideal.Another angle to contribution is requesting a word. What if I'm an entrepreneur and run into a word that I don't know and isn't in Founders' Dictionary? I should be able to request that a member of the community give a definition so other people aren't stuck in the same quandary as I. The most plausible way that I'd contribute a word is if I were looking up a word and realized that a word that I was familiar with wasn't in the dictionary. Then I'd try and contribute a definition.Note how the "request definition" feature could hasten the expansion of the dictionary -- if there was a sidebar on the site with the requested words (and a link to contribute their definitions), then people wouldn't have to look at the dictionary itself to contribute a definition. It's easy to see how this would make contributing definitions much easier and faster. So far, you guys are looking great. Keep up the good work!

Thanks Brett, Request definition is rethinking user contribution as currently the user has to submit a word and a definition which was on the homepage but is now changed to the homepage being more about the viewer not the contributor.

Great Harry! I see you uploaded 30 new words! Awesome! I went to a lecture from a Y combinator guy today in London at Springboard (accelerator) and learnt about 'soft circle.' and 'convertible debt' Still picking up vocab all the time.

Thanks for re-raising these issues, guys.I am in complete agreement with Harry's suggestions and as a potential user (rather than contributor) I would really ultimately like a seamless approach to requesting definitions. That's why I suggested that a 'failed search' approach would be a natural way to collect words and terms not already in the dictionary. The first step for a 'user' will be to use the search function - it should be fairly straightforward to provide a custom response (analogous to custom 404 error pages) and perhaps (as a unique feature) offer to email the definition if the user is prepared to leave their email address. This would make it an educational service - as a ICT trainer I am not an infallible source of information to my clients so I would often have to say "i don't know, but I will find out and let you know."While such a service might not be entirely unique it would, I believe, be a means of retaining or regaining  users who in the meantime may be forced to look elsewhere.If Founder's Dictionary is to be monetized in some way this would contribute to a win-win situation.At the back-end the word would then be added to the 'requested' list which might, as Harry suggests, appear as a sidebar list. It is difficult to know how big the 'requested' list will be at any given time but hopefully sufficiently small to be scanned "at a glance". Perhaps the 'failed searches' could provide visitors with a request or contribute option.Another possibility might be to include requested terms in the browse lists (suitably highlighted). I guess there is a range of possibilities some or all of which might be incorporated. As part of my 'learning experience' in website design and development I have been investigating Google custom searches and it appears relatively easy to create such an item, which could then be offered to any other web-based winning concepts from this challenge to incorporate into their sites, and perhaps more broadly too.In my Wordpress based Open IDEATOR Resources prototype site I am creating a descriptive page for Founder's Dictionary linking it directly to the Founder's Dictionary site. As an example in the description I have created a direct link for the definition of Accrual. Of course a custom search engine has to be generated at the Founder's Dictionary end but I would be very happy to trial install any custom search on my prototype site, as it will always be experimental in nature.
Thanks for the ideas! I will look at how we can implement a "request" mechanism.

Product is looking really good!As a potential user I might prefer a little more prominence for the search function but that is only a personal observation.Looking forward to seeing this as a winning concept.
agreed!
Paul, it's at the top of our list for the new interface
Congratulations on sharing a winning concept! The EC is thrilled by your working prototype and thinks it is a great way to help raise the bar for all entrepreneurs.

Congrats James both on the original idea and on the prototyped product hope they take it up as is and help in further development. Looking forward to the realisation of this concept as part of the whole suite of tools chosen in winning concepts.

We are a team at Wells College and we had combined this idea with the Start-up Wallet. What we did was create a book that included how to find financing and press and defined business terms, internet terms, and than added sections for the cost of starting the business and the required steps needed to create the website and make the business official.  We had set up the book with clear sections and dividers that are easy to read, easy to find and are clear cut instead of long passages.
http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/start-up-wallet/

One of the plus points of this being a website rather than a book is that it would become a dynamic resource that can be continually updated. I think more web entrepreneurs would access a website than a book. What do others think?
I think we all tell a story, and it should available across various mediums. For starting off, I think the web makes sense due to low costs and easy scalability.

The web would be easier to update and grow over time. It would be more similar to a Wikipedia type online dictionary. Printer-friendly pages could be created to allow users to print out terms/sections and keep in a binder of sorts. Maybe somewhere down the line users could create accounts and save terms, add their own notes and print if needed.

@Meena. Yes a smart website could work better I think. Is anybody thinking about peoples incentive to keep data up to date? @James, are you building from scratch the backend? There are tools out there which try to be wikipedia 3.0, mashing text and number calculations together you prob know about. @Vanessa & Jessica. What about meet in the middle way : Have in the site a print on demand button to get your physical up to date copy from a cloud printing service?
The print on demand concept is a nice idea.

@Paul I possibly need a good definition for back-end and may have used it incorrectly! :)The guys are using wordpress and making a custom design whereas I used a theme.Vanessa: Great point about personalisation, I was thinking today about personalised to region as more long term plan, so UK one might advise about UK terms from law to SEIS, whereas Austrian one might have different schemes and different laws.

Regionalisation is great, and necessary, inclusion in this process.LawMaster has the same issues and the hope is that if such a concept is realised through EEC collaborative effort then perhaps it could lead to greater levels of process consolidation.and standardisation.

WordPress sounds good to start with for now. I also hope the EEC is catching on, though from somewhere needs to come incentive to keep it alive. The EEC has databases and the only ones which stay up to date are the ones where you are legally binded to submit info.

Yes - Founder's Dictionary is almost certain to make it through to realisation - after that agreement between OpenIDEO team and EEC will kick-in but I expect that becomes opportunity for developers and start-ups to partner for continued development and maintenance.

To answer Meena's question, and in alignment's with most other comments, I think the web will allow collaboration, dynamic updates and it will be cheaper. However, I like the idea of being able of printer-friendly pages. Personalization would also matter (in particular regarding legal issues).
By the way, talking about personalization, language would also be important to think of. Translating the dictionary will be important.
Great point, A-L  especially as we are considering multi-lingual Europe on this challenge.

Anne-Laure thanks for the point. In my notes for the next version. I believe the web is the main platform and having a printed version of a specific category (or someone's contributions) via print-on-demand gives a sense of ownership.
This concept addresses inclusion of non-digital/business idea innovators in a moderately simple fashion. It appears certainly to be user-friendly and adaptable according to users need. Well done!

On the next build think that the homepage should be the dictionary and various options for contribution are made easy as opposed to now where the homepage is the contribution page and you navigate away to find the dictionary.
I notice there is a (non-active) link to startuplawyer dot com - is this intended as sponsorship or advertising?
what is a non active link? The definitions from startuplawyer.com should be linked. It is not sponsorship or advertising, just where the word came from.
ahh I understand - its just a point of reference not intended to be a link to the commercial legal practice startuplawyer dot com

This is a super cool tool. I have seen attempts to do that in the past but so complicated that it just never took off. Your is simple yet powerful.Your challenge will be to get people contributing and then driving attention then growing traffic etc. :) You know that. Here a few thoughts:1) Make sure everybody who is contributing is exposed as a contributor. In sort of a "Hall of fame"2) Give points to contributor. Each contribution - say - 10 points. The more points the higher up in the Hall of fame.3) Allow visitors to actually value the content - again very simple 'like' to ranking and rating - way to complicated. Each like gives another 10 points to the author.4) Humans are competitive, so Authors will ask friends to like the content - that creates traffic. :)5) At some point you will worry about financing the hosting, traffic etc. You may get sponsors such as law firms, consultants, recruiter, banks etc. to sponsor it.6) In order to make it more social, provide a vanity URL for each contributor - make sure I get www.foundersdictionary.com/Axels and the more likes I get for my contribution the higher I rank as an expert for entrepreneurs. That gives you also the entrance to be featured on XeeMe, where we help over 250 social media companies to gain more attention :)  http://xeeme.com/smdir Need a board member? Happy to chat -ha ha ha Axelhttp://XeeMe.com/AxelS

admitting_failure.description: What can we learn by sharing stories of failure? The Admitting Failure website collects & shares stories to leverage learning in the social development sector.
admitting_failure.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: Right on! There are so many cases of failure (and success) among startups and their founders. If only new entrepreneurs could tap into this wealth of information! Definitely an important mission that Admitting Failure has undertaken.A couple things. First, is there any reason not to share successes as well as failures? If we only focus on failure, and all of the different ways we can fail, it seems we may always find some reason NOT to pursue our passion and play it safe. There are plenty of lessons from failure that if you look at another example, with similar conditions, another company succeeded. The key lies in understanding which conditions and decisions were different between the two.Second, it's important that entrepreneurs are able to get relevant information efficiently. This could be tricky. There are so many examples out there, it's difficult to know which lessons apply to whom. Sure, there's some industry-specific filters you could apply, but I bet sometimes the most valuable and relevant information for a given innovator will come from a totally unrelated startup. I guess one option would be to filter ideas based on stage of development. In fact maybe it's better to divide one entrepreneur's story into lots of bite-sized parts that apply to specific situations, so an entrepreneur doesn't have to read articles 90% irrelevant to their situation to find the 10% that's relevant. Plus, if they see the 10% first, they will be more likely to care about the other 90%.Efficient transfer of experience and advice is one of several things we're trying to do with Zaplings. We really want to be a facilitator that connects people in fun, relevant ways to each other and to valuable resources. Admitting Failure seems set to become one of these valuable resources, and a partnership between us could be extremely valuable. We would help people discover Admitting Failure, and Admitting Failure could help our producers' ideas blossom.
Yes! Very important. Failure is an opportunity to learn. Maybe the best there is.

Great inspiration. I wonder if it would be helpful to categorize the failures (as in this article http://goo.gl/6SJfw) to encourage entrepreneurs to actively seek out good failures. According to the article that would include:Version failure-----------------Small failures that lead to incremental but meaningful improvements over time. Examples: Linux operating system; evolution.Predicted failure-------------------Failure as an essential part of a process that allows you to see what it is you really need to do more clearly because of the shortcomings. Example: the prototype -- only by creating imperfect early versions of it can you learn what?s necessary to refine it.
Great build, Kelsey.

Another thought I had was that cataloging and helping people use failure properly helps dispel the myth of the epiphany. I am always telling people that good ideas never stand alone. They are a combination of previous experiences good and bad that have been combined in some new novel way.  I think if we allow people to really unravel the history (including the failures) of companies that are admired, there is a lot to be learned from the realization that there is rarely a magical moment, just lots of hard work.  Of course the best thing a budding entrepreneur can do is just go to work, but it would be good to be able to ask "How has this failed"

I like this. The group MobileActive organizes what they call FailFaire, where mobile and ICT developers (in social development sector) get together to share ideas. MA typically publishes a summary of the discussion, which is very useful. More info http://mobileactive.org/tagging/failfaire
Wow  that's great, Graham. I'ma fan of MobileActive so it's fab to find out that they take this approach of seeing failure as an opportunity for learning. Way to go!

How did I miss this inspiration, Meena?! I love it! So relevant to the insights from the interview I carried out. If that start up had used a site like this, I wonder if they would have moved forward, faster?Turning a negative into a positive - that's my way of working!

Awesome post! I think that actually it is very common that people feel overwhelmed by the idea that they have to work everything right from the very beginning, and better than anyone. This false sense of perfection really hurts the creativity growth. I guess, we usually feel safe applying a set of established rules that, in some sense, have proofed to be effective. But, by doing this with everything, how many key variables are we failing to consider? Culture, language, beliefs, etc. can make a huge difference between the success and failure of any given project. We should eventually stop the practice of "one-size-fits-all" and promote a more open and tailored way of learning and understanding. Take the time to recognize that variables are there, not as an obstacle, but as an opportunity to test our ability to develop new solutions and uncover unmet needs. At the same time, be aware that there will be times when we may totally miss to consider the variables favoring a bad outcome (long held habits may be hard to get rid off). And that such a thing is ok, as long as we take it as a learning source to improve future endeavors.

great post! I'm interested in the power of failure and the shame that accompanies it which prevents people from starting a business, and I have posted a talk from TED exploring the emotion and its effect on innovation.http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/confronting-shame-and-vulnerability-makes-a-good-entrepreneur-/

I would add to your idea Meena is some more tangible tools and frameworks for those who share stories to capture "the moment of failure" and how it moved them forward...I also think it would be even more powerful to capture videos of people sharing their stories!

comments.text: Interesting points made here, Avron. I agree that projects can fall down when it comes to the specification phase. It's usually a lack of understanding between the founder and developer (if they are different!). James' Founders Dictionary http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/founders-dictionary/ and Carrie's System that Translates http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/creating-a-system-that-translates-between-idea-people-and-programmers/ are concept which resonate with your concept - worth a look.I'm going to build on this idea but looking at the researching/discover phase... thanks for the inspiration ;-)

Louise, my view is that with regard to the researching/discover phase there are already a wide variety of tools and methods out there, people like Steven Blank and Eric Riess have written extensively about this topic. I don't think that throwing money at the discovery stage will solve anything as in some way the entrepreneur has to go through that process with a certain amount of ingenuity in order to succeed later on. My concern for start-ups that are pre-dominantly web or mobile based is the apparent lack of methodology in developming, managing and depolying the software that these businesses would rely on. Whether they turn out to be sustainable businesses is another matter. If there was a well worked out methodology it might at least save on resources and put otherwise ocupied technical resources to more productive uses. Also one would assume that the consumer would gain from having far better working choices to choose from.

Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

Thanks ...

I liked the planner more than the roadmap. I think all entrepreneurs take different raths to realizing the opportunity. I am really interested in specifically the process that is used to develop web and mobile applications (as I see this as a huge area of wasted resources).

comments.text: This is a really interesting idea.  I would love to see this expanded to include some of the niche markets (such as my interest: equestrian) that have small markets in both the USA and the EU so that a small company can capture a wider market than is possible in any one company.
Thanks Victoria, products that appeal to passionate but niche audiences across the world are most certainly one of the targets for the proposed scheme. Equestrian is a perfect example.

Very interesting concept Tim.I hope I am interpreting this correctly in so far as it makes a more level playing field for start-ups where there is an element of competition between potential partners.Can I please ask what part, if any, does Intellectual Property play in this marketplace generally?

Thanks Paul and apologies for the delay in responding to your comment. Yes, hopefully there would be a more level playing field and start ups would be evaluated based on the attractiveness of their idea and their progress in implementation rather than their size. In answer to your question about IP, I would see a role for this body in giving support to the start ups and supplying templates for franchises and licenses.

The middle of the night usually Meena, after my son has woken me up and I can't get back to sleep!I'm very open to building on the concepts here, including my own. There are some great ones up on the board now so I plan to get commenting today.I should point out that I'm posting in a personal capacity and all views and comments are my own. However, there clearly is a lot of synergy between my employers work and what you are doing with this and other challenges.
We're stoked to know that folks turn to OpenIDEO when they can't sleep!
Could be quite common practice - I do it too although I can't plead the same reason for my insomnia.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thanks! So many great start ups struggling in small EU countries because of their inability to reach new markets. Infrastructure is there- just needs some coordination

comments.text: I really like how this will bring more action and practice to EU entrepreneurial classrooms! I have had entrepreneurship courses in both my bachelor and master degree studies in Denmark, however a major point I felt the course lacked was stimulation games like this. Theory is great, but utilizing and putting that theory to practice is so much more powerful!
So great to see a concept built on your experience as faculty, A-L. Great thought to start with a paper simulation as well.

Thanks Meena. I find simulations (computer-based and paper based) very useful and powerful and students love them to. In the case of entrepreneurship, while having students working on real projects and business plans, it might not always be possible and some might feel not confident enough... This could be a great tool in particular based on the informal feedback I heard from faculty teaching entrepreneurship.I wish we had more time to develop the concept with Ashwin.

comments.text: Great stuff Ashwin. If others want to use the interview kit that Ashwin & his NYU-Poly professor put together  check it out here: http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/the-interview-kit-learning-from-entrepreneurs/

Great interview, Ashwin. A couple points in particular stand out: the first being that your friend felt more confident when he knew someone (his mentor) would be proud of him even if he "failed" - this is awesome because it points to the importance of having the right cultural support. The second point that moved me was his first "genie in a bottle wish," which is simply to keep doing (in this case combining science and economics) what he's doing forever. I think a lot of success in start-ups comes from not just wanting to START something, but wanting to SOLVE something. What did others find inspiring?

Nice one Amy  this brings up a great point when posting interviews. It's a good idea to add your key takeaways/insights from the interview somewhere on your post. Here's hoping others using the brilliant kit, which Ashwin & co have put together, keep in mind going forward. Ask. Highlight Insights. Inspire!
Wow, yeah. I'll definitely do that from the next inspiration.

comments.text: To add to this, why not incentivise big online communities (Netmums, Avaaz, etc) to 'plug in' or 'adopt a start up'? I'm really sold on the idea of leveraging an established company's channels to offer start-ups a route to market. Especially if it is planned in at the earliest stage possible when that company can influence product development.Like your blog too Paul - some interesting posts on there, especially the latest about education. I would love to see an IDEO challenge on something to do with the problems and opportunities relating to i-pads and toddlers / preschoolers!

exactly, plugging in early can be really win-win for the host company and the startup; both can evolve/grow better/faster. big online communities having 'real plugins' webentrepreneurs, is good thinking can be technically easy, though do they have 'real challenges/innovation need like big firms and cities have (=investment incentive).  I can imagine helping these global portals go local through plugins.
ipad toddler challenge on openideo; yes! Would love to see global inspirations gathered how to help kids from not getting bored in school when 6. What institute should we ask to sponsor one?

Where I got the idea for title from : http://www.pwcaccelerator.com/ PWC is aligning with silicon valley box 'plug 'n play startups. This is mostly getting startups started and than to use their network to scale. There are about 100 incubators/accellerators in European cities, if not more. Many concepts are great, but when funding runs dry to host the startups, the startups die with it. In the period the startup has momentum, it should seed itself in more cities or a big firm, this is where EC help is needed to faciltate.

comments.text: Hey kelsey -- thanks for pointing me to your concept.  I like the kick-off idea of partnering with students at local universities, as the more I thought about it, the more I saw this toolkit as most appealing to new or young entrepreneurs esp. before the content on mobile app got more sophisticated.  I could see experienced entrepreneurs getting the most out of the mobile app over time and perhaps the timebox.  I liked that each part of the toolkit worked best with the others in a very IDEO-like spirit and competency model: the business by design deck could be a good, easy to digest, first-point-of-contact for the toolkit and then act as reference for later use (discovery), the mobile app would turn the deck into a living document where a budding entrepreneur could learn from her own or others' documented experiences (concepting/refinement), then the timebox would be a structured way to actually do something about what you had learned (implementation: acquire or improve skills).

I love that this idea includes the mobile app. Even with well-designed cards, some of us need concrete examples to learn new concepts.  The mobile app is a great way to hear how others interpreted the cards, used them to solve their own challenges and learn from their experiences. Nice!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thanks. Exciting to get feedback for refinement
This reminded me to keep reading "Business By Design!" I almost forgot about it!
Change By Design*
Particularly like the 4 bullet points for card content - looks like the idea will offer more than just top-level info.
Great!  It's crazy but in 2010 I was helping setting up a university design pathway for T-shaped persons using the heroes journey and game design principles.  Totally see where this can lead to!

Utilizing this tool as well as the simulation game from the virtual incubator concept could make for a great addition to entrepreneurship courses throughout the EU!Concept link: http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/definitely-a-virtual-incubator/#c-ce4bd8678997fd9068ba4cb0777b866f

comments.text: Interesting concept, Ahmed, addressing a real need. I wonder if you could elaborate a bit more on step 1 - assembling the network of voters. What would entice them to participate? How will you build up that group of people? Perhaps it would be worth a tie-up with a site like kickstarter to help people stay in touch with and support sites they've already invested in. Take a look at how http://fundhaus.com/ builds on top of kickstarter.

Hi Amy, thanks for dropping by! As for your good questions, I think there are many possible incentives or benefits that would hypothetically entice the pushers network not only to participate, but rather to grow if marketed quite well. Below are a few examples:- Psychological/Sentimental - Pushers will feel happier knowing they are helping others maximize their potential and understanding how their businesses will perform. Such fulfillment is fairly addictive and contiguous.  - Rational/Logical - Pushers will have free stuff .. free access, free applications, free trial and probably free products- Functional - Pushers will climb up the network ladder as they emerge to become more active in terms of testing, pushing, collaborating and networking - think of "Design Quotient" model of OpenIDEO I wouldn't agree more on the point you mentioned concerning the tie-up  with high traffic entities such as Kickstarter and the likes. A beautiful example you shared on fundhaus - many thanks! Surely, so many variations of the same can be worked out to ensure the network grows acceptably and robustly fast.

masspush_a_push_getting_you_on_the_radar.title: massPUSH - A Push getting you on the Radar!

the_founder_s_roadmap.description: What if there were literally a roadmap for entrepreneurs and web founders to understand the steps it takes to start a business?
the_founder_s_roadmap.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: This is great and has the potential to be a fantastic tool for fast-tracking ideas forward!

This is a great idea Ashley! This Road-Map would definitely be a great resource for the start up community. It would be great to also do a crowd sourcing community (website) that will allow founders to give their personal insights as they are taking their journey through the checkpoints. This will give founders real experiences to reference.
Aina, I really like your point of incorporating the personal stories of entrepreneurs  everyone's map will look different after all. Thanks for  weighing in and apologies for being slow to reply!

I agree with Aina in that there is a great opportunity for input from successful entrepreneurs who have experience drawing (and most likely re-drawing) their own road map. What if there was a feature called "I'm lost!" that would connect the user to an appropriate mentor who could help them find their way to the next checkpoint or milestone? It would be akin to stopping for directions. The mentors could be pre-interviewed and tagged with keywords that would be used to match the best mentor to each "lost" entrepreneur given the nature of the startup and their location on the Road-Map.

Great, don't forget to put in the failure periods, they will happen, it is not only a stairway to heaven :) Especially going through the downfalls and head up going strong is important. I read some inspirations on the importance of psychological guidemap'

This is a great idea Paul. What if these moments could be called something clever like 'rest stops' on the map - almost like a chance to take a time out, reflect on your progress and assess the missteps you might have made?

Missteps/Missed-steps breaks probably, to reflect on the steps you took and because being further (and wiser) to see if you did enough or should do some more partnersearching friends user testing. So it doesnt become a waterfall. Scrum fits?

Good points - many steps will be cyclical and iterative - like conventional software development - and each step perhaps represents milestones in conventional project management.I can envisage two levels to this. There are many ways of getting from London to Rome (by road) sometimes detours will be necessary, even retracing steps, but good planning will make a smoother journey.At the top level we can see the major steps (like Paul's 12 steps)  underpinned by detail in something like Louise's Project Angel and incorporating tools like Andreanna's Toolbelt. Bringing these concepts together truly collaboratively might result in an excellent and self-evolving expert system application across all platforms.

Hi Paul, Ashley, sorry only see this reply now. Various concepts hook in together, complementary. Would be pitty if only 1 would get through this phase and loose interest of people to further develop their ideas.  You mention a few, here is my throw : 1. Identifying ingredients : The startup wiki http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/the-startup-wiki/  2. Search ingredients for own soup : Fast help on mobile : Angel http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/-project-angel-planning-for-success/ and (Zaphod) Guide http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/the-start-up-b4-s-guide-to-the-marketplace/3. Have the data and fast search as a resource for timeline/roadmap/highway  : this concept.4. Have an inspiring journey with EU hero stories as guide. Collect/connect heroes in webentrepreneurship to inspire people to join/start online business. http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/hero-startup-roadmap/This is enough for webentrepreneurs not all the time have to reinvent the wheel, locally, globally. I see a foursquare/wiki/facebook timeline appish toolie. ....5. To inspire a generation which is NOT yet thinking about webentrepreneurship, If the data is real (crowdsourced up to date). And the 'holy' hero starters success stories are real. We have a backbone to develop something like urgentevoke http://www.urgentevoke.com/ in the future. ( Real data resources + great fictional/real hero layer) .

It might sound obvious but it would be good to include information on what happens if the person chooses not to (or can't for some reason) follow the road map at a certain point. The fact that starting up is convoluted and confusing means it could be easy to try and jump hurdles or skip sections but this could be detrimental to success. I've been working with a client who a wants a similar idea for his company to follow and we discussed creating a 'snakes and ladders' visual for them so that they could instantly see how far they would be set back if they didn't follow the journey properly...
Great point Louise. It will be great for people to know the potential extra hurdles they might get into by omitting a step.

This is a great point too. Maybe it's less of a curvy map like I've drawn, but more like a process flow diagram that shows decision points along the way....I'll have a think about how I might revise my image.

The concept is really great!I admit one of my first thoughts was "snakes and ladders" but I don't think there is anything wrong with your image Ashley. In my humble opinion it represents the twists and turns encountered along the way, perhaps with the occasional blind alley, cul-de-sac or roadblock. I think the imagery could even be embellished in places with the odd bridge, hill to climb, plateau, downhill run.the analogy goes on,,, maybe I'm an old romantic - now I'm thinking La Tour de France - teamwork solo effort - my mind is running away....

Hi Paul, sorry for my slow reply - but yes! It's easy (and fun) to start imagining what this map might look like. Lots of the landmarks and symbols we see on maps could actually very nicely translate to stories, decisions or pivot points on this map too. Thanks for weighing in.

Very nice idea. Of course, as you said, each start up is its own journey and each country is specific, however, through some of the interviews posted in the inspirations, once can see some similarities emerging. You could also imagine then country based versions (the founder's road map in the UK, in France, in Spain, in Germany, etc.) if / when needed. You could imagine a paper version but also an interactive version that would allow you to go more in details, maybe with short interview excerpts.

Oh I love the idea of a map for each country! And then there could be elements or 'stops' on the map that help founders see moments when they can be creating opportunities to work across borders and countries.

Continuing here - I think the interactive aspect is a winner too - the interviews could be a bit like tourism highlights, maybe based on Paul's heroes, and James McBennett's Founders Dictionary like interpretations for road signs, while links to important standard steps like those in Louise's Project Angel could be like milestones. These in turn might link to Andreanna's Toolbelt, although these last three would stand on their own too.  Below these would be further interactive elements like James Moyer's Intelligent Flowcharts and another related concept IP FastStart (that I'm about to publish).I'm sure I am leaving out lots of relevant concepts that have appeared since you floated this and I must start to map them to get a proper overview - but I see this and Haiyan's Startup Planner Platform as complementary top layers.

Great idea! Having checkpoints that challenges assumptions would be extremely valuable. Also providing a resource for "no strings attached capital through competitions and grants can build momentum and guide one through the early stages...for someone who might turn to a road-map for guidance.
Nice one. Maybe some learnings from Wicked Start? http://www.wickedstart.com/features/2/detail#

Hi Ashley,I really like this concept! As you said though, every idea is different, every start-up has different needs and the journey varies according to who you are, where you live, which resources you have, etc... Recently I put together a Mobile Business Entrepreneurship course for teaching entrepreneurship in Africa where I guided entrepreneurs in the process of  finding the right idea and make it happen on paper (business plan). It didn't include funding and legislation, but only pure business design. That process is also the same I used to organise the tools on the platform I put together, www.businessdesigntools.com .What I noticed is that you do need a 'Human' and 'Expert' to guide you through the process... Maybe your map could be linked to my 'Business Design Coaching' platform idea?  http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/business-design-coaching-for-start-up/
Oh, I like it! I'll connect our two ideas using Build Upon next....Great points about the 'human' element of this.
simply brilliant!this reminds me of Tom's video, on how to visualize a business model:http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/where-to-start-how-to-start/
Great point - I'll add it as a build :) Glad you liked my idea!

Cool concept Louise! I definitely agree that it makes sense to break down the massive mission of creating a startup into manageable parts to move great ideas forward. It can become overwhelming when you think of everything at once, but if you define the tasks, set priorities, and focus on the next step, progress is not so far away.

Wow  savvy thinking Louise. Do you envision something that could apply to all projects or specifically to start-ups? If the latter, seems like Start-up Angel might be a better name to differentiate it from the cluttered marketplace of task organising apps. Just a thought...
agreed on the change of name as a way to differentiate the app.

Good point, Meena. I see value in creating the App for start-ups with the view to widening the offering later on. Start-Up Angel would be more appealing for this audience.  The interface also needs to be different to general planning tools - I want this to be fun and engaging rather than just a necessity.

Very nice Louise. I like how you thought of providing structure, tools as well as leaving some flexibility depending on the different needs.I was thinking that you could think of incorporating the tool bet concept http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/toolbelt-everything-you-need-always-at-hand./ as part of the resources offered. From the description of the concept and my conversation with Adreana, it seems that it is a "library"of resources that you can grow as much as you want. What your concept brings in is some structuring by providing steps but also triggering questions.

Yes these concepts mesh very well and Priyanka's concept for connecting entrepreneurs and experts ( http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/connecting-entrepreneurs-and-experts/ ) is also somewhat complementary.

Thanks for the build ideas - real potential here. Including a library resource is really important for the app to be useful beyond basic planning.  The idea of connecting entrepreneurs and experts could definitely be part of the crowdsource aspect of the app.

Thanks for adding me to your virtual team! I'm a big fan of this concept and glad to see my own idea inspired yours. Perhaps there's a way that my idea could be incorporated into yours? What if the mobile interface looked a bit like my roadmap  when you click on a stage in the map, you'd get taken to a screen much like your image suggests. This way people can see the overal journey but drill down into the steps and progress they're making along the way. What do you think?
Good idea Loiuse and I particularly like the idea of using the roadmap as the interface - its innovative and appealing and with this app behind would provide a sound underpinning.
Very nice indeed. I like indeed the idea of having the road map as an interface, or at least to structure the different steps.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

I think that this is a good idea that will allow people to plan out what they need to get done. This is really helpful for those people who need to manage their time better. This is very helpful for college students and the percent idea to show how close you are to reach your goal seems to me like it will be a motivation to get your goal complete.

This is a nice unifying solution, I like how it supports, connects, gives funding, and celebrates start-ups all at once!I think you identify well that the role of EC in this is mostly dealing with legal issues (patents etc.) and how the community can make things go viral. I also asked this to David Pinto of eco^2, do you think it needs a centralized location for meetings and coworking?

Thanks for the support, David! Anyway, I don't think that online start-ups necessarily need a physical meeting place, although I would prefer it. The team network can allow huddles through skype and/or instant messaging to tackle work. Phones may prove helpful as well, obviously. However, the option to work with people who live somewhat near you is there and it would be interesting to see some trends along the lines of what people prefer. I'm thinking about refining the search details to automatically include a second column that lists the best matches in a member's area. Maybe some teams will have two people from Wisconsin, two people from Tokyo, two people from England, etc...How great would that be for the world? What are some pros and cons to such a team?

comments.text: Hey Evan, great points! Glad to have you and your classmates along for our efforts. In the Concepting phase, let's take some of these insights and use them to create new ideas that can help entrepreneurs. Your points about web design are important: what concepts can you add that offer opportunities for people to learn these skills?

"Web Design for Dummies," referred to me by my boss also helped me understand the basics of web design. A concept I can offer from Jake's teachings, books and my own experience working with a start-up company is keep it simple. Big ideas should be transferred to the visitor quickly and concisely which doesn't always involve a lot of code. For web entrepreneurs getting the viewer (to the bottom of the funnel as Jake would put it) or to the call to action quickly is crucial because time is $! Web entrepreneurs should think simple and about the user experience when coding or designing a site is a concept suggestion. Hope this helps, thanks for the comment!
Have you explored Codecademy? Offers free interactive and simple lessons to coding! http://www.codecademy.com/#!/exercises/0

I love the idea, but I think it's limited. You're assuming that a web entrepreneur doesn't need extensive code; that big ideas and extensive coding knowledge go hand in hand. I'm in the media business and I've seen too many of my brethren invest a lot of money in contact management systems that end up not doing exactly what they envision. That's a barrier to a start-up. How can we make that barrier come down?
