ted_positive_sharing_failure.description: Let's learn from other people's mistakes and create an event where other people's failure is praised. Why reinvent the wheel? A fun, engaging set of speakers could help new start-ups proceed quickly.
ted_positive_sharing_failure.creator: 8e84dcee4c3a16638492d06cd11ca88f

comments.text: Awesome idea, Louise!  I know it would be helpful to many of my friends working on their own start-ups.  It can be a bit difficult to get people to share their failures in meet-ups, but if some brave souls would step forward and tell their stories, it would set a great example.  Perhaps you could partner with some of the incubator programs out there(TechStars, YCombinator, etc) as well.  I would imagine those programs could tell you about the trends in failures as well--what the common mistakes are and how to avoid them.  Since they have seen breadth of entrepreneuers,their lessons learned should resonate well to a larger audience.As for venues, I know some companies set aside a week for their employees to work on their own projects, called Hack Week or something similar.  As long as the speaker makes it more of an inspiring talk rather than a depressing one, you might ask such companies to offer space to hosts talks to kick off or end their hack week--helping their employees take their ideas to market.

I hadn't thought about partnering with one of the incubator programs but as a few of them are part of this challenge, they are a good place to start! I like the idea of introducing the talks before/after a hack week. It could act as a great source of inspiration for people working on their own projects.ALL talks MUST be inspiring - depressing talks will not be allowed ;-)

Took a class at LSE summer school in Entrepreneurship last summer and think it would good to get in touch with Fei from LSE. They talked about failure too. http://www2.lse.ac.uk/management/people/fqin.aspx
Thanks, James. Do you know Fei to be able to connect us?
Not really, her email is on page above f.qin1@lse.ac.uk I'll email her and cc you.
Hi Louise, I made you a logo while in the Chunnel :)https://skitch.com/prototypechan/edeae/failtales

I love the concept and think that it is absolutely something that should be examined, but can we shift the focus from 'failure' to 'lessons learned' or something less emotionally charged? Around the world, people consistently say 'the reason we here in X country don't have our own Silicon Valley because we have a low cultural tolerance for failure'.  To me, a huge part of the problem is not the concept, but the term 'failure', which I don't think is that accurate: if you learned something, it's not really a failure. If you built skills or bettered your chances of getting funding for another venture, it's not really a failure.I heard a great story once: an entrepreneur coach gave a talk in China that was translated. Periodically, about 1/4 of the audience would giggle for apparently no reason. Afterwards she discovered that every time she said the word 'failure', it was translated as 'work harder', because of the shame associated with the word failure. Only the bilingual audience members understood the mistranslation, and they thought it was hysterical. So I support failure bootcamps but can we rebrand them to overcome cultural resistance?.

Congratulations on sharing a winning concept! The EC recognises cultural fear of failure as one of the biggest challenges start-ups face, and is excited to support celebration of entrepreneurs who have tried  and learned! Theyre also excited by your early prototyping efforts and look forward to the first event.

Congratulations again Louise - you come up with some really fascinating concepts. I'm sorry I didn't take the time to contribute earlier I was heavily involved in another concept. However, better late than never I guess - just a quick suggestion and a few links that might be of interest.I agree the connotations of using 'war' in titles may produce a mixed reaction - perhaps, in keeping with the nautical flavour of some of the posts, something along the lines of 'weathering storms' might prompt thinking on a series title.I heard a brief interview with Richard Saul Wurman that you might find interesting ( http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/bydesign/the-conversation---richard-saul-wurman/4014516 )  and in conjunction with the recent TedXSydney (but possibly less relevant) (  http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/commonknowledge/robots2c-the-expanding-universe-and-weeds/4031366  &  http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/commonknowledge/bees2c-aussie-words-and-a-big-philosophy/4031388  ) which feature interviews with speakers at the event (as well as parts of the talks themselves).Best of luck with developing your events - and sad I'm at the other end of the world.

I love this idea!  Failure is such a great teacher.I want to come back to something mentioned earlier in the discussion, which is the idea of having different disciplines involved.  I think that rather than creating different nights for people interested in similar disciplines -- architecture -- the idea Louise puts forward of having speakers from 3 different disciplines each night would be great.  It's important not to underestimate the power of lateral and associative thinking -- so that someone's story from a project completely unlike mine might teach me something, or spark an unexpected idea.  I also think that there is a temporal aspect to failure.  Depending on when the experience happened relative to the story, the story about it will change.  Put another way, there is "digested" failure, which will be people telling stories of a failure and what they learned from it; but there is also possibly an opportunity for people to talk about "undigested" failure, allowing someone in the midst of a problem to seek solutions.  I wonder if there would be a way to allow the audience to problem solve.

A great proposal Louise. Most web start ups actually end in 'failure' but with founders and staff who have huge potential to succeed next time around and with important lessons to pass on.However, knowing the pitfalls and traps is only part of the solution. Speaking as someone who has failed, I sometimes knew I was making a mistake but couldn't find or afford the 'hands on deck' to turn it around. Here's a suggestion for TED+You could invite three groups: the experienced entrepreneurs passing on lessons, the new founders and a third group- specialists - who could be freelancers, graduates or post grad students looking for placements or internships. After the talks, the new founders could publicly identify one or two problem areas they most anticipate. The 'specialists' could then approach them with offers of help.You end up with a process of1. Inspiration and wisdom from the speakers2. Reflection and identification of potential problems by the founders3. Offer of help from a 'service community' of suppliers and interns.
Fab build, Tim.
Kudos Tim. I'm currently finding myself in group 2, so I can see how I'd love to attend such an event and benefit from it.

Awesome idea -- this is something that should go worldwide. One interesting twist you could put on the "failure" series is look for speakers who failed once, realized what they did wrong, and THEN succeeded.Oftentimes, people aren't able to correctly identify the reasons why they failed, despite the cliche that "hindsight is 20/20". That is, speculation on why one failed is usually just that: speculation. Focusing on those who have succeeded in spite of prior failure -- or, indeed, because of it -- should definitely be a focus for this reason.

I want to prototype this concept and have a venue to hold it in... Who in London wants to help out? Needs a planning session, think about potential speakers and help advertising. A website would be great too if anyone has time/the skills...!
I'd love to. But I will have to contribute from Copenhagen.

Way to go, Louise! And as you think about how to spread beyond London  you might like to check out Swiss Miss' Creative Mornings model: http://www.creativemornings.com/ That could *eventually* provide a way of allowing Carl & others take the goodness further. But fully support your idea to start locally  great way to prototype.
Great idea Louise. Happy to help where I can.

Thanks Carl, Meena and Amy, all help will be appreciated. I've been doing research into running a TEDx and it will need 'negotiating' or amending if this concept is to be a TED event (is this essential?!) 'Theme names: Generally, we will not approve theme-based names (e.g., "TEDxMarketing" or "TEDxEducation"). We will not approve any location-based name with a theme or vertical added to it (e.g., "TEDxSydneyDesign" or "TEDxNewYorkSpace"). You may give your event program a theme ("Revolutionary Ideas"), but the name of your TEDx event (appearing on your logo, website, etc.) must be the standard location-based name.'I want to prototype it initially away from the TED name to see how it could work and then approach TED with an ironed out proposal. I'd love help with the following:-  Brainstorming the developed concept idea I have (which I'll update shortly)- Plan a series of events (looking at maybe 5 to start)- find a host for each event- find 2-3 speakers for each event- find a speaker from abroad who will pre-record their talk - help market the event

I love the concept, Louise! If there's a good talk series, I'm there. Would love to help where I can, with the caveat, I might not have much brain space / actual time until June. What's the timeframe we're looking at for your prototype?If you want a TEDx location ... I've been thinking there should be a TEDxClerkenwell -- a TEDx name can be for a series of events, right? The area is so varied, that there could a rotation of events for startups, for interior designers, for architects, for craftspeople -- though ideally we could get them to all interact!Lots of available conference rooms, large restaurants and showrooms for potential venues. For instance, there was a GLUG event held at he club fabric a couple of months ago. Will have a think about the other points you'd like help with!
I agree, Louise  it might be easier to prototype away from the TED name due to various constraints. You can count on the OpenIDEO team to help promote any events you get going!

Joining the conversation a bit late but I like the idea... maybe rather than failures (to attract speakers) you could call it war stories. I remember reading the work by Julian Orr on war stories shared by Xerox technicians. I agree that maybe moving away from the TED name (even though it had also value) could help. Maybe you could also try variations - some more informal and some with maybe one or two big names. As for locations, if I could help from NY, I would... How big are you imagining the first events to be?

Thanks for all the comments, everyone.To answer a few questions before updating the concept, I am suggesting to prototype this in a local, London bar away from the TED name. I think it's important to allow the prototype to be flexible and fluid to see what does and doesn't work. The venue can hold about 100 people although I'm sure that a fraction of that would turn up!@Charlene, I love the idea of having different 'disciplines' involved and think this is important anyway. I see each event having 3 speakers - one from the tech start-up world, one from a completely different discipline and one videoing in from another country.I'm wondering if the last Monday of the month might be a good time to host the events. The last one of June is looking more realistic.@AL Agree that war stories is a good angle for the type of event but i'd like to find a name that is more inspiring. The idea of connecting the event with 'war' (some people may take it literally) might prevent some people coming along. a good name and logo are important. @AL and Carl, tt would be great if you could think of some NY/Copenhagen based people who would record their talk for us. They could be included via video link with the live speakers!

Thanks for the long and thoughtful reply. I love the idea of a flexible local bar. Being able to be flexible and fluid is indeed key. I agree that war stories is not necessarily the most inspiring name but is failure really inspiring? :-) I guess war stories in the context of the technicians made sense but I'm sure there might an inspiring word in the context of entrepreneurs. My main point was indeed to find something that will refer to difficult situations but in an inspiring way. I agree that "war stories" was not necessarily the best alternative. I will try to see if I can think of someone for a talk to be recorded. If you can have a short "brief" / invitation for the speaker that can help. Are you looking for web entrepreneurs only?  to be continued.

Great dialogue, guys. I just noted on the start-up annual concept that one version of that could be a capture of the stories that come out of this event. http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/the-start-up-annual/ Sounds like a smart move to step away from TED at the moment - let's get it right then worry about fitting with them later (ah, they'll be knocking at our door!). Love the debate on wording. Whatever we decide, I think we want to be pretty clear that this is about celebrating failure. We're trying to break away from the stereotype that failing is bad. I just saw this great quote on the Startup America home page: "Entrepreneurs learn more falling down stairs than up." - Scott Case, CEO,  Startup America Partnership.  They go on to ask people to tell how failures led to successes. I think we don't even need to go that far... we can just ask for learnings.I've got a couple of people I might be able to persuade to share their stories, so as we get closer I'll drop them a line...
Link to startup america: http://www.s.co/

I know I'm a little late in the conversation, but If i can help with something I'm all ears.  Right know i'm in Colombia ( my home country) , but i'm expecting to travel to London in september to start a MA . So I'll be happy to help. :)
excellent, thanks Natalia. Hopefully the concept will have developed on loads by September and you'll be here just in time to help with the talk series! Let us know when you're here.

Louise, I haven't had a chance to think of speakers but once you have some dates, I can definitely start looking for someone which we could videotape for one of your events. I guess that you could even try something live but it might add too much complexity...

I support the concept as well.  TED seems fairly eager to partner with other groups especially if they are doing the majority of the coordination.  The costs associated with the idea are small especially if people are willing to make space donations.  Most often we hear about small failures before stories of inordinate success.   It would refreshing to hear a more realistic set of speakers discussing the varying degrees of failure they were met with.

Agree, Nicole. I'd like to see three speakers each event - one could be from a large, now successful company, one could be from a small, still starting up company (or starting out again) and one could be from a different country (via video) where failure has a different meaning.

I like the concept, I think their is too much hype about how such and such with no money turned overnight millionaire or started a successful company. Very few highlight the long periods of limited success or out right failure that many endured. The question is even if you get notable person to speak of past failures this will this motivate others to speak of their current failure? I mean it is easy to speak of a past failure when you are currently successful. Perhaps incorporating some sort of anonymity into the process would allow one currently facing failure the ability to reach out for help without exposing their weaknesses to potential investors, clients, or their competition.

Good point, Joshua. This is why I feel a themed series is a good idea to try. We need to get a range of views, a group of insightful people and enough engaging stories that people understand what failure can mean to different companies. I don't think we need 'detail' as such which means that the talk can be anonomous in some sense...
Check out this ship: Semester at Sea + Unreasonable Institute + Stanford D.School http://unreasonableatsea.com/

your pointer made me wonder what actually would be a good place   to stimulate a discussion about failure: a ship, a hulk, an architectural blunder, a traffic island, an institution, ...?  anyhow, in accordance with the suggestion from louise to use the ted format + london, i can't resist to suggest: the best place might be the banking district, where failure and success take turns with enormous speed. every day you can pick a new candidate.

interesting idea Mariann. Hopefully the prototypes will help confirm where the event should take place but the city is definitely worth thinking about. It will depend on whether the concept stays with the tech start up world or moves to any type of start up...
you might consider to get in contact with the people from  thefailcon.com,  coming up again in octubre, interesting speaker list.
thanks Mariann!
Two videosLarry Smith Why you will Fail to have a Great Career!http://www.ted.com/talks/larry_smith_why_you_will_fail_to_have_a_great_career.htmlStartup Stories: Failurehttp://vimeo.com/41871291

I really like the idea of a TED talk format. Not sure on the focus and angle of event though. Failure (just like success) have a context. What was a failure for me in my context and with my networks and talents might not be yours. So, to make these conversations useful, the event might best be framed as: (1) examining key decision points in start ups; (2) big insights; and (3) strategies to navigate the journey.
a nice visual for failure, yet the founders and copycat business model is still considered as success, at least in germany. why? http://wannstirbtstudivz.com/

good idea. being allowed to fail is a concept not to be underestimated, as it allows a step backward in order to see the path forward. it is another word of saying: lessons learned, an exercise too often ignored. especially in europe in regard to start ups, but also in regard to politics. what europe needs is to allow failure, as we do make failure all the time. what about proposal that dont get accepted, what about proposals that financial basis are cut off after two years? in the final report the latter will be sold as a success story. in reality they failed. another case study: successful projects who are developed in europe but realized over the atlantic will be named a failure in/for europe but a success story overseas. rightly so? i dare to say no. we are at this point too often asking ourselves: did we fail? but we dont talk about it. we are afraid. can talking about failures change our notion?  can it lead to more self-confidence within europe? this, imho, should be the outline of your endeavor, to make a difference. if it is just an exercise of best practice turned around 180, it wouldnt open up new doors for perception.  so my question after this rambling is the following, and very basic: how do you define failure?

Good question, Mariann! I don't think this need to be defined too carefully though. The point of the talks is to let other learn and share stories. One person's failure may not be significant to someone else but it may plant a seed or spark a conversation. James' rules to live by: http://www.inc.com/geoffrey-james/turn-failure-into-success-10-ways.html is an interesting starting point - I'd like to see if we can create a 'set of rules' to get the speakers to base their stories around. The stories will need to be carefully chosen but that's what the prototype phase is for ;-)

well, some have been there already. in the european society we face some strange aspects in regard to "failure", we even have a law that warns us not to "fail":>as far as i am concerned and at least in some european countries (keyword insolvency) you may face a ban from your occupation, if you went into bankruptcy. so the notion not to fail in europe has a different  flavor compared to the usa. (don't know about britain, though)   > banks and loans: how difficult is it in europe to convince a bank after you failed?>society: not to talk about the "dark" site of life or risks  (circle closed, feeds into laws and regulations and policy). for the latter we have an insurance by hand, how cynic.james' 10 points sound nice, but we don't have the right parameter around to go for it yet, i fear. a lawyer might be of help? ...  [and no, they don't have to be boring  and spoil the party :)]not sure if you want to go into this, but  it might be interesting to consider that there is more than one part to the story.

The advisory panel loved this idea, and suggested you take a look at Failboat ( http://www.meetup.com/Failboat-London/events/55509652/ ) for inspiration. We'd love to see you take steps to get this started!Swing by our Web Start-up Challenge Refinement Phase Announcement: http://bit.ly/startup-shortlist + the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine for more tips!

Thanks for pointing me towards Failboat. Very similar idea and clearly a successful one. I like the way they describe themselves:'...Sure, we all enjoy celebrating other entrepreneur's successes, whether they have achieved epic growth, closed seed rounds or raise VC, but were all far too ashamed of the bad days. Failboat London is here to fix that.If one of the keys to startup success lies in validated learning, then we should be proud of our failures, sharing them with one another and growing a stronger, more agile ecosystem....Hear tales of woe from some of Londons startup all-stars, share your own, learn together and lets move forward as a team.If youve truly cocked up we may even let you present!'

From Failboat: Would have loved to hear Dan Hill speak on why Crashpadder failed to get to level of AirBnb. I met him just before the Airbnb buy and was a very interesting conversation.Would be great to combine Failboat with Summit series on a boat!http://sea.summitseries.com/
Definitely! I wonder how many of the attendees we could get to come to this series.....!!
Really really nice idea! we learn most from our mistakes!Check out this TED talk about NGOs and failure:http://www.ted.com/talks/david_damberger_what_happens_when_an_ngo_admits_failure.html

Wow, Stefan! What a moving TED talk - everyone should walk this! It's so interesting to see just how important he feels talking about failure is, especially when he discovered he'd made the same mistake he had already identified previously. This talk confirms the importance of creating TED+. Thank you!

I'm a big fan of this one. Very fitting for this awesome idea: Brene Brown on Listening to Shame "You know what the big secret about TED is?...This is like the failure conference...You know why this place is amazing? Because very few people here are afraid to fail." http://www.ted.com/talks/brene_brown_listening_to_shame.html
Thanks Danielle, I'll have a listen

Another quote in favour of failure: "Failure is a good option. I think we have a notion, especially in British culture, that its terrible to fail, which stunts a lot of growth and a lot of potential in young people. http://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/europe/uk/london/9175811/Made-In-London-the-capitals-boom-in-entrepreneurship.html
interesting article, Charlene, thanks for sharing. It's good to see honest stories of failure being shared, especially in the tech world.
Fun example of a (non-web) start-up learning from a web start-up failure, and creating a new business out of it: http://www.kivasystems.com/ecommerce/ - click on the video about Webvan
Realised I never replied, Amy. It's good to hear examples of all types of start ups. Learning about business models in general is really useful. Thamks for sharing.

wow, very inspiring! I think as a start-up, the most attractive thing would be hearing experience and stories from other entrepreneurs! this is the best way to get an image , ideas and suggestions! wonderful!

Love it Louise! Here's a quick build for you to consider: what if, in the spirit of making this a slightly different TED experience, there was an opportunity for the entrepreneurs in the audience to take these lessons about failure and apply them to their work? For instance, after a speaker tells his or her story, what if there were some sort of interactive or facilitated debrief that helped the audience understand how the latest lesson applies to their efforts? That way it's actually part speaker series, part applied workshop. It makes things a bit more complicated, but it also helps the founders make clear connections between other people's stories and their own work. What do you think?

Ashley, I agree with you, this is an awesome idea.  Your suggestion about audience participation is great because it gives you instant feedback and you are able to see where you can enhance and what you can eliminate in addition to being offered a variety of options.

Oooh, good thoughts ladies. I wonder if a summary of each start-ups challenges could be sent to the speakers before hand so that the speaker could prepare their talk to suit the start-ups....or if there could be a Q&A at the end of each TED for the start-ups to explain where they are.... Let me have more of a think! Definitely a fantastic build coming, thanks.
Fab collaboration  looking forward to builds on this fab idea!

I actually chuckled reading this - kind of celebrating failure (well, valuing it at least!), what a fantastic idea. So often we want to hear what a single successful individual did right (which is fine) but there is so much to be learnt from the many who have experienced failure. Love this concept.Extending a little on Ashley's suggestion of an applied workshop, it would be great if the speakers could be streamed and audience interactivity facilitated online to maximise reach.Consider also what the outputs of the events might look like (case studies, tools, channels for advice etc.) and how they might be packaged and distributed.  I'm thinking this would be particularly useful for university business/commerce/entrepreneurship faculty and students - perhaps partner with some universities to get it up and running?

Very good build Louise. TED is great platform. Specially younger generation following TED at such a great scale , this kind of TED extension will act as a great inspiration and learning resource for young entreprenuers.You can also look at these areas.1. How the TED speaker will be selected. All most all the companies ( including the startups) can have their yearly publication on experiences. They can share their success and failure ( or how situations could have been handled better ) stories with such a publication.2. Does some kind of correlation arise between similar stories. Can there be a panel discussion arranged among similar story owners.3. Can the pane discussion results and key insights/suggestions be archived is some form.

@Luc, the idea of streaming to an audience to maximise reach is essential - definitely a need build on this concept. thanks. Some kind of clever online tool to allow people to access the information needs to be worked out....@Jyotirmaya, selecting speakers is a good thing to be considered. The speakers MUST be engaging, useful and inspiring. It might be too easy to people who think they know best to get involved when actually it's the people who are more subtle about their successes/failures that we need to reach. Maybe a screening process is required. I'll have a look into how similar platforms screen their speakers.Your point about collecting results is similar to Luc's comment about an online tool.

Love the ideas, I think the topic is really important! A book on the subject was launched earlier this year in Finland called "The Hard Way", where 15 Finnish celebrities share their fail-stories. I'm working with a cultural festival that will be held in a couple of weeks, and we are having a guided workshop with the authors of this book where the audience will be writing a book about one of their failures in an hour, and will then get them actually printed to have for themselves :) There could be a template / set of questions available for people to start analyzing their mistakes and ending up with a document ("Fail Certificate?" that states how they have failed and what they have learnt from it!

Hi Jemina, is the festival taking place in Finland? Sounds like a great initiative. I agree about having a template to guide the talks and it ties in nicely with James' comments about Rules To Live By http://www.inc.com/geoffrey-james/turn-failure-into-success-10-ways.html I'll be incorporating this when I update the concept!

Yes, we're holding it in Helsinki this year, maybe later in other locations too! Also, not only the speakers but also people in the audience could receive a fun booklet/notebook with templates to fill in :) Keep up the great work developing the concept!

Please let me know if the event comes closer to the UK! Having something tangible to take away could be valuable - maybe not printed material but something physical to remind everyone to be open to failure.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thanks OpenIDEO!

Just came across this...http://www.inc.com/geoffrey-james/turn-failure-into-success-10-ways.htmlRules to Live By1. Failure renews my humility, sharpens my objectivity, and makes me more resilient.2. I take the challenge seriously, but I do not take myself too seriously.3. If the more I fail, the more I succeed, then failure is a part of the process of achieving my objectives.4. Failure is temporary when I use it as an opportunity to try new ideas.5. I learn more from failure than success.6. Negative feedback is information that helps me correct my course so that I stay on target.7. I am paid for the number of times I fail.8. My self-esteem is not based on the reactions of others, but by my own sense of virtue.9. The unkindness of others reminds me that I need to be kind to myself.10. It takes courage to failbecause nobody ever got ahead without taking risks.

Ah ha, this could make a great set of topics for creating your own 15 minute video for the prototype - choose one of the topics, record a 10-15minute explaining the positive learning from their failure, post it to YouTube and allow people to search through them.
Great collaboration guys  loving how this idea is evolving, together!

Great idea Louise, and I love the fact that you're leveraging something that already exists. I suspect you could apply to TED to organise a one off event (e.g., TEDxLearningFromFailure) and try it out, before scaling it to a series. In terms of an activity, it could be interesting to do a simple synthesis session at the end of the day where the themes are pulled out - what can we learn by putting together what we heard from all the speakers? What type of speakers might be most interesting? How would we define failure? Some of the inspirations you built on might be a great source of first speakers.

Thanks Amy, great insights. It would be really cool to get the people who visualise insights (similar to the RSA videos?) to draw the learnings for everyone to see straight away - always a great way to quickly see the best picks.

I will be at TEDxSummit in Doha next week with 700+ tedxorganisers and TED staff. I do know TEDx do not like to give licenses out that are not location specific i.e. TEDxLondon or TEDxKingston. However it could be encouraged to link themes together, that Failure which is well discussed anyway becomes a connected theme from various location events....Also see IQ2 (Squared) Shorts videos.
although TEDxLicenses have been given out in past for theme names, they don't seem to like it.

interesting to know, James. It doesn't mean we couldn't create a similar lecture series but give it a different name and change the format slightly. I'm thinking about how we could prototype it quickly - encourage some entrepreneurs to video themselves giving a message about a failure of theirs and post them to a site like YouTube for people to comment on. We could therefore understand what format people find interesting and discover how explaining failure is best done...

I just found this video and piece on 'the wisdom of failure' - worth a read/watch for those interested in this concept. 'So many times the possibility of failure paralyzes us, making one incapable of daring to think big or act boldly. Its critical to realize that we all will inevitably face failure, even the best and brightest do, but its how you deal with such moments that are important.'http://www.echoinggreen.org/blog/the-wisdom-of-failure
Louise, this is an awesome idea.  How can we help you to get TED to agree to this new series?
Interesting question. Let me (with everyone else) build on the idea properly then we can approach them with an awesome idea they can't say no to ;-)
Perfect!

comments.text: A safe environment in which to test and develop ideas without fear of intellectual property theft would be very useful: it's not disimilar to the academic environment where researchers are free to bounce ideas off each other (to a point).I can easily imagine an online community based around a forum, but also conferences and meetups where people can get together and intensively work on their ideas. To work though, I think people would really have to trust that they were safe, and that means the group has to have the power to punish transgressors. A small membership fee could be used to fund a litigation pool, perhaps?

I think this might be (sadly) necessary, but it's also about a pervasive culture of trust, and that is about consistently reinforcing the beliefs that the idea is based on.  A combination of a fanatical culture (a la Zappos) and an easy way to filter out those that don't adhere to those beliefs (interview process, referrals, etc) would hopefully minimize the likelihood of using said funds.  :)
Great analogous thinking, Matt  we're big fans: http://bit.ly/oi_analogous

zaplings_proposes_a_new_model_of_innovat.description: Too many great ideas do not succeed because too few people have the connections and resources to make them happen. Zaplings helps level the playing field for innovators and brings great ideas to life.
zaplings_proposes_a_new_model_of_innovat.creator: 43747ab892a17de5fd79ff866e147d34

comments.text: I'm pretty impressed with this idea, but I was wondering...  Do you think Zaplings would offer some sort of legal advice/feedback to help entrepreneurs navigate the complex legal consequences of starting their business or startup?  I guess I'm concerned with things like intellectual property rights, tax implications, business incorporation/organization questions, financial regulations or restrictions... there are a lot of things that entrepreneurs will need to hammer out before they can get moving.  At least... they ought to hammer these things out to prevent disputes or other problems down the road.I guess my question is, do you think Zaplings would have a legal help department or "tool" built right in?  Or do you think it would be better for attorneys to join Zaplings and offer their services much like Kathleen (the graphic designer below) would offer up her graphic design expertise to an entrepreneur in need?

Zibi, thank you for asking such an insightful and thoughtful question! You're right, there's a LOT of legal issues that startups need to consider, and I think sometimes idea people don't think enough about them early enough.There's a couple ways we plan to address the legal issues. First, as you alluded to, we want lawyers to be included in our community. The legal profession can be incredibly fulfilling or soul sucking, depending on your field, and for those in the latter category, perhaps helping startups get off the ground is just the job therapy they require!Second, we will utilize LegalZoom's affiliate program. If you're not aware of it, LegalZoom is an awesome online resource that simplifies and streamlines the process for addressing just about any issue a startup may face. From applying for patents to drafting contracts, LegalZoom is an incredibly valuable resource for entrepreneurs. Better yet, when users we've referred pay for their services, LegalZoom pays us!

Check out the Community Economic Development Lawyers model from the Boston, MD area Community Law Center: It was founded by a Skadden Fellowshiphttp://communitylaw.org/http://www.wcl.american.edu/clinical/community.cfmhttp://www.bc.edu/schools/law/services/studentorgs/ced.html
Danny that's awesome! We should totally partner with a community law organization or multiple ones. And I should get in touch with someone from American U before I head out to Austin!

Cool idea, Dan! I could see a lot of people getting really into this. Is it just for entrepreneurs, though? For example, I'm a graphic designer and not really interested in starting my own company (not yet, at least). Does it make sense for me to join Zaplings?

Awesome question, Kathleen! The answer is yes, Zaplings is absolutely for you! You have a skill that many idea people don't possess themselves and don't have connection to. We want to connect you with innovators who share your passions and who have ideas you will be excited about. You will be more likely to lend a helping hand to one of these zaplings (each idea is a "zapling", by the way) than you would to an idea you were not passionate about.Not everyone is an entrepreneur- it can be a very intimidating and risky choice to make- but just about everyone has something to offer. We want people with all sorts of skills and passions from all over the world to come to Zaplings and participating in bringing great ideas to life!

This does indeed look an interesting possibility for improving the way in which ideas are supported. However the fear of having ideas stolen is both real and rational. There is some question about the patent-ability of ideas but where the prospect of patent arises there is an initial step that represents a barrier often beyond the reach of start-up and incubator assistance.

You're right, Paul, idea theft is a legitimate concern, and there are no ways to guarantee propriety. It is important, then, to mitigate the risk of an idea being stolen. To this end, Zaplings will help in a couple ways. First, ideas stay private until you make them public. You can invite trusted members of your own network as well as users outside your network. It's up to you how much you share with each contributor.Second, we will offer an electronic non-disclosure agreement, which a producer may choose to require before sharing information with a contributor.Third, Zaplings will keep records of all information passed between producer and contributor. That includes recording who visited what page. If a producer invites a contributor to a private idea page, the contributor views that page, then turns around and takes the idea for themselves, Zaplings will record of those events, which would be admissible as evidence in a dispute.Thank you for your comments! Do you think you'd feel comfortable developing an idea with Zaplings?

Thanks for the feedback Dan. These elements you have described would form a useful template for some of the other concepts here and I shall refer them to this thread.I realise from reading this that Zaplings is an existing platform. Yes I think I would feel comfortable.if I had an appropriate idea - at the moment most of my ideas either need the full protection of patent or are shared openly.

Thanks so much for passing on the word! Glad to hear our concept is something you envision using yourself. However, I can't claim that it's an existing platform. We are very much in the process of creating it, but we are very interested in getting input from others to shape where we go from here. If you're interested in participating further, it would be great if you could submit your email on our site. We will only use it to notify you when the beta test is ready. We look forward to continuing the discussion!
this idea rocks!  i met a homeless guy in austin for whom it could be really useful - he had a great idea for game but no one to do manufacturing, marketing, etc.
Yeah, thanks for telling us about this guy! It would be an awesome success story, I'm going to try and meet up with him when I move down there!

If anyone is interested, the guy Rachel is talking about invented 3M Chess - www.3mchess.com. He invented it in 1988, but I bet with our help he could take it farther in 6 months than he has in 24 years!!

I think this idea is great.  This is a model that many people have tried, but have not succeeded at.  I give this project all the credit in the world, and I'm sure the team has a great vision for this product.  Kick ass!
Thanks, Sam!

Exciting times, Dan. Given we have 3 weeks left in the Concepting phase in which to evolve ideas  it might be great to think about specific challenges for European entrepreneurs and how Zaplings might help to meet some of these. Looking forward to input and discussion with our OpenIDEO community here  and to see you chiming in on others' ideas.

Thanks Meena! The key challenge we see is that too few people have the connections they need to bring their great idea to life. This is true everywhere - Europe, the US, the developing world. Put another way, innovation favors the upper classes, who know others in the upper classes and have access to their networks and resources. We believe that anyone with a great idea deserves a chance to make it a reality.Every idea starts with a passion, and every idea needs people with certain expertise to grow. No one has all the expertise to do everything on their own, so it's critical to form strong partnerships. The key is to find people with the right passion and right expertise to take the idea to the next level. You want people who are excited about the objective and who will be willing to invest and sacrifice to see it to fruition.Finally, it may seem like we are pretty far along in development to be considered relevant to the Concepting phase. To clarify, we have only just begun development of the website, and we have yet to seek funding. We have yet to even decide how we will accomplish many of our objectives, so we would love to get input on how to achieve them. We have our sights very clearly set on the problem at hand, but the whole solution is not so evident. To attract the network we seek, we need to provide real value to our community, and this is a perfect forum with which to hone the value proposition.Excited to hear what you all think!
Fantastic idea; would be a great resource for ventures looking for funding and beyond.

Justin,Thank you for telling me about this.  You are definitely on to something with this idea. I really believe that this could turn in to a platform that could do lots of great things for people who would not normally be able to bring their ideas to life.I wish you guys the best and I am looking forward to using your website.Tiffany

Tiffany,You're welcome, thank you too! Please make sure to submit your email address on our homepage for updates. Feel free to also submit an idea if you would like to be one of the first people to participate in our beta testing when it begins.  Justin

Web Entrepreneurs face a big challenge in getting local, on the ground support to help them raise a platform, idea, or movement. I'd be interested to see how you use the GetUpp app, http://www.getupp.com/, which helps people get motivated through peer review and social networks (okay, let's be honest, this is on-line peer pressure and it's great). Maybe you can think about helping web entrepreneurs build on the ground capacity through a mix of technology and social capital like this. -danny

Thanks Danny, I hadn't heard of the GetUpp app, looks interesting. I like how broadly you're thinking about how we can help innovators make progress with their ideas. GetUpp focuses on increasing motivation and productivity, and Zaplings can definitely be a part of that. One tool we'd like to develop eventually would combine the functionality of Self Control (http://visitsteve.com/made/selfcontrol/) with a scheduler. Self Control allows you to block time-wasting websites for a set period of time. Adding a scheduler to this would allow you to set recurring times when you wanted to focus on a particular task.One challenge with GetUpp is that it's limited to location-based commitments, such as going to the gym. Many entrepreneurial tasks such as writing a business plan are not location-specific. If GetUpp could expand their model to handle more types of commitments, we may recommend the app to the Zaplings community.

Hey Dan, I think this is a great idea to enable a better environment for entrepreneurs, or level the playing field as you call it. It seems like everyone has had the experience of struggling with a problem/question on ones own and has seen how beneficial exchange with others can be in order to find a creative and sustainable solution, even more so when this requires a wide set of resources and expertise. One of the challenges I see is how you will create the network of people with the necessary skills and knowledge, but since youre not limiting your platform to a specific set of projects or ideas I can imagine that you will be able to appeal to a very diverse crowd of people. So if you do manage to attract creative contributors in the first place, they could probably benefit a lot from each others different backgrounds and respective networks.

Agree with your thoughts, Marieke. The great thing about the start-up world is that news tends to travel fast. I'm sure that once a few creative contributors have got on board that it will have a tumble weed effect. Having a varied set of backgrounds would be really appealing to a range of people.

Growing the network is definitely going to be the hardest part. First, we have to convince idea people that we have something valuable for them, that they should grow their idea with us. In the beginning, the network won't be so well established so this may be a challenge.Second, we need to show contributors how they will benefit from helping ideas thrive. One way would be to form equity partnerships. Another would be to build up a portfolio of activity that would attract other innovators to employ you.Any other ideas of how to provide value to these two groups? Lots of the concepts posted could definitely apply...

have_a_designer_as_a_founder.creator: 8e84dcee4c3a16638492d06cd11ca88f

comments.text: Though you might find this interesting from this week's Fast Company: http://www.fastcodesign.com/1669544/what-both-mbas-and-mfas-get-wrong-about-solving-business-problems
Oops! I meant "thought you might find this interesting" not "though" Damn slippery iPad keyboard!

Hi Louise.Thank you for this inspiration! I believe having a Designer as Founder is key as it not only helps keeping quality and consistency into a project, but also helps saving money (good design is expensive) and helps adapting to changes (start-up needs to be flexible to easily adapt to what customers want or to what is possible to 'build' in a certain time-frame). Also designers always try to innovate and think about ways to improve a product/service (which is also the reason why probably 'designers' should not be the only founders as otherwise they will never launch a product on the market!).At the moment I'm working on my first web start-up, Buddy Bounce, and I can say that, if I wasnt the Founder, I would have never been able to reach the quality the product have today without asking for investment (and a big one).To try to make design more affordable, over the past 2 years I also worked as Design Coach with a few start-ups that didnt have design in house.  My experience so far showed me that Designers are really important to help start-ups clarifying their mission, getting to know their customers, innovating within their offering (too often start-ups focus on features rather than benefits) and can also help visualising an idea quickly so that it can be tested in front of potential customers. This speed up the validation process too.I came up with the idea of 'Design Coaching' as I wanted to help start-up understand the value design can have for their businesses without asking them for a massive investment. Unfortunately start-ups usually try to cut on design, thinking that an un-experienced and un-paid intern could do the job without any support (or that they can do the design themselves!). Also, often start-up founders with no design background believe design is just about colouring suff and that research only means 'quantitative market research' (which I consider a waste of money for a start-up), whilst they don't know how valuable qualitative research methods can be for them to understand their customers and spot opportunities in a really short amount of time. Having Designers as  coaches could help start-up improving their products/services but could also 'teach' them the value and complexity of design (so that they may invest on that as soon as they have the money for it).If you are interested in my idea of 'Design Coaching' here is my presentation on that topic: http://www.slideshare.net/giuliapiu/piu-guerra-openservicedesign . At the bottom of the deck you could also see an example of how my coaching with a start-up, Meetphool, helped them to transform a web product with no clear purpose, into something that is speaking to an audience (and the founder of Meetphool did everything on her own, I only guided her for 3 days!)Looking forward to hearing your comments!
design coaching sounds very interesting~and I truly agree with having a designer as a founder is necessary~good job
Good point, Louise. I think that getting different perspectives to turn an idea into something great is very important.

definitely needs a multi-disciplinary team but having a designer as the founder is very thought provoking. Would be interesting to interview start-ups and discover what discipline their founder is....

Interesting thoughts. When I think of combining multi-disciplinary teams I always think of the final scene in The Breakfast Club where they learn that simply fitting the mold of what other people want and expect of them is severely limiting. (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sv1I4q6lOpo) How might having a design as a founder be different? What results does that yield?  Real power comes from stepping outside that expectation and using the acquired skills to produce results instead just playing the role.Like it!

I think that just as in The Breakfast Club (you should get DQ points for referring to that classic by the way), a team existing of different characters can help in stepping out of that expectation of the mold.

Oh, by the way, for future reference links in comments are only recognised by the system if they're surrounded by spaces. Like this http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sv1I4q6lOpo and because it's such a brilliant reference, I copied it here :).
Provocative conversation you've started here, Louise  just the way we like it! ;^)

Love the idea that is underlying this - starting up a company is a hands-on job. Thinking of other inspirations I've seen, I wonder how many shared work spaces invite in a mix of folks to cross pollinate.

Cross pollination is really important but also hard to facilitate. I know from hearing stories from The Hub in Westminster (London) that people are really starting to talk and share skills. It's a bit like your Make-a-thon idea, Amy where people started to move around groups depending on their skill set. I went to an event at NESTA last year where people posted their business cards on a wall and you could draw links to show how you could help or collaborate with each other... I feel another inspiration coming on!!
Hello, I read this article today and it reminded me of your post! http://www.fastcompany.com/magazine/164/designing-facebook

Thank you for sharing this article, Bassem. It was this bit 'Facebook doesn't just want to catalyze interactions. It wants to catalyze emotions. It wants you to have the same feelings--the positive ones at least--that you have when you cuddle up to friends and family in person' that I see as being important - having a designer on board means you're more likely to have design thinking incorporated and therefore empathy with the end user!

This resonates a lot with my experience. The lesson I learnt was that you need people with a stake in the business who can help you iterate quickly and continually. That may be a designer or a developer. Outsourcing this function inhibits your responsiveness to customer feedback, even if the quality you get is better. Start ups are also less in need of a highly experienced chairperson, something which VCs are always keen to add.  Speed, responsiveness and customer relationship building trump wisdom and detailed planning. The need for that comes later.

Quick and continuous iterations are really important, Tim. Good to hear your personal experience on this subject. It's true that VCs want to add a chairperson - I very much believe in mentors (which a chairperson should be) but do feel that entrepreneurs can often get caught up in going by the book instead of being speedy... most would blame shortage in funds but hopefully some of the concepts will help resolve all of these issues ;-)

There are two ways to go with this.  First, if we would like every start-up have a designer as a founder, we need more designers.  :)  This needs to be pushed into the curriculum of the top business programs within their entrepreneurship tracks - where many a start-up founder spends some time.  Second, does the founder need to be a designer, or have access to designers willing to help them form their plan and consider the angles that design thinkers see that a typical entrepreneur would not?  How about a confidential, invite-only site where professional designers and design thinkers can provide feedback on business plans, UIs, usability, etc. for either a small fee or return business-focused feedback on their own projects?

Hi Matt, yes, good thoughts on the subject. It's more about being creative and understanding user centered design than NEEDING a designer. Design thinking opens up different methods and in my view, often leads to a successful, sustainable solution. It can be less ruthless, more thoughtful and appealing to the end user. I believe a designer is more likely to think about what the end user actually wants rather than assuming what they want.  I'd love to see a system where design thinkers can contribute to business plans etc but I really think they need to be part of the process all the way through....  I like your thinking though!
Hi Matt, have you read the article that Meena posted above? http://www.fastcodesign.com/1665120/designers-are-the-new-drivers-of-american-entrepreneurialism
It's below now ;^)

Suddenly remembered this article from my buddy Bruce over at Fast Company from a while back which I thought you'd be interested in Louise: http://www.fastcodesign.com/1665120/designers-are-the-new-drivers-of-american-entrepreneurialism

What a fantastic, thought provoking article, Meena! Thanks. Here are my take-aways:'One key to entrepreneurs success is that they frame things differently, they connect existing dots in unique ways' - are successful business men automatically entrepreneurs or does a business man need an entrepreneur working with him for a successful business?! This plays on my thoughts are creativity verses design....'We also need to know a lot more about meaning, not just the data gathered by ethnography but knowledge that takes us much deeper into understanding culture.....We need to know more about shared spectacle and why we crave it, and how honing craft and skill to near perfection can enable you to make and do the unique--which is what entrepreneurs do' - gaining empathy instead of just gathering data is soooo important! It's very easy for a business to take research figures literally instead of interpreting them into useful insights.

it_are_the_first_followers_that_sparks_a.description: Like the dancing guy, a start up has its own ideas on how to change its environment. But next to the dancing guy you need first followers to start a movement. They are the ones who positively refer you to others and adopt your concept.

Rob, this is potentially one of my *favorite* leadership videos of all time. Cheers for sharing it with us here :)
Hi Ashley, thnx for your reply and it is a great and inspiring video
Absolutely agreed.Love this video as well.Big changes/movements/impact involves & needs *leaders* of all types, not just those most visibly/typically recognized as such.
Yes, absolutely a favorite video. And a good lesson.

Agreed, what I like about this is the message that no one does anything alone. I think its an incredibly relevant message for start-ups, who are often founded by one person. Question: Do we think the second (and third, fourth, etc) person needs to officially be in the start-up? Or, could he or she be a mentor, or someone off which to bounce ideas?

I learned an important lesson from a serial entrepreneur; To get the startup baby flying you need to know how many manhours and specializations this takes from today onward. If you know this, than make those limited people equal shareholders, nomatter how many years and sweat you put in already. The question remains, how to 'convince' 'the dancing guy' to share equally the pie? And should the first follower not get more as without her dancing guy would not have gone global.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured inspiration!
Stellar inspiration! Can't wait to get my new moves on!
Three men make a tiger! - love it :)

comments.text: Absolutely - I love it!  STW Buzz

Provocative post Nima!In fact we've had a number of inspirations which involve education opportunities for entrepreneurs which sit outside of the university model. Here's a few but there have been many more:http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/apprenticeships-for-the-enterpreneurs-of-tomorrow/http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/breeding-entrepreneurs/http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/inspiration/project-m-think-wrong-to-do-right/So I think that many people out there are already answering *yes* to your question. However it seems that you have highlighted a tension here between desire to attain a university degree and 'wanting to take the road less travelled'. While we do hear of universities doing some amazing things around entrepreneurial training  we're also learning on this challenge that there are many other educational avenues for would-be entrepreneurs. Those wild horses certainly aren't short of options ;^)  and we hope that our community will be coming up with even more in the upcoming Concepting phase!

Very good point and I think with increase ubiquity of entrepreneurs, an ecosystem will emerge that will both support and benefit from these start-ups. It's important to recognize that the strength of big companies is their matured dependence in and on a ecosystem and their weakness is immature innovative thinking and that the strength of start-ups is their innovation and their weakness being too independent. I am certain that in time, both will continue to learn from one another for a perfect balance.
Sort of like the Thiel fellowship? http://www.thielfellowship.org/
Exactly Vincent. I think that's the right idea. You should share this if you haven't yet.

Feel free to post this as a separate inspiration Nima, after all it's your inspiration here that jogged by mind on this ;)I'm actually flooded with work right now =(, so not sure I'll have the time to write up a full inspiration that does this justice before the inspiration phase closes.

b_schools_as_idea_incubator.description: There are lots of business schools coming up these days everywhere in the world. B schools should encourage entrepreneurs to launch their business.
b_schools_as_idea_incubator.creator: 89e235e8d4c519960762f976f34e5329

comments.text: This is a great idea, but I don't think it should be limited to just business schools. American colleges and universities should teach entrepreneurism, not just academia. Most colleges have general education requirements that ensure students take courses in science, arts, math, language, etc. Why not make it required that every student takes an entrepreneurship course as well? Entrepreneurship can be taught, and there's no reason it shouldn't be required.

Clemson University is doing this very thing They are starting a new MBA program in June that is billed as "365 days from zero to start-up". The program is based on entrepreneurship and positioning the students to launch their idea as they are finishing the program. I am looking forward to seeing what their first class accomplishes.

Nice idea Sargam. This is already done by many B-Schools as well as engineering schools in fact. I know it's the case at NYU, and in several other schools I know in the US. This might be less developed in Europe (but I might be wrong). Yet, Imperial College in London  has also interesting programs to support entrepreneurship: http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/entrepreneurshipThere might be a way to develop a framework for these competitions to happen in various countries in Europe, maybe with connections across schools. As the challenge focuses on webentrepreneurs, you could imagine having a specific focus for some of these competitions (web and technology, social innovation, sustainability, e.g.)

Thanks Anne...i agree that there are lot of B schools running such programmaes but there are lot of places where such step has not been taken on a large scale. Like in India there are not many schools who have taken the initiative,,,So as Meena has also thrown a light on the point, I think there should be a centralised body to coordinate and approach B Schools to start such programmes...and since internet is the necessity today..so lot of emphasis can be given to start competitions which motivate web entrepreneurship.

Agreed and  I think the idea would be to think of how to structure such an organization / program. How then would this "centralized body" look like? Who would be the actors? What would be the incentives? I guess these are questions you might want to explore as you're developing this concept.My comments was also highlighting the European context because of the EU sponsorship but this could be reproduced in other continents and connections could be developed across countries.

I agree, Sargam! More B schools should encourage entrepreneurship. Some schools do have programs. I went to University of Wisconsin- Madison and we had one there. I believe Texas - Austin does as well. I'm sure there are others. But maybe these courses should be more integral to the degree. Perhaps one entrepreneurship class should be required to graduate. Too often it seems as if people don't even think of a startup as a viable option. And the truth is, there's nothing our economy needs more than individuals following their passions and creating their own purpose.

True Dan.I agree with you view of having one entrepreneurship class should to graduate. I have also done MBA and in India not many B schools encourage such steps by organizing competitions and providing sponsorships. Therefore lot of people end up looking for corporate jobs because they don't get the opportunity and motivation to present their ideas. So I think more B schools should encourage students for entrepreneurship by providing them the right platform.

Lovely idea, Sargam. Have you seen Social Innovation Camp? http://www.sicamp.org/ Your idea sounds like a great development from this - allows you longer to develop your idea (SiCamp is only 48 hours long) and nuture it over time. Receiving guidance as a start-up is essential.

Agreed Louise..I feel that receiving right guidance is very much necessary...SiCamp is the instant way to give a shape to your idea and I think going through competition might be little longer but I am sure it will motivate students doing business courses to start something on their own.

Interesting thoughts, Sargram. Do you envision some kind of centralised body to facilitate this (and perhaps get B Schools, corporates, etc competing to participate)  or each B School to operate individually?

Thanks Meena...i think there should be some centralised body which should approach corporates, venture capitalists etc. to participate..also it should approach B schools to start some kind of entrepreneurship incentive programme individually on their own so that more and more students can participate. So, a centralised body should be there to manage and review the progress but B schools should operate individually to start programmes own their own.

comments.text: The problem that we had in Greece (and still have) and we have found that there is in Europe is that investors dont hand dawn even the 30%... Basically the problem lays on exactly this point. Investors arent willing to risk on early stage nothing for them is irrelevant if they will loose by 80% chances instead of 200K, 100K or 70K for them is still money and what matters for them is the low returns that they get So programs like that which expecting the combined private assessment/investing to trigger the process are poised to fail because investors simply dont trigger the process in the magnitude needed Because what is not understood by all (policy makers, financial engineers, economists etc.), are the underlined mechanics of the cause that makes investors flee from early stage For an investor is irrelevant if he is going to loose just the tip of his finger or half of his finger it is still a loss while there are other types of investments that return much more predictable results. So why to risk? Tax breaks and other incentives are based on the assumption that a success would happen so they will get the extra but that isnt the case 80% are the chances of failure for startups

"Especially many comments see 50% as very optimistic", trick here is then you need to select projects with higher protection - like Bio or Nano technology which can be patented and maximum innovation = but this can be achieved only by to investing into radical inventions ?

comments.text: Props on the use of "chunky" hahaha What else can EC offer beyond funding? Some entrepreneurs might find a work space or a truck more useful than cash. Opening up the conversation with at least one are of EC must not be too difficult. How about we ask them what else can they offer?

Yes, Chunky is a wonderful euphemism! Totally agree, the EC has lots more to offer - segway into our other concept - the Start Up Shop, which would provide space, advice and business consultants, funding and developers would earn virtual credit for helping out on other projects
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

I wish I'd come up with this concept, Munich! Genius idea. You're right to add the caveat but it's a bit like taking on an intern to help out but this could really benefit both parties. I'd love to see 'fresh designers' go and shake up the design process.Surely this could be prototyped straight away? Can we find a department or area in the EU which needs help straight away?

Exactly, why didnt I think of that! I think a good start would be Horizon2020, to get involved as designers. We started a little concept on that to start with a workshop through the DAA (organizer of this challenge) http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/what-needs-to-be-done-pool-teahouse/#c-93e2358394526cc28d3d7baa1ea74d5a

Love the win-win here. What other ways are there to help start-ups bootstrap? For instance Telefonica is already supporting start-ups with Wayra (http://www.wayra.org/) - instead of funding companies could offer part-time jobs for founders of all flavours - and get the benefit of having some entrepreneurial blood in the system.

thanks for sharing Wayra amy. The EU does not have 'telefocnica' offices everywhere, not the people. What I could imagine is 'upgrading' National Contact Points/Desks to be intermediary between DAA mission and exiting (IT) firms who want to support startups with expert time/space.

great idea. loads of procurement rules to get around but if it could be done fairly and transparently, this could work very well.It only helps web designer - led starts ups though. How could entrepreneurs with great UX concepts but who are neither technologists nor designers get involved? Perhaps this could be combined with one of the various match-making concepts that have been posted in the Connecting People section?
Nice build Tim!
This is an excellent idea for startups with site design expertise.
I can also see how this concept is connected to your start up shop concept and how it could help "funding" the participation to the start up shop space.

starting_a_business_starting_a_family.description: Mumsnet is a virtual community where new mums can discuss everything from diapers (cloth or disposable) to repairing relationships strained by a new baby. This is a lovely analogy for the challenges of starting (& growing) a business.
starting_a_business_starting_a_family.creator: 7771fbb20af6ef10827c593daa3aff7b

comments.text: @Amy, 350 views and 15 applause... I see a little 'parentling booklet' concept.. you? Maybe with foundersroadmap of Ashley as a poster in the middle.
Great analogy - new parents are keen to learn from people like them, those that have been on a similar journey.  How can we match make entrepreneurs in a similar way?

Having a pivot in an informational world where news come from all directions (pro-am), an startup benefits from the inception and nurturing to the grown up stage when accompanied by a mentoring role model as Sina Mossayed illustrates "TechStars". It's a proven recipe.
Great analogy. This also makes me think of the potential to have specific initiatives needed to support women entrepreneurs and mothers.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Fab analogous inspiration Amy! I'm excited to see these parallels, especially around defining what success looks like. Here's hoping your questions lead to some great discussion!

Probably to a cool concept!! 9 months preparation the baby startup can survive outside the womb. This counts also for company startup. 9 months investing no money, just a lot of time and making connections which shape the (startup) baby. year 1 : only about survival; is the businesscase in all essence logic, natural, an internal ecosystem relating with an outside ecosystem. Basically the first year you should be able to do a startup company in spare time. Between work and life, just like a real baby. All the way to the baby is 7-8, as than children's mindset change to grasp life as it is. If a company doesn't change it's mindset to a bigger environment, it will suffer. Silicon Valley took 7-8 years to take over the world ;)Parenting, father and mother 'roles' are important to divide. If you don't than you end up doing both half, with a baby all time in the daycare and your minds always at the laptop to work.. etc. etc. ;)

Love the family analogy. As a father of a toddler of three in the middle of reinventing our roles. 9 months preparation , for mum and dad. Than basically 2-3 years of organized chaos :) This is same for startup. And how the baby develops, body+brain+abilities can be greatly mapped/rolled out for company startup! Also, the essential different roles of mum and dad...
Glad to hear it works. Any other things that have helped you guys get through it all?

Through? in the middle we are!  : ) A very important aspect to make it as a startup is realizing/believing; "It needs to be done". You can't stop feeding your own child once you decided you have one. The same is for startup, you need to answer 'does this product/service' really NEEDS to be done', Or, we do it just because it is (technically possible).Parents don't make babies because it is technically possible...I think within this lies the answer for Europe to become succesfull in webstartups; Young people understanding what NEEDS to be done in Europe, on the globe, in the neighborhood for that matter... build the web environments/tools, nurture the baby, and one day go travel with it on other continents.For what "needs to be done" great analogies can help us forward here.
In free time I am also desiging toys, true is,  there is nothing so more inspiring them your own kids :-)

starting_a_business_starting_a_family.title: Starting a business = starting a family?

crowdfunding_crowdcube.com.description: The world's first business finance crowdfunding platform for businesses to raise equity finance.
crowdfunding_crowdcube.com.creator: d1098c78d52c8160edccd29d50ed3fdb

comments.text: I am big believer in Crowdfunding. I think their are lots of different models out there (Kickstarter and IndieGoGo have already been mentioned) and I have no intention of saying one is "better" than the other.I added Crowdcube as I believe it's the only platform offering true equity investment.I am personally looking forward to the future NESTA report on this topic [http://goo.gl/UhioY]. Crowdfunding is still in it's infancy [http://goo.gl/e339N] but exciting times ahead!For anyone interesting in finding out more I would recommend the following:- The crowdfunding wiki was created after the Wikipedia page was removed [http://crowdfunding.pbworks.com/]- Kevin Lawton has a series of presentations online and even wrote a book called "The Crowdfunding Revolution"- Charles Armstrong's company Trampoline System managed to raise 1m over four rounds from private investors, also behind the recent Tech City Map [http://crowdfunding.trampolinesystems.com/]- Catarse is a Brazilian open source crowdfunding platform with source code available on GitHub [http://catarse.me]- Other noteworthy platforms (besides Kickstarter, IndieGoGo and Crowdcube) are Peoplefund.it, GrowVC, Profounder.com, Seeders, Buzzbnk and many I am probably yet to discover!
Nice one Thomas. It's going to be really interesting to see what all the discussions on crowd funding yield in our upcoming Concepting phase  we're looking forward to some bright, bold ideas!
This is a great inspiration Thomas - I agree that Crowd Cube seems to be pioneering crowdfunding for equity which feels like a more sustainable model for many web startups

I too am a believer in crowdfunding, there are lots of crowdfunding platforms out there, but most of them are closed source. I have been trying to find open source projects. There is very little to go on, one project i did find was called Thrinacia, it will be fully open source and available to the public. It is still a work in progress, but could be very beneficial in the near future. The site is https://www.thrinacia.com/ if anyone is interested in reading up on it.

Good idea Thomas!In my opinion, the best thing anybody can do to foster entrepreneurship is to remove the barriers that exist.Raising capital at the seed stage is a huge barrier for web entrepreneurs, so I think that this is a great solution to the challenge.Crowdcube, and now Seedrs, which will be the first platform to launch with FSA approval, provide a model for how crowdfunding can work to fund startups.I spent sometime in South America studying crowdfunding, and I think it's a really powerful trend that can revolutionize fundraising everywhere around the world. I look forward to discussing this more in the next phase!

crowdfunding_crowdcube.com.title: Crowdfunding/crowdcube.com
